Must be one of the best waterfronts and shopping malls in South Africa. The waterfront is a place where just about everything can be found. The place is abuzz with people from all walks of life.
A place that must be visited when you are in Cape Town.

Heart of Cape Town. This is the happening place of Cape Town, better in the evening. Lots of activities & very nice eating joint, so make it a point to visit this place during youir visit to Cape Town.

The great Waterfront. This experience is something else. There is just too much too see and you really need enough time to experience everything. It is like being in another world. Food, activities, scenery and the boat trip are the best. If you do not go on the Lady Jane boat trip you have not been to the Waterfront. It is just all unexplainable you must experience it to appreciate it. I love it and can go there all the time because everytime you go there is something new.

Lovely place for a walk, for browsing or serious designer shoppers. V&A is beautifully situated right on the waterfront, so it has a beautiful view of the harbour and you can take a leisurely walk breathing in either the bustle of harbour life or shoppers heaven! Shops are so widely ranging in price, quality, from basic tacky souvenir stalls to the highest couture all within the V&A. So no matter your budget, you can afford to visit, take in the atmosphere and eat here. Parking availability is high - look out for the best prices, check before you go as some charge more than others.

Vibrant & safe & full of amusements. There are markets full of great little stalls of both prepared foods like empanadas, samosas, salads, cheeses, nuts, as well as local artists stalls. There are many restaurants, shops, boats to go out on, a great aquarium, a Ferris wheel and much more.

Urban adventure. There is so much to hold your interest at the V&A and its kid friendly. The Aquarium,Watershed (art market), Food Market, Museums, Ferris Wheel, Shopping Malls, Brewery and restaurants all surround a bustling working harbour harbour with the majestic table mountain in the background. The are unique urban art photo opportunities and live entertainment. If you have 1 day in Cape Town, this is worth a visit...

Something for everyone. I am lucky enough to live just north of Cape Town and one of our treats is to eat in one of the waterfront restaurants every Friday.The waterfront is much more than somewhere to eat - although you have a fantastic choice of restaurants and many of them have a great view of Table Mountain and the harbor. Whilst have lunch you have ample opportunity to people watch and also watch the many boat trips coming and going from the harbor.Inside there are many shops to browse - my girlfriend can always find something to buy!Add in the opportunity to get an alternative view of the area by riding in the Cape Town wheel. You will always find a single of group of buskers playing music in the area and if you want somewhere will sketch your portrait for you.I feel blessed to be able to enjoy the waterfront every week of the year.

Wish I would have had more time there.. This area has lots of shops and restaurants. It is very commercial, with malls and mini type malls. But there is also a South African flare that if you have the time would be very nice to take in. There were singing groups preforming in front of one mall, and lots of people strolling around. You can catch the hop on, hop off bus there or ride the big ferris wheel.
Lots to do. Lots of bars and restaurants, shops gallore! Try the food market and craft market...Lots to see and buy...Great bags and jewlery

Tourist traffic. This is the most obvious and cliched thing to do in CBD. Felt like I was in a high end mall in the Americas. Wend your way instead through the wonderful neighborhoods in the Cape. Stay away.
Did not expect to like it- but I did!. It sounded very touristic but is actually quite a nice spot with a functioning harbor, lots of restaurants and nice shops.

A great place to eat. Cape Town has a deserved reputation as a foodie destination. Nature is bountiful here and the seas offer up amazing fish - try snoek, a meaty flat fish, kingklip and luxuriously huge crayfish and prawns, inexpensive compared with the rest of the world. Cape Town has always been a mixture of many influences, now further enhanced by the influx of global tourism. As a result you can find pretty much any kind of cuisine you want here, done well and with the freshest ingredients - including the spicy local cuisine Cape Malay. Look out for outstanding Italian restaurants - a result of the big Italian community in Cape Town, descended from migrant workers who came to work on the South African railways. The V&A Waterfront is a great place to eat, you’ll find everything from starched table clothed restaurants to street food here. Other great spots include Camps Bay and trendy Green Point, the so-called “Soho of Cape Town”.
Something for everyone. the V & A has something for everyone, boats shops cafes, restaurants. Night time is buzzing, excellent.
Alba lounge waterfront. Attended a function at Alba lounge and was blown away by the service and exceptional food Awesome venue

Amazing. The V & A is always a buzz. Lots of shops, eateries or just sit and watch the world go by. There is always something to do there. I come from Sydney and it makes our Darling Harbour look tiny. It's a must see

Fancy but relaxed and with live entertainment. The V&A is basically a must see in Cape Town. It is very classically stylish, has great dining and shopping and is basically targeted at tourists and has all they could need. You can stock up on souvenirs, handcrafted goods, get your hair braided, taste regional cuisine, you name it!Apart from the touristic appeal, however, the water front offers very pleasant walks and sitting areas to just enjoy the fresh breeze and the sound of the waves. Interestingly, it doesn't smell super fishy like in other harbours. Another great bonus are the street artists and musicians that have really good performances.
The fun in Waterfront!. Always fun, always something to do, meeting up with the most incredible people, love the shops and the restaurants. There is something for anyone ! You will love it!

Relax in the restaurants. The number one tourist spot in Cape Town, you get the vibe of a working harbour/port with the convenience of a huge shopping mall and dozens of restaurants. Easy to visit many times and enjoy each visit.

A tourist mecca. It is all there. Every shop you can imagine. V&A is the tourist scene for Cape Town. Some like it others don't. I'm not that fond of it but it is a very busy tourist attraction. Judge for yourself.

Only in Africa!!. The V & A Waterfront is basically the same as any large shopping complex you would find in any large city in the world with the usual regulation shops etc. What makes the V & A unique however is the impromtu entertainment, there is always a live band playing in the street somewhere. On my visit I was lucky enough to see a band called 'We are Africa' so their T shirts read, a four piece combo who play instruments similar in appearance to a xlyphone but gave a sound like a Jamaican steel drum, but what made them even more original was the lead singer who got up on a concrete plinth, folded his arms across his chest and gave a spirited rendition of 'O Sole Mio'!!! It was amazing, only in Africa? YES!!!

Nice place to walk and enjy evening. visited the place in evening around 5 pm and the place lived to expectation, altough no cruises or boat trips at that time but the sheer view of the place and sea was amazing. the giant wheel is one good experience with tickets only 100 rand to see the city from the top. There are lots of restaurant and shops with good stuff mainly sports clothes and artifacts. The fish market is must see and good to walk around. The restaurants are plenty and offer wonderful choices of meals and drinks. there is mall which hosts branded shops for brand lovers and fast food outlets. the wifi in the area if free and its adds value to visit. just be careful of the taxis which are ready to take you for a ride and over charge you. the place closes by 8 pm mainly for business with only restaurants operating.

Shopping and food. we stayed in a apartment close by,we visited on a sunday afternoon and it was packed with people having a good time in the sunshine.Lots to see and lovely restaurants and bars to cater for all types and tastes.Great supermarket in the main shopping centre with a great selection of hot and cold food,just perfect for our apartment. Very good security and we felt safe and relaxed in this lovely part of town.Good on you Capetown

A LOT of Everything!. It is always fun and exciting to browse the V&A Waterfront with its working harbour, multitude of shops and restaurants, magnificent views of Table Mountain and the ocean, as well as the various entertainment options that it offers. Whenever we take friends from abroad there they simply cannot get enough of this place. There is most certainly something for everyone! Too much to describe, but please do visit their website: http://www.waterfront.co.za/

fairy tale mall perfect water front setting. With its charming architecture, water vistas, giant wheel, working harbors, lots of street performers and fairy lights in the night, this mall is a must visit when you are in cape town. it is 100% tourist centric so do not be fooled into thinking you will go where the "locals go" BUT they have done such a stellar job of making it into a tourist attraction that you can easily spend hours browsing through shops, craft market, curio market, wellness center etc. when you get tired of strolling, you can make your way into one of the 1000 places to eat here within all budget. If you are not fussy about eating at a restaurant, you can pop into the waterfront food market where you get everything from ice creams to cakes to sandwiches, burgers etc all under same roof. They have benches by the water where you can sit and enjoy your meal and probably also spot a seal or two swim by. There is also a food court with indoor seating. I would recommend to anyone visiting water front to pop into one of the many restaurants that offer gorgeous harbor views as the views are to die for

**Brrrrr....Not what I remember at all!. Visited after a long time and I was shocked at how different the atmosphere was. The cute little mobile stalls that sold all sorts of pretty wears are no longer around and the list of local eateries has changed.No longer feels like the waterfront but like a strange shiny place that is actually not in CT, but somewhere far away. I always thought that it reflected the city which its in, it now feels more like it reflects the rest of teh world....nothing special. Maybe its all the physical changes, not sure, but it feels rather cold.

Shopping and Food. Any tourists visiting Cape Town that think they mightnt feel safe walking around just go here. The safest shopping and dinning area in the city. Security everywhere but not in your face. The shopping centre has everything. High end shops are also found here. Car park if driving or most hotels have a shuttle bus. Great food outlets. Plenty for all the family or friends. Great spot. Def staying around this area again

Ideal setting for a stroll. This is the ideal place if you want to grab something to eat and do a little shopping. There is also a market with local produce and typical food which you can buy or eat on the go.I visited in May, which was Fall down there, and the colours were breathtaking, blu sky, beautiful colourful boats and lights all over the arbour.The place is well worth a visit if you are nearby, highly recommended.

Always a good day out. Loved coming here as a kid and love visiting every time I get back to CT! There is always something new to find on a visit - just a little disappointed that on this visit the Red Shed was shut and I couldnt find half the stalls that are usually there.Hopefully next time it'll be open again.I would advise to avoid going into the V&A if there is any kind of event on at Green Point Stadium as the whole place goes a little mental. We made the mistake of going in on the day the One Direction concert was on - big mistake!! But we got out before it went too crazy

Great for shopping and eating. If your looking from getting away from the centre of Cape Town, then this is the ideal place to be. It has a shopping mall with lots of designers shops that are expensive then London! The restaurants are good, especially in the evening, if you want a nice and quite night out. It's cost approx 60 rand in a cab return to long street !
Tourist spot. Good enough place for some food and shopping, but feels like you're in any other city - not really an 'attraction'. Good supermarket downstairs.
Good shopping and value for money restaurants. A very good selections of restaurants to suit all budgets, look for bargains when shopping, don't always pay the high prices some expect.

Amazing. This is an amazing complex with some great shops and good restaurants where tourists and locals alike come to shop and eat. We spent the best part of a day walking around here and still didn't see all the shops - many of which have items that are unique to South Africa.
Very Busy Waterfront with Lots of To Do's. Very attractive waterfront area with many restaurants and shops. A nice way to spend the afternoon after sightseeing.

Always changing. The V&A waterfront is still undergoing construction but mostly finished. The shops are very tourist orientated and prices seem higher, but the variety and clean surroundings is worth it. The shops are very near the cruise terminal- walking is a bit of a challenge to get there while under construction, but worth it. There is a lot of street entertainment, we bought a couple of CD's of singers and bands as souveniers and well worth it.

A good place for food and shopping. A surprisingly large shopping experience over 3 floors with a good mix of shops. Outside facing the waterfront there are a plethora of restaurants and bars, gift/souvenir shops and a big wheel (which is lit at night). The restaurants offer a huge variety of cuisine types at very reasonable prices. We ate on the Waterfront 2 nights out of the 3 we stayed in Cape Town. It would be useful to have some indication of what restaurants/businesses are where as they can be very difficult to find.

Heartbeat of Cape Town!. The V&A Waterfront has a culture of its own. The dock offers great views and the place has some very good antique shops and great resurants.From some locations you get beautiful views of the ocean and Robben Island. One of Cape Towns biggest Mall is also located at the water front.

Central Hub for activities and Food. Great shopping for guys and girls, many activities to sign up for near the water (such as the Sunset Sail). Great food everywhere you turn, live bands playing incredible music, great atmosphere.

Great Place. This waterfront is absolutely beautiful! I loved the bridge, the restaurants and the large African statues on the stairs on showcase. I especially loved the live entertainment of African dances and the amazing and many beautiful souvenirs.

Great shopping and food. My wife and I were planning to spend only one hour or two at the waterfront and we ended up spending most of the day. The setting is spectacular with the views of the bay and Table Mountain. The shops are excellent, the prices are low and you can get stuff that you don't see in the States. The restaurants are excellent as well, specially Willoughby's.

I ate at several restaurants on the Waterfront and they were all an enjoyable experience.. There were a variety of restaurants to choose from and when my feet were sore from walking. I popped in to the Wellness Warehouse at the Waterfront to enjoy a fantastic Reflexology massage from Sean, he's good and tell him Jessica from Norway recommended him, lol...

trendy. My wife had a ball here with the trendy shops and restaurants. It was a bit too 'touristy' and not really representative of Cape Town or South Africa. More what you would expect in LA or Sydney.
Great pastime . Have come here numerous times. Always nice hangout. Amphitheatre great to be around. Loads of restaurants. Robben island in the distant. Must do for everyone!
If you have time to wander.... Nice place to spend an afternoon walking around. Pretty shops and good restaurants. We had a wonderful dinner at the Greek restaurant.

Wonderful Transformation of the old Cape Town Docks.. Lovely restaurants shops hotels yacht marina street performances big wheel trips in the bay local arts and crafts and I am sure lots more I have missed.Another area of the Mother City tourists must not miss. At least four hours.
Lively area with excellent restaurants. loved the harbor views and the lively atmosphere. There are many restaurants to choose from and the seafood was outstanding.

V & A Waterfront. Otherwise just known as the 'Waterfront' in Cape Town it offers anything a person can want from an Aston Martin real car to its miniature version from a well stocked toy shop. There are hundreds of shops stocking local and international brands including clothing and even semi precious stones of Africa not to mention plenty of first class jewellery stores. Restaurants galore to suit every taste and pocket, cinemas - and outside one can experience the 'Wheel' in your own cubicle or take a cruise around the harbour - you may be lucky enough to see some internationally acclaimed yacht moored on one of the jetties or seals just dozing a few feet below you.

Watershed or Dryshed at V+A. Disappointed to see how undersupportted the new "Water-Shed" area is, what are you doing to "push" more visitors to that side of the V+A, poor stall holders bored to death sitting there and that on a Saturday PM when weather is foul and no one on beach, but rather in Malls like V+A/Cavendish/Canal Walk etc.?

It will just keep pulling you back for more.... I just love the V & A waterfront in Cape Town! The fantastic variety of food and restaurants and pubs, (we have our favorites but still love trying new eating experiences too) the craft market has the most beautiful and unique gifts I have seen in South Africa (even if it is a bit out of price range for the average South African), the feris wheel at night (lots of fun), the street musicians, the boat trips or rowing in and around the harbor, helicopter rides, Robben Island trips (which we did not do as ours was cancelled due to weather as this time of the year - something to look forward to next time). You just cannot get enough. When you want to sit and take a break, there are plenty of outside taverns if its sunny or a warm pub to crawl into when the winter chill bites a little. Just keep going back... every time! LOVE CPT! <3

An excellent entertainment destination. A vast Shopping mall, extensive Food court, Water cruises, trips and amusement rides makes this a must visit place in Cape town. The Local arts does have a strong presence and one can get loads of handicrafts, metal crafts, clothing and local cuisine in abundance. A range of water rides in different sized boats or ferries, ensures a good outing for the entire family. Sunset cruises are quite popular among the visiting couples and two oceans aquarium nearby does add a lot of knowledge to the growing children. The amphitheater in the centre does host some interesting programs throughout the year according to the season and we could watch a good choir group during our visit there. A fantastic lively place and an experience of a lifetime.

Love It. A welcoming, clean & fun environment. Fun things to do for all ages. Great for tourists & locals. Shops are full of interesting things, but my fav area was the local artist craft area. There were so many beautiful choices by such talented people.I am only sorry I was worried to chance packing items for a long flight home. Next time I'll carry it on board. Outdoor dining is great for people watching.

A must for every visitor to Cape Town. You can shop local clothing, top brand clothing, curios, jewellery, diamonds, food ( from fish to the best steaks, sushi, burgers, hot dogs, pizzas and enjoy all this with the view of the ocean on the one side and the famous Table Mountain on the other. You can also book into the best hotels here and connect to a hop on hop off bus to see the various sight seeing Cape Town has to offer. You can also watch a movie at one of the cinemas at this complex.

All in one place in Cape Town especially during the rainy season. If you haven't visited the V&A as a local or international tourist, do make the effort to go out there. The advantage of this destination is that it has something to offer the entire family. Caters for shopaholics, foodies and relaxation. The Wellness hub on the upper level of the Watershed offers wide choices from massages to eastern treatments without the hassle of long appointments.Food offerings are wide in terms of cost and variety of cuisine.Choose from the different options of boat rides and don't be pressured into getting onto the first boat offer because they're leaving in five minutes (You still end up waiting 15-25 minutes). Lots of beautiful crafts but take your time buying them because you might see them at a more reasonable price elsewhere during your visit. In short, a day at the V&A isn't enough...
Good atmosphere. The heart of the city maybe? Great selection of shops and restaurants. Put your comfy shoes on as things are fairly spread out. Note you have to pay for parking.

My second home. You have everything here, plenty of restaurants of different cuisins. I would recommend Tashas for a menu with a big range of options to brunch/lunch/dinner, Whilloughbys for the best sushi (in a shopping mall? strange i know), you have the movie theatres here, regular seats or "Scene" where sits are bigger and more expensive. Woolworths (better fruit and vegetables) and Pick n Pay (cheaper) are the supermarkets. @Home and Woolworths have things for the house, Clicks is the a huge pharmacy, Nespresso, Zara, Cotton On, Top Shop, Gstar, Country Road and Trenery, Calvin Klein, and the expensive brands such as Louis Vuitton, Gucci, Burberrys, etc which i hardly buy so i wouldnt know much about them. You have entertaingin for kids outside as well as a small amphitheater. Saturdays ans sundays during summer is pure joy, there is small african bands playing live and dancing, and the Cape Wheel, with a stunning view to the Table Mountain. Its a must go if you come to CT

Go!. The is The place to stay...shopping, restaurants,safety, quality craft and food market .. This was the best food and shopping in one place with the comfort of security thru 11pm at night.. If you are staying CT stay in this area, no question..,

V & A Waterfront - don't miss it!!!!. Great variety of restaurants to suit all budgets. Cape Town Fishmarket Restaurant is fabulous. Costs a little more than average but well worth it. Plenty of souvenir shops. Visit McIntosh's Bar and try the piri-piri chicken.The Big Red Shed houses local artizans whose craftsmanship is well worth checking out.

Great shopping and dining. This is a very touristy area and is active well into the evening. This is a good location for staying while in Capetown. There is a large ferris wheel that you can spot from anywhere in the area. Many fine restaurants throughout the area as well as a beautiful shopping mall with high level stores selling jewelry, clothing and gift items. There are also many tour operators along the harbor offering all kinds of tours.

A must!!! . If you visit sa you should stay in this area, it's safe, tons I mean tons of restaurants and shops and plenty of security at night. I wouldn't stay any other area in Cape Town .. Was here for a week loved every minute... Food is so cheap and excellent quality.. Best places I've ever eaten., and the watershed has great crafts.. Don't go anywhere else for authentic buys.. And the malls are also a nice option.. There is also a food store and pharmacy there as well.. Don't forget to also visit the food market! Crazy good! Like I said it's the place to stay as your hub for excursions.. And dinner/shopping... Perfect! Miss it already!!!

"It's a trap", as Admiral Ackbar would have put it.... If you're looking for a convenient place to eat, then go to the food court where you can find Pizza, Burgers, Fish & Chips, Asian food and frozen yoghurt (and almost all are halal).But, other than this, it's just a huge tourist trap.It's filled with over-priced shops, at which your regular South African will never be able to afford to shop. And, most of the time, the clothes, bags and shoes, are just regular quality, Chinese-manufactured items, polished and displayed perfectly, so that they can add a hefty price tag. Europeans and Americans, beware! You are the target market of these shops... if you find something that you really, really like, go ahead and buy it. Otherwise, spend your $$$ on food or drinks, or at the market, or a boat ride, or transport to explore the other areas outside of CT.

Love it. So many things. We went to the Comedy Store - great fun and cheap (by English standards). The Ferryman's is great, we ate in four or five other places and I think you'll be hard pushed not to find fantastic places to eat, drink and be merry.

Tourist centre with shops and restuarants. This area is the hub of Cape Town as far as tourists are concerned so you need to think about how much you are paying at many of the shops and restaurants. There are reasonable things within the centre and one restaurant that really stood out for us called Cape Town Fish Market. The biggest fish restaurant we have ever seen with separate sushi bar, fish and chip department, and main seating area. The main area is waiter service with everything available from a menu including many fish dishes cooked in many different ways. Prices where very much lower than most of the other places we reviewed the menu at, although in all fairness if you are out to impress your companion and need a waiter in a bow tie, and fewer people around you this may not be your place. We loved it and the quality of the food could not be beaten as judging by the crowds and sometimes the ques waiting for a table most of Cape Town must agree.Close by but not inside the Victoria & Alfred is a craft market, a snack bar, coffee shop, and cafe area, and an aquarium. We bought most of our gifts in the craft market hand made local products, we drank the best coffee in Cape Town, and enjoyed a fantastic fish feeding session in the aquarium where divers fed the fish, in what must be one of the worlds biggest fish tanks, whilst fending of massive sharks. You got to see it to believe it.

Hippy, Trendy Place. Waterfront is an awesome place to do some shopping, watch a movie, go for a quick bite and coffee or eat out. Various shopping brands to shop for, good shopping hours for the late working people and the amphitheater usually always have some event going on.

FABULOUS DAY OUT. There are many things to do at the Waterfront. It is also the starting point of the city tours and trip to Robben island. Boat trips and many more. Fabulous markets, the aquarium. Top class shops and restaurants. Lovely curios an live entertainment.
Perfect place. Great view of sunset, amazing restaurants and the best place in Cape Town to enjoy youself!!! Drink a Savannah beer and eat a slice of fish and fries!

Awesome !. We loved it !! I found it better than the views at Sydney Harbour area or the SFO Pier 39. Its got stunning views.. lots of shopping.. amazing food... nice play areas for kids. We spent one full afternoon and evening there.. but didn't feel enough... so on our last day at Cape town.. we spent another morning there.. must visit in morning as well for better views ... its a must go if you are in Cape Town.
Good shopping & dining precinct. Bright & lively shopping & dining area, with bars & a wide range of restaurants. It is clean and staff in all the outlets are very good.

Everything you want & more. The waterfront is beautiful; with great restaurants, shopping & people watching.
It is a must visit location while in Cape Town. You won't be disappointed.

Fun place to spend the day. This place has a good mix of shops, delicious food, curio shops, boat tours and fun things for kids to do. We loved the view of Table Mountain. We did a half hour tour around the harbor which gave us unique views of the area.

Capetown Waterfront. So many restaurants, all very reasonably priced, all very clean, staff all polite and efficient, all the meals and snacks we had were either very good or excellent. Shopping centre to suit absolutely everyone, I have never seen such a good choice of shopping; great for local souvenirs up to the best designer stores. I think it would take me about three days to see all the shops so I am going back next year.

Improved. Just visit the Shed, listen to the ad hoc music, buy from the many and various stalls offering African Goods, buy the spices that are as cheap as chips, go to the Food market to experience the tastes of South Africa and view Table Mountain and just decide to go back again

A special place. The V&A is a great place to visit for young and old. A very clean and very safe area with lots to see and do. We took the grandkids on the 'Big Wheel' and it was great. The shopping areas are excellent and we had some of the best coffee 'ever' so no complaints at all.

Last tango in Cape Town. We took some short term visitors here from USA and were completely satisfied with the shopping and dining and people watching. The services here include helicopters to shark diving and safaris with a optional cape wine lands lunch to a simple lunch, drinks and dinner. The amazing mall is also nice.Easy visit for shoppers.

Interesting bustling area.. We stopped here for a lunch and a look around while on a hop on hop off bus tour. it has a typical old port area as well as modern buildings, restaurants and a very nice market area. I found it a bit of a jumble but still fun. Didn't have long in the market area but could have spent more time there. Some very interesting little stores but also some high end ones as well - especially jewelry stores! I was actually wanting to buy a little souvenir e.g. an elephant pendant, but couldn't find something simple like that! (I found one in Kalk Bay!). A great place to spend half a day.

Very much aimed at the tourist. What can you say? Great variety of shops but very touristy. There's a lot of art to purchase for your living room as well as furniture, jewellery and of course clothing. This is for the more well-heeled so bring your credit card.I mostly hung around here watching the bridge go up and the yachts go by. The Two Ocean's Aquarium is part of the Waterfront and definitely recommended. Also the better restaurants are around here - not to say the ones on Long Street aren't good.Shopping mall has anything you want, from supermarket to children's toys, beach and diving gear or expensive trainers, shoes and suits. You can also book your cage diving with sharks here.

Everything you could ask for in a shopping centre. From clothes to food. Artwork local and imported. Live music. Brand orientated shops and funky little ones. I couldn't think of anything missing. If you are a tourist in town this is your one stop shopping center. Did I mention the amazing view ???
Lovely waterfront, very safe.. Love the waterfront. Great places to eat, though some are pricey by SA standards. Very safe to walk around late at night. Good for families, couples, etc.

A Staple Visit in CT.. The V&A is always a great place to stop at when visiting Cape Town, with many activities and great restaurants in one location, its a one stop spot. Not to mention the amazing views of Table Mountain and the historic waterfront itself. There is always a bustle of people come day or night, and visitors from every corner of the globe.

Bustling. The V&A Waterfront is a very vibrant place. Lots of things to do. From dining to taking a boat trip to Robben Island. I enjoyed the craft markets very much. For a local, the prices in the Waterfront would appear to be a bit steep though

Something for everybody.. The V&A Waterfront must be Cape Town's best man made attraction. Supported by locals and tourists alike this development has something for everybody. Shops, restaurants, entertainment and kids activities. The new watershed development is also a perfect place to see all our local arts, crafts and designers in a stylish setting under one roof.

FAB!. Best place in Cape Town!Best foodBest musicBest ambianceBest shopsBest pubsBest viewsNeed I go on?Visited and stayed here over the past 10 years and still keep coming back..what does that tell you??

Must visit destination. There are many restaurants and we tried out a few. we shopped and bought great stuff. I went to see a movie, the movie house was very comfortable. there was so much to se and enjoy. We talked and made many friends.
Heavan on Earth. Time stands still. Time to relax and just enjoy this once in a world wonderful Setting. So many choices, excellant Service, great Food.

Convenient and safe. This was the only place that I visited in Cape Town which offers a relaxed shopping vibe. Lovely restaurants and bars and lots of various activities to do. I felt safe at all times. Lots of different shops to buy presents and just chill out.
Waterfront. Lots of restaurants. Lively and bustling place with every shop your heart desires. A great place to just stroll and soak in the wonderful atmosphere of a harbour.
Busy and plenty to do. Too many shops and not enough attractions for the non shopper. Plenty of restaurants and snack bars. Lots of activity on the water too.
A Cape Town must do!. This is one of the most visited spots in Africa. Now I can see why there is a bunch of activities for everyone. This the main tourist hub a huge mall restaurants galore.

A busy harbor with good restaurants and shops. During the day, harbor cruises are available as well as the ferry to Robbin Island. Evening has nightlife, shops of all kinds and some very good restaurants - particularly Harbor House for seafood.

Proud to be South African. What a wonderful place for foreigners and locals alike to spend time visiting all the wonderful shops and restaurants with the most magnificent view of table mountain. Loved seeing the seals.

The place to Be!. It was very touristy but lovely with super restaurants and lots of lovely shops.
Plenty of entertainment - a lovely atmosphere and it felt safe!

Excellent natural beauty. We had been to this place a number of times during our stay in Cape Town.
Wonderful place and at the same time great place for some shopping and good restaurants.
A MUST VISIT IN CAPE TOWN WITH YOUR FAMILY AND DURING SUN SETS.

Very nice place for an evening walk and dine. From our hotel only 5 minutes foot walk away, we spent nearly every evening in this nice area to have dinner or some drinks. Interesting people, international guests, nice shopping area and lots of nice restaurants.

Fun Stop. V&W waterfront is a great introduction to Cape Town. There are many interesting shops and restaurants. We especially like Baia restaurant right on the harbor. The African Trading Post has great items at reasonable prices. The waterfront itself is beautiful. The waterfront is what you make it. You can enjoy the serenity of the harbor or the energy of the shops and restaurants. Both are combined easily.
Variety of restaurants!. Liked the atmosphere, the view to the ocean and the beautiful seals! The foot bridge that gets hoisted for boats was also beutiful to watch!!

Vibrant. We strolled around the area for 2 nights - lots of eateries offering good food for average costs. Plenty of entertainment happening day and night. All the trendy shops are there for those with ample cash in their pockets. Loved the way the new integrates with the old.
Walkabout. Lots and lots to look at and looks of places to eat at.At times there is entertainment. Nice to just have a walkabout and sit around watching the rest of the world go by.

Great shopping and eating. This is a very nicely done outdoor commercial area with numerous shopping and eating venues right on the waterfront. We especially enjoyed the Watershed which houses some of the most spectacular native craft stores we have ever seen. I only wish they stayed open past 6 pm!!

Always a great place to visit!. This is a must for any visitor to C.T. Always lots to do, plenty of restaurant options and great shops if the weather is a bit wet or cold. Loved the marimba band and the singing groups. This time we took the canal boat cruise to the CTICC, great fun and very relaxing away from the hustle and bustle for an hour or so. I don't think anyone could get bored at the V&A Waterfront!

Something for Everyone. The Victoria & Alfred Waterfront is a great combination of shiny shopping centres to cater for all budgets and stunning scenery with Table Mountain behind and the harbour in front.Whether you want to just relax at a restaurant watching the world (and boats) go by or shop till you drop, you won't be disappointed. Although it's very touristy, on both days we visited last month, it wasn't heaving - though it's getting a bit more out of season.We did a bit of everything; shopping - something for all wallets from the usual chains to high end designer; eating in a restaurant overlooking the harbour; buying some gimmicky gifts; visited the Robben Island tourist centre and watched some street entertainers (excellent band!).Great place to while away a few hours and well worth a visit.

Vibrant and fun. I was expecting a generic tourist trap, but it was not like that. Interesting shops, great views, good food. You an watch craftsmen and women at work. Prices are high but the quality is good.

Location. The waterfront is a must for all to visit. A variety of things to do. Shopping, eating, viewing, experiencing. A starting point to travel to Robben island. Sitting on the quay looking at Table Mountain, enjoying a beer at den anker surveying the beautiful scenery
Excellent shopping centre, often quite busy. Wide variety of shops and entertainment, right next to the ocean. Close-by parking. Variety of restaurants.

Never a dull moment. There is so much to do at the Waterfront. The only downside is that it's always busy and is expensive to hellishly expensive. Otherwise you have the wheel of excellence, stunning restaurants, dolphins and boat rides, pirates and seals, wine and ampitheatre, cosmopolitan people and books, tea and tradition, movies and Robben Island trips, dragon boat racing and flied lice (fried rice), stalls and chocolates... we even have Pick n Pay!!! At a "larny" joint like this? Yup. Unpretentious and lavish... it's all there... you'll have a ball.

A good multiple activity in Cape Town. If you are travelling with a group, The Water Front Mall is a perfect place for all. Be it for shopping, for eating, our hanging out or even for a ride in the Giant Wheel (probably one of the largest).
Wow. Excellent shops and food places - even found a Post Office !!!seals in the waterways - old swing bridge - artifacts good.

Visit to Victoria&Alfred waterfront with husband and yorkies. I am an animal lover and are totally hooked on my 3 yorkies. As far as I can, I try to take them everywhere I can..For that purpose I have a doggy stroller where they are safely tucked in against any harm..I tried to cover them up with a baby blanket so that nobody can see I am not pushing a pram with a baby in, but yorkies..A shop owner then told me it was completely unneccary as they are welcome because they are in a stroller and out of the way...I really felt most welcome and thusfore will pay them a visit with my yorkies whenever I am in CT..This is the mall where you can feel the relax atmosphere with all the holiday makers strolling down the aisle..

Multiple shops, restaurants and views of the ocean.. The water front has two large malls with trendy and cool shops and also a huge indoor building where local artist sell their wares. A lot of restaurants indoors and outdoors are all around to choose.
New York in South Africa. The shopping centre is huge, fantastic designer shops, excellent restaurants and amazing views of the harbour and sea. An absolute delight

Interesting Harbourside. Many shops, handicrafts,restaurants and cafes. Probably not the cheapest place for souvenirs but a good range offered. We particularly liked the area where you could see artists working on their craft - with very good quality items for sale.Vibrant area both day and night - with the giant Ferris wheel lit up at night. Purchase and begin your hop on hopoff bus journey here - highly recommend this way to explore Cape Town.

Loads of things to do at the V&A Waterfront. Lots of shopping, touristy type place. Love the restaurants. Although service may lack in some restaurants for locals. It seems to cater for Tourists especially the prices. The shops have always been high ended, however they've introduced Mr Price recently and there's Pick n Pay.
V&A Waterfront. A fab place to spend time spending time with friend or just window shopping. Your can spend a pleasant just sipping a cup of coffee viewing the movements of the boats in the bay.

All-round entertainment for everyone. A good mix of museums, restaurants, boating activity (including cruises), movies and shopping. You must be very special if you get bored here! Easily reached by bus with lots of car parking. I found the variety of ships mooring here fascinating.
The way to go.. So much to see and do here and the restaurants are great.From here you can go to Robbin Island and all types of boat rides. If you have a kids birthday hire the Jolly Roger.

Fun and food for everyone. The V&A Waterfront is a must for locals and visitors to Cape Town. With restaurants and takeaways to cater for all tastes, along with a large shopping mall, craft market, excellent aquarium, boat trips and buskers, everyone will find plenty to do.
Stylish. Very stylish and geared for tourists. Good range of restaurants, excellent street entertainment and massive shopping malls.

Afican High Light. Fantastic place to shop , meet friends and family even to stay at one of the numerous hotels. By far the best place in South Africa and even Africa.A truly first world experience with the sea and back drop of the mountains.When the weather is bright and no wind then one can spend the entire day just people watching.
Amazing makeover. Old working dock (still working) made over into a haven for tourists and visitors. It actually works. Great restaurants. But the rest of the mall is huge and very boring.

EVERYTHING IN A MALL THAT YOU WANT IS THERE!. Best mall in all of South Africa. OUTSTANDING RESTAURANTS (I LOVED the GREEK FISHERMAN), great and lots of shopping. Easy to get to via cab or car and parking.
You even get the ferry to ROBBIB ISLAND NATIONAL PARK from one of it's piers.

Busy restaurant/bar area.. Very good choice of foods although you have to be carefull to select restaurants that cook correctly and do not use the 'boil in the bag' principle to supply a hot meal. Quite busy with several bars and shops.

Cute and Touristic. Great place to walk around, eat, buy, listen to some music, meet friends, feel the city, do groceries, go to a movie, have a pint, enjoy the aquarium....
You can spend the entire day there!

great place to spend time and walk around. excellent place to explore, the souvenir shed is well set out and the products are beautiful. There are plenty of food places for different budgets, from fast food to a la carte. Well worth a visit and you can get the ferry to Robben Island from there.

You won't be disappointed.. We spent a lot of time at the V&A Waterfront during our visit to Cape Town. There is so much to do and see. Plenty of shops if you want to shop, lots of restaurants if you need to eat, and also a great place to relax and watch the ships come in and out of the harbour. Its an absolute must see at night from The Wheel and the Food Market is a great place to have a bite or a great cup of coffee. The Watershed has the most amazing curios. If anything, just go for a stroll, you won't regret it!
Loved it. I visited a while back and i loved it. Great shops, great food, great boat trips and great experience. Would love to return one day

Tourist trap but nice atmosphere :-). shopping galore! Oh, and drinking/eating. A real tourist trap. But it is really nice to just take a stroll around the harbour and watch the people and ships come in and out. you don't HAVE to buy anything... ;-)

shopping. This is a fantastic Waterfront it is a shopping experience with so much unique and casual shops, restaurants, with boats trips and helicopter trips this was for me one of the best places to experience so much in one place.
Many dinners at the V&A Waterfront. Cape Town has a beautiful waterfront. Go check it out. Walk around, go shopping, eat - whatever it is just go.
Relaxing. Loved walking through all the shops and at night getting dinner and drinks at a venue outside with live music. A nice place for a stroll and some fun.

The heart of CapeTown. This is a great place to wander around a harbour front with great shops and restaurants but also watch the waterfront at work. Seals loll about in the harbour, beautiful yachts cruise in and out and there is a wonderful warehouse full of great African products and art. You also catch the ferry to Robbin Island here and that is not to be missed.

Great Place for everyone.. They have great shopping, great restaurants, and great things to do. we were there for 5 days and we spend 3.5 of them on the waterfront. most of the restaurants there are fabulous, there was one that we went to San Marcos that was horrible, worst service and worst food ever.but the V&A Waterfront was amazing

Jewel. Ok it was June 2009... but really feel the need to submit a review. This place was exceptional. Extremely comfortable and central. Fantastic food. Staff were so friendly and helpful. Fantastic memories!

A fabulous restruant sharing so many South African tastes!!. Ambiance just great. Music local and imaginative. Food out of this world. Service naturally great! Architecturally a winner - the architect being my cousin. This Restruant over looks the water and bird life of the Harbour and Robben Island in the distance. I liked this stop for a meal and will certainly return.

Tourist Shopping. A excellent tourist attraction for shops and restaurants. Nice atmosphere with secure underground parking. Make sure you go outside and cross the footbridge to the Clock Tower where there is an interesting museum of Robben Island where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned.

great mall!. ok it's not the like the kind of choice of clothes etc you have in LA but this place is a lovely mall with a great deal of natural light. the jewellery stores are good though seem a little overpriced for what they are offering. we ate lobster at the Belhazar restaurant which seems to be a decent steakhouse that also does seafood.
Relaxed location!. Nice combination of shops, excursion departures, food markets, harbour and restaurants in a pretty safe and relaxed atmosphere
"A must". See Cape Town in all it's glory, with a mixture of cultures walking the streets. But the beautiful people of Cape Town with their friendliness will bring the travelers back for more.

Tourist trap--but beautiful. This area is not surprisingly a new development--but is is still beautiful, safe, a little pricey, but very enjoyable. It is however a little too much like an upscale mall--literally for my taste. The restaurants offer lots of different fare and this is an ideal place to people watch...however you will just be looking at other tourists and business travelers. Still, it is beautiful, clean, safe and a fun spot. If your accommodations aren't here consider using über - as it works well and is much cheaper here than cabs.

A great place to be. The V & A Waterfront is the place to be in Cape Town at night. We were in Cape Town for 10 nights and spent every night here and a couple of days too. There is a vast range of restaurants and bars all at great prices if you are from the UK. The quality of the food is high. There is a huge stylish shopping mall in Victoria Wharf and in general a full range of shops from exclusive goods to African souvenirs. There is plenty to do in the day too from Two Oceans Aquarium to the boat trip to Robben Island plus a few historical sights. Most importantly it feels a very safe and relaxed place to spend your evenings.

A lot to see so take your time looking at the Docks and the Nelson Mandela Plaza.. The area has many cafes mostly in the large Shopping Mall. I would recommend just looking at the general area around the Docks before deciding what you would like to do. There are tours on offer but the one to Robben Island is a priority. ( You must book for this and check the sea swell on the day if your 'sea legs' are not good - it was reasonably priced for what one experienced).

The only place to stay. Location, location, location! This hotel couldn't be in a better place, centred in the heart of the Waterfront district surrounded by attractions like the wheel, craft beer pubs, shopping centre, restaurants, food markets, culture stores - you name it. If you are lucky you can even see dolphins swimming in the waters right in front of the hotel.But then there is the hotel itself - its charm, elegance and service makes you feel special. The rooms are spacious and well appointed with a special class you don't find anymore. There is even the chocolate on your bed covers as they are turned down for the night along with the TV guide open at that night with the remote, breakfast menu and laundry service. It is sometimes the little things that make an impression. The concierge and front desk staff are friendly, welcoming and incredibly helpful. Breakfast buffet is also awesome. The human side of the hotel, the staff are vital and everyone here goes out of their way to make you feel welcome. It is the only place I would stay in Cape Town.

I Don't LIke Shopping ......... As I say.... I don't like shopping as a rule but it was a pleasure to visit the shops and food outlets here at the V & A Waterfront in Cape Town. The staff in all the shops, cafe's and at the stalls were delightful and really helpful. There were lots of people around and yet it never felt crowded. Top marks.

Fantastic. A great way to spend several hours which we did on several occasions just wandering round the many shops including High St brands as well as local arts and crafts shops. At night there is a multitude of excellent restaurants to try.

The tourist hub of Capetown. Undoubtedly the most vibey place in Cape Town and probably South Africa, you can stroll through and browse the malls. Entry is free but parking is chargeable. The are some free activities like the kids playground. Most of the shops are national chains and well priced. Huge variety of restaurants. V&A houses a big wheel, aquarium and the Gateway to Robben Island tour, all separately paid for and quite pricey. A must do is to see the foot bridge near the Alfred Mall that opens and closes for boats and pedestrians - its free. Several top dollar hotels line the waterfront and if you staying in Greenpoint you can even walk there.

Good place to hang around in Cape Town. Created by connecting two wharves (Alfred and Victoria), the area is full of cozy restaurants, souvenir vendors and walking areas. Two malls open from the waterfront area with ample shopping opportunities.

Always worth a visit. The atmosphere in rain and sunshine is always lovely. There is something for everyone and this time the children joined in with the marimba band players which we so appreciated. It was a truly memorable experience.

Late afternoon visit. We visited the V&A Waterfront as our second stop for the day. Just walking there is exciting. Had late lunch at the Mitchell's Waterfront Brewery and loved it. The waterfront was a bit noisy but with so many people around you would expect it.

Something for everyone. Cape town is brilliant but this place is something else you can really enjoy the atmosphere. you can spend days here. There is a place for everything from jewellery to bookshop. The food is great. Although it is always busy so expect noise.

Where everybody has a good time!. Walking around at Waterfront is just great! Lots of entertainments around, free of charge. Dancers, singers, musicians or choirs gives you the real sound of Africa. Harbour view, smell, seals and sealions are amazing. Shopping, nice places to eat and The Table Mountain in the background are unforgettable. To watch it all from above, there is the Cape Wheel bringing you 40 metres up in the air, so you can see the Stadium and even Robben Island.waterfront is one of my favorites in CT, cause it is for everybody to enjoy.

V&A waterfront is everything you could wish for. This shopping centre is world class and is one of the best in Africa if not THE best. You are spoilt for choice and can do so much - high tea at the Table Bat hotel or Cape Grace, take a wonderful bus trip, walk around all the hundreds, or is that thousands of shops, and literally bump into people from almost every nation on earth! On some days its really crowded but thats just adds to the excitement I guess, unless you detest crowds, and in that case (stay home) ... Movies are great, restaurants and coffee shops are wonderful and the vibe is amazing.
all good. good events, live music, cosmopolitan enviroment, shopping cinema, very diverse dinning options. you can go cycling through, there is a huge aquarium to visit ans spend some 2-3 hours

Very average - Not great value for the price. We decided to break away for the long weekend and spend some time in Cape Town. When searching for hotels we came across the V&A Waterfront, it had very good reviews and because if it's location, we settled on booking it. My experience at the hotel in one word ... Underwhelming. The only thing going for it really, is it's location. You have easy access to the Waterfront with many restaurants and things to do, and hence you don't need to drive much.The rooms are clean, nothing spectacular to report there. The hotel itself is styled on a colonial theme, a theme which in my view, is outdated. The staff are efficient but not great. The food is okay. The decor is white and a dark grey which gives the hotel a drab atmosphere.Cape Town is such a beautiful place to visit and if you are considering it, there are many fantastic hotels to choose from,the V&A is not one of them....

Great place to wile away an afternoon. Such a buzzing, vibrant waterfront. So many great places to eat, or even just sit with a drink and watch the world go by. Trip to Cape Town wouldn't be complete without a visit.

Eating and shoppping heaven. Loads of fine restaurants, loads of shopping to be had!Combine this with street entertainers, seals playing in the harbour and a great atmosphere and you have a fabulous place to spend a few hours.

Food & shops!. If you like shopping & you like eating right by the waters edge you'll love this area. You can happily spend a good hour or so having a mooch round the shops & then deciding what you're wanting to eat.

Great spot to visit when you are in Cape Town. Very Busy water front with many stores and restaurants to choose from, not to mention the Some fantastic views.Make sure to pick up a guide and walk around the water front. There is a great history to see here.During the day the view of Table Mountain is great.There is a nice market to pick up souvenirs. Definitely a tourist visit.

Lovely. This was the last part of our tour, and it ended on a high.The water front is amazing. A bit upscale and high end shops, mostly quite expensive. But apart from that, the area is real fun. You can spend hours sitting and just watching the boats and people.Do not miss a cruise out to the open sea. The day we went, it seemed a bit rough and the boat was rolling a lot. The operators served us champagne on board. Loved it.Overall a must visit

Nice vibes . The overall visit to the V & A was super. The choices of food is extensive, shopping great , entertainment is fun. There is something for all ages happening all the time. With the aquarium or red bus tour nearby it's linked well. traffic becoming a problem to get in or out at some times.

More upscale!. Not really my cup of tea, but it is another fancy/upscale part of cape town. Very pretty down there with expensive shops and restaurants. There are also a lot of boats you can go out on tours on from there.

You can spend all day. The original waterfront was a great idea and still is a wonderful place to sit , walk , shop and eat. Part of its interest is that it is stll a working harbour with inshore and oceanic fishing vessels, the tug boat centre and slipways and repair docks as well as the marina. There are still masses of attractions, the aquarium and museums as well as the shops but irt has grown considerably since we were last here and while some innovations like the canal are good the number of large hotels, appartment blocks, and offices that are beginning to encircle the harbour are in danger of changing the ambience. It is great to be able to park your yacht outside your appartment on the canal but you relise that by doing so you are advertising that your yacht is rather small compared with those too large to gettthrough the canal dock!!

Good for a restful, wandering day. We're not much for shopping, but this place is a bit different. Unique vendor stalls, and an entire renovated industrial building filled with delicious food/snacks. Definitely worth the trip. We actually even went back for some more good food, but were sorry to see that some of the food attractions closed at 5PM. The bigger restaurants were all open much later, so we had a good meal oceanside. Seems there's always music, and if you like the standard shopping mall, they have that as well.
Just Fabulous. V&A is not only a beautiful building with loads of shopping and cafe options...its just fabulous.Victoria and Alfred lives up the regal name

Lovely. Yes the waterfront is touristy but it is also so lovely. My husband and I enjoyed strolling along, enjoying the sunshine, and stopping in on many of the cafes and restaurants for something to eat or drink. The shopping inside was excellent and the parking was very cheap.

Fun afternoon of wandering. The V & A Waterfront has a plethora of restaurants, shops, museums, & street entertainment. We easily spent 4 hours just wandering, eating, & enjoying the beauty of the waterfront. Not to be missed on your visit to Cape Town!

Lovely area to walk, shop, and dine. We stayed near the V&A waterfront in Cape Town and discovered that it was the perfect location for drinks, shopping, etc. There were plenty of bars, cafes and restaurants to choose from, as well as a large mall. The ferries to Robben Island also leave from the V&A waterfront. This is definitely a nice spot for a stroll if you’re in Cape Town.
Lots to do. You can shop, eat and drink till you drop.Good restaurants lovely sceneary and all the shops you can need in the docks.
V&A Waterfront. This place is clean, exciting and lively. Lots to see and do plus wonderful places to eat. Great outdoor entertainment and places to shop.

Fancy shopping in Cape Town. V&A waterfront is VERY nice...you'll see the richest people of Cape Town around here with nice cars parked everywhere. It is very pricey for SA and if you would like to do some shopping you would find at home it's great (ex Havaianas, Nespresso etc) but if you are looking for traditional South African shopping this is not the place
Everything in one place. Beautiful area down in the harbor (overlooking Table Mountain) with several great shopping malls and good restaurants/cafes. It was one of my favorite spots in Cape Town.

Shopping, dining and/or strolling... This is the place to be!. There is so much going on at the waterfront. You can spend an entire day at the waterfront because there is so much to do. I began the morning with a nice breakfast by the dock, followed by the Robben Island tour, and then a nice stroll around the waterfront. There was entertainment for those just hanging out; fabulous restaurants for those wanting to dine; and a huge mall for those looking to shop. I enjoyed a little shopping in the mall with plenty of designer stores although it is quite pricey compared to the suburban malls. However, the experience is worth it. Taxis are easily available outside the waterfront area or directly outside the mall.

Food market a place to visit. We have visited the waterfront many times and we have missed the Food Market always, yesterday we decided to give a try because we have to be in church at 3 pm and was a bit late for seating in a la carte restaurant. Very good decision, all of us with the differences in food preferences were cater for. On top after church I came back for a craft bear on the top floor bar and was very good. Very busy place but clean and easy to navigate.If you visit the waterfront don't miss the chance for a quick tour on this wonderful place
Great. Great mall and place to spend the day. Great restaurants and stores to do shopping. Worth a visit any day.

Very nice place to spend some time. Walking around the V&A is a must when visiting Cape Town. There are various dining options, a huge variety of shops, and beautiful views as well. The shopping includes craft markets, and Robben Island tours also depart from the Waterfront.

Nice place to walk and browse. There is lots to see and do down here, along this lovely waterfront. This is where the Robben Island boat leaves from...make sure you reserve well in advance as we missed out because they were booked a day ahead at least.There is lots of local shopping and designer mall shopping, street entertainment, and plenty of eating establishments. Also a ferris wheel.

Amazing view!!. A great 'tourist' must see for a day. There are plenty of restaurants and shops as well as small market stalls. I really enjoyed the upmarket craft markets nearby. The atmosphere is very fun with live music and performers in different sections. I felt safe whilst walking around the outdoor shops as well as through the connecting shopping centre. Catching a cab from the main cab rank is a little different- some cabs in Cape Town (and South Africa) are reliable and honest whilst others will try to rip you off by not putting the meter on or modifying the meter to run at twice the usual speed. The dodgy cabs are usually old run down cars without permanent cab signs. I recommend walking over to the Table Bay hotel and asking them to call you a cab- this way you will get a reliable and honest cab driver.

Good time pass in Cape Town with a wide variety of shops. V&A waterfront is a large area with a collection of upmarket mall, antiques as well as several shops selling unique items. Good place to spend an evening while in Cape Town.

What a great experience. What a place. A must for visitors to Cape Town. Any time of the day the place is fabulous.It is full of energy, vibrant and busy. Super location with views of Tablemountain from almost anywhere. Many restaurants, bars, with street entertainers and lots more beside.For those wishing to spoil the day there is a large shopping mall !

Watching seals. There is so much to do at the Waterfront: watching seals, eating in one of the many restaurants, take a boat trip, go to the movies, shop, the blue shed with all the arts & crafts - a beautiful setting with so much attractions.It is even in winter a good place to visit.

Pleasant evening with great but pricey shopping options. The place is nice for an ideal stroll in the evening. The setting is beautiful, the food is great, the shops will offer almost everything you would be looking for. Be sure to book your cab in advance for return journey (incase you are travelling by cab), as cabs waiting outside fleece tourists, so its a good idea to travel at a fixed rate and a safe option as well. Do try our the sea-food at the various joints.

Excellent for tourists. This is a great tourist attraction when visiting Cape Town. You will find a lot of restaurants, coffee shops and a great mall for shopping. From this area you can do helicopter rides, go on a yacht or visit Robben Island. It is close to Table mountain which mean you have great views of the mountain and see.

A most pleasant Sunday afternoon. Spent a most pleasant mid morning into sfternoon, firstly with a bit of shopping, extensive range of goog quality shops in all areas. Then a spot of breakfast, followed by the museum s, live music was at every corner, including the large staged area. A truly beautiful expetience, only down side everybody else had the same objective, but there are quiter area's, where you can catch your breath. Plus you have the stunning scenery, and the mixture of historical and modern architecture. Lovely day, and major attractions are close at hand.

Perfect setting. Wow, we could have remained in the Waterfront all week - it has so much to offer with numerous attractions and activities, bars, restaurants, shops, cultural events, etc etc. Yes, it is very popular with tourists - obviously - and relatively expensive, but you are paying for a great experience in magnificent surroundings - the sea on one side, Table Mountain on the other, excellent security, very clean and organised and a great buzz and huge variety all day and night. This is simply the epicentre of Cape Town and needs to be visited more than once.

Worth a visit.. No problem with eating here - plenty of restaurants with a variety of dishes available. Give yourself plenty of time - service is slow, tho' you can look out over the waters and relax! Enjoy!

Beautiful Views but Very Touristy. The first day we visited the waterfront there was a huge fire on signal hill and we were able to witness Cape Town’s fire department putting out the fire with helicopters. The water for the helicopters came from the waterfront. We were truly impressed by the skill of those firefighters. The V & A waterfront is definitely worth a visit if you are in Cape Town. It has beautiful views of Table Mountain, Lions Head, Signal Hill and the Harbor. I really enjoyed walking around the waterfront especially since the weather was gorgeous. But having been there once I don’t feel a need to return in the future. It is very touristy, busy and expensive. If we return to Cape Town we will try to seek out places that locals enjoy.

Stunning but pricey. The area around the Victoria and Alfred Waterfront is beautifully laid out with superb shopping malls, restaurants, visitor attractions and live music. It is however very expensive and in some shops rather overpriced. They are clearly targeting the tourists who is they travel to the southern suberbs or Kalk Bay ca buy a better range of items for far less.

Lots of shopping, lovely views. This is really the heart of Cape Town, surrounding the shops and the water are upper class residences and prime real estate. If you can't find a gift or something special here, you won't find it anywhere else. Highly recommended. Just be prepared for plenty of tourists.

All in one place!. It's an interesting place. There's a mall for shopping, lots of restaurants-from fast food to fine dining, nearby aquarium and museums, and cruises to choose from. There are playgrounds for kids too! I love the South African street performances. With the table mountain and the Atlantic Ocean as backgrounds too!

Day out for the whole family. The V&A Waterfront has so many elements to it that it has something for everyone. Scratch Patch for the younger one's, an aquarium for the whole family, shopping, cinema's, shopping, restaurant, etc. There are boat trips that you can take to Robben Island and helicopter trips around the peninsular.There are many international shops as well as local independents.

With Table Mountain as your backdrop.... Imagine enjoying a good meal with Table Mountain keeping a watchful eye on you? V & A Wharf is well designed offering something for just about anyone. Shops to keep the spenders (& store owners) happy, live free entertainment to make your soul sing, restaurants with the mountain as your backdrop, marina to lure you out for an outing, or even book your aerial tour of one of the most beautiful places on earth.This place just about has it all. They've done a great job in turning a wharf for mariners into a place most would enjoy.

The most touristic place in SA.... If you fancy loads of bad dressed tourists, bachelor parties, MacDonalds and a Zara store overcrowding the hard workibg people trying to get clients in theor boat tours: this is the place. Unlike the true South African sights and interesting highlights of this beautiful country, this is more like the Spanish tourist places or the tourist market in Marrakesh, Marroco. So, nice to spend an afternoon but if you really want to see and experience South Africa: go elsewhere. No wifi, just fake souvenirs, and cheap tourists. We moved to Port Elizabeth and places like Grahamstown and Mosselbaai to see the real SA...

If you are a tourist.... Definately worth a visit if you are tourist. Love the street performers and the vibe. Lots to see. Stop at one of the restaurants and enjoy the spectacular views of Cape Town and the harbour. You will definately also spot a seal or two. Only shop if you are paying in foreign currency.

Views say it all. By sharing with friends the Restaurants have best food and quality and value for money with a view...seals watching..TRuly beautiful mother city with lots of sun...the SOUVENEIR shops are a must...bead work amazing talent...FRIENDLY STAFF...FRIENDLY PEOPLE...A Visit to a BEERHOUSE for tasting don't miss out....lots of outlets shops too.

the absolute "go too" for leisue, food, drinks and shopping. The Waterfront is and entertainment area located at an old shipyard. dozens of bars, restaurants and shops are located around a Ferrus-wheel which gives you a spectacular view over Cape town.

Wonderful place, but wait for your change. We have visited South Africa more than 20 times over the past 20 years, owned a property there for 10 years and have travelled around a fair bit of the country with no trouble; well, if we didn't feel safe then we wouldn't have kept returning.We still feel safe but one thing we noticed this year - and it doesn't apply only to the Waterfront as it happened in other places too: when paying a bar/restaurant bill by cash some places "forget" to bring your change. Most times this can easily be sorted but at the Victoria and Alfred Hotel we had ordered drinks on the outside terrace, paid the bill with cash and waited for the change in order to leave a good but relevant tip. And waited... then asked for change and told "the waiter has gone for change now".... and waited again. Another of our party went up and was told "the waiter has gone for change", at which point he demanded our change immediately, and was given it by another waiter. Needless to say we did not leave any tip!
waterfront. So much to see and do.enjoyed a nice half hour boat trip for R50 a person.big wheel is also nice.bread shop a must

This is a must on your trip.. What a stunning place. Get there early in the morning and spend the day. Fabulous food, amazing gifts, super things to see. Every one was friendly and the artisan area was just amazing. Enjoy the wonderful food on offer in the food court, soak up all the fun of a fair. No wonder the residents come here as well as the tourist. Treat yourself a day here as a minimum.

Great shopping!!!. The V&A Waterfront is a must for any visitor to Cape Town.It has a huge amount of shops and many designer ones too.The choice of coffee shops and Restaurants is great too.It is always very busy with lots of African traditional shops too with many gift shops so no problem with gifts to take home.Boat trips can be taken from the quayside or a helicopter ride if you fancy!!!Allow yourself plenty of time to do and see everything and to soak up the atmosphere with Table Mountain in the near distance.

Great Destination!. Often viewed as merely a shopping and eating destination, I think that the best part of the V&A is its past.Home to 22 landmarks the history of this still working harbour can be traced back to 1652 when it was established as a refreshment station for the Dutch East India Company. You can take a guided historical tour for which you must book.Alternatively do the self-guided walking tour. This starts and ends at the Information Centre as they have a free map from which you follow a series of numbered boards with all the information. However on this visit they had run out of the maps which was a shame.You can easily spend a whole day here but do some research first on where to eat as there are a lot of eateries at different price points.
Do not miss it!. Kind of touristy, but I would not miss it! Wonderful restaurants, great views, shops, etc. The bars at the waterfront are a lot of fun, especially at night with the live music!

Best place to chill - go for meals - always vibrant. Generally a wonderful place to spend spare time constructively - lots to see, do and absorb be it shop, learn or look/absorb - activities galore from action to relax, Working harbor. Vibrant with many cultural /sporting programs and activities planned over the year.
Very busy/children friendly/but can get crowded - very safe. (don't be careless though).
I visit it often

Essential to visit. One of the most popular spots in Cape Town so a visit is a must. It is nice to see what ships are in harbour but essentially it is an upmarket shopping mall with all the brands covered. There are a variety of lovely restaurants to choose from for a meal overlooking the harbour and other attractions, like the wheel, clock tower, sheds selling local handicraft, and aquarium. There is always some activity happening and quite lively, especially on a weekend but be prepared for heavy crowds. Enjoyable day out.

Harbour junction. An excellent venue to while away your day! Aquarium visit was truly wonderful & especially if you arrive at feeding time. The Warehouse is jam packed with fantastic arts & crafts - talent abounds! There is of course the shopping mall for those who want to shop until they drop! Many fabulous restaurants to visit - our choice at lunch was the Food Market where there is a choice of Sushi, Thai, Italian and Indian dishes and all this while listening to live music.

Great views, lots to see and good shops. Enjoyable place to visit, with some great scenery and views of the harbour. Embarkation point for Robin Island but plenty to see and do before or afterwards. Well worth a visit and plenty of interesting shops also.

Touristy, bustling fun for all ages. Whilst it can be unpleasant from a traffic and parking perspective, especially during the holiday season, the V&A is always worth a visit: For shopping, entertainment, big wheel, boat rides, restaurants, even helicopter rides. The Aquarium is great for children, and the vast selection of curios a must for all travelers and locals alike.

V & A Waterfront Fam day. We had an awesome Family day at the V&A Waterfront. Security beefed up, Toilet facilities intact & the entertainment was pleasing. Good spread of variety for every family member each with their own taste.

Welcoming Waterfront. We took family to the Waterfront and everything was great. The shops were having sales and boy there were bargains galore. The only gripe we had was our visit to the Red Shed Craft Market. At almost every stall the Assistant sat with her cell phone, at times oblivious to our need for attention. I think this should be addressed. The large array of restaurants to choose from makes us wish we could spend more time there so as to try them all!

A GENERAL VIEW ABOUT CAPE TOWN!. Well, this is not a specific review about the V&A waterfront, This is a review about my interpretation of that place. Please enjoy it. First of all, if you are one of those who has a “movie idea of South Africa, let me invite you to open your mind wide and let me impress you with a reality that goes further than Safaris, hiding the amazing Amazing Rainbow Nation.Rainbow land is the name that Nelson Mandela gave to South Africa after his release of 27 years from prison in Robben island. In Mandela’s interpretation the name “Rainbow Nation” remained a place with people of all races, therefore of different colors, who live in peace building the most beautiful view for all the eyes around and that is the perfect description to CAPE TOWN.However, in my opinion, to call a country “THE RAINBOW NATION” leverages unbelievable characteristics that make it such a magical place as Cape Town is.THE RAINBOW NATION... BY ITS BEAUTIFUL WOMENI am a latin-american woman, who was rased with the american and european concept of beauty. I did all the chemical hair processes available to transform my hair from almost curly (I would like to say that my hair was curly enough to have an afro, but that would be a lie) to straight. But the capetonian women are proud, at least now, of their physical features. They use their hair in the original texture, with high volume and all kind of colors in their highlights; they emphasize it even more using colorful hair craft. So, my peace of advise is…If you are single and are ready to go to south Africa be prepared to be overshadowed (In case of being a woman), or Enchanted (in case of being a man) for these goddesses with black skin but hair in all the rainbow colorsTHE RAINBOW NATION…BY ITS FOODOk, here is a personal revelation. I am not too much into the food. For me the company around the food or how trendy or lovely is the place/restaurant where I eat is the more important.For that reason this is the topic less relevant in this rewiev, nonetheless as a sign of my good intention, to give a complete recap of my South Africa’s trip, I will write five brief tips… 1)English Breakfast is available in all the Hotel Buffets. 2) Indian cuisine is the best in relation to cost and quality 3) If you are a meat lover, you need to taste Alligator meat. 4) The average wine’s price of a world class bottle of wine is less than 20 american dollar 5) Biltong a variety of dried, cured meat is the most iconic African food souvenir THE REAINBOW NATION…BT ITS HISTORYSaving the best for last… If you are a nerd such as me, you will love South Africa. Unlike Europe where everything and everyplace is well known in South Africa you are continually surprised with new information each minute. IMPORTANT WARNING: I am from Colombia and the basic worldwide historical information that we receive at school is focused in USA and Europe.Some of the most interesting insights that I learned during my trip were:1) Cape Town is one of the most multicultural cities in the world, about 3.5-million people live there.2) The world’s first heart transplant was performed by Dr Christiaan Barnard in Cape Town in 1967.3) The city’s motto is “Spes Bona”, which is Latin for “good hope”, a relevant motto for WSPID 2013.4) Cape Town is sometimes called the “Tavern of the seas".
