There is a huge shopping mall with great variety in terms of retail therapy, large supermarkets, multiple pubs, a plethora of restaurants and eateries covering many cuisines and budgets, a large cinema and many other options.There are also various attractions housed within the Waterfront (eg. Aquarium, a market, harbour), as well as a launching point for various boat trips (eg. Robben Island). It's close to the City Centre, and has multiple large car parks, as well as various bus services.It's pretty hard not to find something that you'd be interested in. The only drawback I can find is crowds, but I guess that comes with anything / any place that has a lot to offer.

Unmissable. This is at the heart of Cape Town's tourism scene. With ample boutique stores, luxury restaurants, trendy cafes, curios and more, V&A is a bustling hive of activity, day & night. We strolled along its chic quays, dabbled in shopping and stopped over for a delicious coffee in the sunshine. It's a must-do if you're in Cape Town. Enough said :)

South African Culture. A waterfront that is constantly animated, it's like watching a 24 hour show!But, let me pay tribute to a really exceptional tourist guide called Omary Abibu. I have never met a man with such a great culture! And with a sense of humour that would drive you off your seat!Thanks a lot Omary. You deserve a medal!I wish my Mauritian Waterfront be the same! but we have a lot, really a lot more to go!

Well worth a visit. This beautiful waterfront has something for everybody. There is lots of shops that you can spend hours visiting, both in the mall and around the waterfront, as well as lots of cafés, bars and restaurants. Both during the day and at night it is always busy giving a great atmosphere. Definitely worth a visit!

Victoria and Alfred Waterfront. Lots to see and do and dine out , its a sprawling place and you need to spend at least a day to go right through if you want to see it all , dining was a bit pricy but worth it at some places as the food was very good , you can book almost any tour you want from Whale watching to Shark cage diving ,fishing and so on its endless

Great Place to visit if you can find parking. Diverse and scenic, wide range of consumer goods available for purchase and wide range of eating establishments. Very poorly marked signage for visitor parking unless you already know where you are going.

Fun place to shop, eat or just people watch. Had a great time here on our last morning in Cape Town. Did some last minute shopping, enjoyed watching Bokkie, the mascot for the Springbok Rugby team working the crowd. Took a ride on the Giant Ferris Wheel and enjoyed final views of this beautiful city.

Shops, restaurants and artists, beware taxi scam. If you only take the mall, it is just a mall as there are millions all over this world nowadays. Only a couple of really interesting shops (do not miss the food section at Woolworths if you are a foodie) and a lot of chain shops though the book shop never failed us. But there is more to this place. Ignore all the people who want to sell all kind of tours but enjoy the water, have a nice rose somewhere in a streeet restaurant overlooking the harbour and/or the table mountain, listen to the artists that are there (especially on weekends) and have look at the clock tower. If you do miss some clothes, or want to buy some souvenirs, this is it as well.Of course it is touristy but what else would one expect.Also have a close look if you can see any seals in the harbour if they are there they can get very playful.An importatnt thing though: There are lots of taxis waiting at the exit and a good deal of them are not real taxi drivers. Many have no idea where your destination is and they will try to overcharge you. Anything up to the Kensington is max 60 rand, do not pay more.

Overwhelming. This place is big - really big. I had hoped for more of a local flavour but in fact it is a mall. But we did find some local South African shops that were lovely. The restaurant selection is also outstanding.

A must in Cape Town. A visit to the V&A is a must for everyone who is visiting Cape Town. There is so much to see and do. Various eateries and choice for every pocket. Shops and entertainment all around for all ages any time of day. Great cinemaDon't miss it

Great destination. Spent 3 nights at the amazingly opulent Table Bay Hotel, right on the V & A Waterfront. Fantastic view of Table Mountain, lots of great restaurants, shops and live music. Of course it's "touristy" but it's a great holiday atmosphere - and it is also a working port. You can also get the open top, hop on/hop off bus tour from here, which takes you all around the city with a very good commentary. Our stay here was part of a tour, which we booked through Bales Tours but organised locally by Thompsons, a S. African company. Our driver/guide for the week, Alex, was brilliant. Also stayed in Oudtshoorn, Knysna and Hermanus. Breathtaking scenery, beautiful weather, great food and wine ... would love to go back!
Great restaurants well worth a visit. A great array of restaurants and bars, beautiful at night and lots of places for a shopaholic. A must visit.

Nice for tourists. There are a lot of shops and restaurants at the Waterfront. It's evidently made for tourists so it feels a bit "fake". However, it's a lovely environment where you can find most things you might need. Not much higher prices compared to other shops, restaurants and cafés in Cape Town.
Very nice. The Waterfront is a very nice place to go out for dinner or do some shopping. The views of the harbor are great to see at night time when it is lit up.
visit the "made in south africa" store. good restaurants and the have currency exchanges- the "red shed" area has tons of local stuff-be sure to get the facility map so you don't get turned around.

Lovely!. The V&A waterfront is a lovely location. We actually went to watch live music and fireworks on New Years eve. Was great,.,,though it was crowded, lots of people had to stand...few places to sit (the crowd was huge anyways),
The view is lovely, great place to visit

Something for Everybody. We arrive in Cape Town after a hectic number of weeks touring and were staying in the Waterfront Apartments.Whether you want food, shopping, night life, craft markets or even a visit to the Aquarium all is on hand - hence my title something for everybody. You can even reach the shopping arcade which has all the usual names and loads more specialist shops.One great things it is very safe to walk around and they have security guards erywhere and even at night you feel safe.You can find all types of restaurants from fancy expensive ones to a range of modestly priced fast food outlets.The food market is a must visit and we stopped by for our breakfasts and lunches a number of times. Inside you can find all types of food.Next door is a craft market where you can pick up some great souvenirs and other stuff.In the evenings great clubbing and music abounds in many places.If a bus tour of the area is what you want then these can be picked up next to the aquarium.

V and A nice place for a sun downer and a meal woth the trip. the V and A is a treat nice shops a bit pricy? Great views of the harbor and a wide selection of restaurants on the Quay a must see stop in Cape town

relax and enjoy. A dowdy water front was beautifully restored with a good selection of restaurants and shops. We strolled around and enjoyed the street entertainment. Although we were on a tight schedule we were pleased that we got to enjoy the relaxed atmosphere for the couple of hours that time permitted

Very Touristy. Very touristy with prices to match. Plenty of souvinear shops and restaurants, pubs. Boats leave from here for Robbin Island, whale watching etc. Also the aquaruim is nearby and a large mall full of contempory shops.

Large shopping area. This area is very spread out with lots of parking and restaurants with hotels. Their is also a dock here to go on a tour to Robben Island which I highly recommend doing. There is a lot of shops just like any other type of mall, but also included are local shops, and a memorial to Mandela. As you get closer, the traffic gets worse especially in the middle of the day. Give yourself plenty of time.

Just Relax. If you don't spend at least a day in or around the V & A whilst in Cape Town, then their is something wrong with you. A great place to just sit down & people watch. Great selection of Restaurants to chose from that caters for every budget. If you want to shop, the Malls are great. Street entertainment is around every corner, so just take your time, chill & relax.

Great way to spend half a day. The V&A is a very nice place to eat some food, walk around and shop a bit.The atmosphere is very relaxed and very child friendly (watch out for the water though).There is a very nice kids play area next to the shopping mall.Absolutely worth to spend half a day.

V & A Waterfront. Quite a sizeable place to walk around. Lots of shops, restaurants, ferry to Robben Island, but be warned book early on line and bring tickets with you. Catch glimpses of the seals in the water. Lots of boat activity in and out of the water as there are dry docks here too. Two Oceans Aquarium is a short walk from here. Food market for food lovers and a craft market for amazing and unusual gifts to take home. Generally lots to do and see, a very sociable place.Visited several times during our stay in Cape Town

A great place in a wonderful setting. The V & A waterfront complex is a great place for relaxation and shopping, with lots of attractions for the children. Set below Table Mountain, it's a lovely place to sit and relax. There are plenty of good restaurants and quality shops.
We spent Christmas in South Africa. :)

Crowded, touristy. The only reason to go to this area is to catch the ferry to Robben Island. All the shops and restaurants were crammed with tourists. Food was overpriced and there weren't any cultural attractions. It's like a crowded mall in your hometown.

Peacefull. Every Trip to Cape Town we make several Trip to the V&A Waterfront a World Class Harbor Very Clean Safe and Lots to Do.From Several Great Resturants to Street Performers to the Many Shops to Purchase African Artifacts.Something here to do for the Entire Family.We also spent New Year Eve here felt Very Safe and the Vibe was Awsome.
the heart of Cape Town. So much to see and do....Springbok experience, boat cruises, fabulous shops, great restaurants, so many photo opportunities, good views of Table Mountain.

Bread and Circuses?. It's easy to see the attraction of this massive mix of retail, entertainment, food and bev and a working dock, all under a stunning Cape Town sun. It's very well executed and there really is something for everyone except those hankering for the real South Africa, whatever that is. In a way it's a pity that the investment put into this has not been matched at other, perhaps more evocative attractions, such as the District Six museum - but for what people visit Cape Town for, it's perfectly matched.

Just keeps getting better!. Always spend time here whenever I visit Cape Town and it really has improved over the years, There is now a good choice of shops, both local and international. The restaurant choice has also improved, offering everything from fast-food to some really great restaurants. The location is stunning and there is a wide choice of excursions on offer. Just remember this is a tourist attraction and this can be reflected in some, not all, of the prices.

Pretty Setting, good food, but mostly a harborside mall. Views and food are great, but it is mostly the same shops and souvenir stands you can find in any world destination. Clearly THE destination for the world party youth set. However it is clean, parking is easy and you will get a good meal while looking a a spectacular harbor

Terrific Range of Shops & Cheap Prices. The Victoria & Alfred Waterfront is a hugely popular sight in Cape Town that offers a dense range of shops, restaurants and views. The restaurants range from fast food to proper restaurants and there is a plethora of shops. The best thing about it is the late and early hours of trading. Even on christmas eve it was open until 9pm. Well made attraction with vast range of shops.

Shopping, eating, sightseeing all in one. It may be an artificial development but it's a good one. The Wharf shopping centre is to a high standard. Plenty of other specialist shops. The quays have interesting historic features, the views of Table Mountain are great. You can just get a coffee and watch the world go by. Outside the V and A hotel there is a spot where there is musical entertainment. We sat over luch listening to a 4 man New Orleans style jazz band and it was just wonderful.
Well worth a visit!. This area is probably the hub of touristy action, but it is really well done. Lovely restaurants & bars, interesting shops & a great place to spend a couple of hours.

Modern waterfront. Lots of shops and modern hotels, there is a canal system running around part of it. We saw a display of African dancing on a big stage. Nice place for a browse about. Lots of restaurants.

Expensive tourist attraction .... not to be missed when in Cape Town. Cape Town one of the most beautiful cities in the world has an attraction that is not to be missed.Situated just south of the downtown city area the waterfront is a tourists delight.From world class shopping to basic to upmarket restaurants the waterfront area offers something for everyone. It is a bit pricy for locals but it is a dream destination for all visitors to this fine city.

The place to be. Some people may find it a bit too "touristy" but the waterfront has everything you could need and is a vibrant and interesting part of the city. Whether you're looking for shopping, entertainment, a good place to eat or just a place to hang out and people watch, then the waterfront is the place. Security and safety is excellent, and even late at night you can wander around in a relaxed manner that you simply couldn't do in some other areas of cape town. Having stayed at the waterfront village the area had everything I needed within easy distance for a relaxing holiday.

Nice indoor/outdoor Mall on the Harbor. I really enjoyed hanging out at the Victoria and Alfred waterfront. The best part, I think, was the restaurant area. If you go to the back of the area and sit outside you have a wonderful view of Table Mountain at sunset. (From the portuguese Tapas restaurant it was perfect!) There are usually performers out and about on the weekends. You can organize cruises of the harbor here, and at the Clock Tower you can get tickets to go to Robben Island, an absolute must.

A day out. We spent a complete day leisurely walking round this area, full of eateries shops, malls and craft shops, there is always something going on from musical groups, free entertainment in the amphitheater and the big wheel a great day out

The V and A. Plenty of expensive shops to look at... lots of people to watch but a great day out especially with a meal thrown into the mix. A cheap taxi ride from downtown unless you feel like a 20 min stroll.

Perfect saturday!. Busy, vibrant, salty smell of the ocean, music... just little bit of whats waiting for you there on one nice Cape Town day.People are happily browsing arround, lots of food, drinks, laughter and fun. Youll find many nice restaurants, shops and attractions that are offered to you as you walk. Nice ethnic music mixed with popular songs and styles will chear you up as chaps are really spreading good vibrations. You also have really nice view of the Table Mountain.If you want to buy nice souvenir from South Africa visit African Trading Port shop on Waterfront, youll find something there. Selection is fantasitc and most of the things are hand made localy. Close by you can also find very nice Aquarium thats really worth seeing.Every time i visit Cape Town this is where i spend at least one saturday. I love it!

Lovely, friendly, entertaining. Many waterfront attractions tend to be seedy and unattractive, and sometimes unsafe. Not so here. It's a charming mix of maritime industry, posh hotels, upscale shops, and even a bit of schlock. It's a great place to stretch your legs after a long flight, enjoy the sunshine, have a glass of wine and people watch. Everyone is incredibly friendly, and the prices are so reasonable that one feels guilty.

There is a total different side to the V&A. Two days ago I was once again in the V&A Waterfront and I didn't really feel like shopping and had to do a bit of catch-up with my daily fitness walk as we have been mainly in shopping centers and different restaurants. My "exercise" started at the Breakwater Parking Lot (4 hours @ R 10,00 = 1 USD) it is a little off the centre but the new waterfront parking is now connected to this cheap section and you have a nice walk under cover into the shopping soul. Here find your way out and explore the new restaurants on the top floor via long stairs, up and down. There are lifts and elevators but not for fitness. Find the new shops and buildings on the other side, walk along piers and watch the seals, fisherman boats, yacht and tourist sailers. Use the stairs and find out all attractions and speciality shops of the entire centre. I spend almost for hours "on the run", have probably done about 5 km and hundreds of stairs, enjoyed the most amazing views over the V&A and Table Mountain with Cape Town's Skyline in between. Today I feel the tour in my muscles and joints, but instead of spending money I had a glorious "walk-out"! We relaxed afterwards in the best fish and sushi place of Cape Town: Willoughby's, rounding off a worthwhile excursion.

Great place to visit. I would totally recommend this place. Yes it is touristy, but no more that most waterfronts around the world. I live by the waterfront in the UK, and most of these places have been given over to tourists. I loved the shops, the singing, the crafts and in the blue shed is Township Guitars where I bought my son an oil can guitar. The owner was there and jammed with him, it was wonderful. We stayed in the Victoria and Alfred hotel on the waterfront so it was perfect for us. it was totally safe, the first night I went out on my own as my son slept for 18 hours!! I felt totally safe and soaked up the atmosphere, great place to stay and visit.

Touristy but good.. Yes it’s very touristy but I liked its lack of any particular plan. Streets seem to go in all directions and there is a lot of choice with what you might like. There is good food to be had in the Foodmarket, good beer in Mitchell’s Pub, lots of history if you catch a boat to Robben Island, plus the many restored buildings. Very busy in the evenings but walking home back through the city to the top of Long Road is quite dodgy after dark. Worth a visit.

A lively must visit place for us. This is a place that drew us back over 5000 miles for another visit. It is a lively area full of shops, restaurants, street performers and much more. Backed by Table Mountain with Robbens Island sat a few miles offshore it is historical and is really the heart of tourist Cape Town.

Must see top 3 wonders for Cape Town. Diversity is the name of the game. If its entertainment, restaurants and shopping you are looking for then you have found the spot in Cape Town. One can easily spend an entire day at the Waterfront. Every outlet or venue is exceptional in its own way and when Cape has a beautiful day its the best place to be. You have a wide range of selection on anything both service and quality is one of the highest I have experienced in the World.
Just a mall. Very nice decorated. Secure. Well done facilities. But it's just a shopping center. Lots of shops that can be found on a globalised market. Nothing touristically intetesting.

Victoria & Albert Waterfront - Excellent Restaurants and Shopping. We recently stayed at Cape Grace Hotel on V&A Waterfront and approximately 400 yards walk to shops and variety of excellent restaurants on the waterfront. It has a Mediterranean feel about it. The atmosphere is very relaxed and variety of cuisine is on offer in numerous restaurants and public houses. We tried Thai, Indian and fish restaurants and all were excellent and not too expensive. Local beers and South African wines are very good. Couple of restaurants had live bands and that added extra ambiance of the placeWe had anxiety of walking after dark but we were reassured by the presence of private security officers who patrolled the complex and let their presence known. V&A Waterfront well exceeded our expectations

A working harbour and more than just a mall. I don't know what some of the other critical visitors were expecting but the V and A Waterfront was just what I was expecting. We went several times as our apartment was close by and we didn't even go into a shop once. You visit the Aquarium and The Robben Island Museum and ferry point from there. The food market/hall is fantasmagorical - if you don't try The Fish Box at least 3 times like we did you are missing a culinary treat and bargain. There are so many choices inside that building it will make you salivate. There are dry docks with boats being worked on, there are pleasure boats and helicopter trips you can take if you are feeling brave. There is history all around and there is fun to be had. We ate one early evening at The Harbour House and whilst it wasn't the best meal we ate on our holiday - it was very good and the outside setting was marvellous and the price for 2 large gin and tonics, one mussel starter, one king prawn main one fillet steak main and one lovely bottle of sauvignon blanc was the princely sum of £45. To sum up it is a lively and integral part of Cape Town and shouldn't be missed. Also just a 10 minute walk in the direction of the stadiium but hugging the coast is The Grand Cafe which is great for a chilled out lunch in a posh beach setting. The prices are a little higher but you don't mind for a lovely setting like this.

It's a mall.... I'll say, if you're looking for a lot of food selections in one place, you should go here. It might be over priced though. I don't know. We didn't stay long. When we realized that it was essentially a mall along the water we left. There were a lot of souvenir shops between other stores you would find in a normal mall. There are a few street performers as well, so that's entertaining for a bit. The "crafts" section is a bunch of booths that sell things you find pretty much everywhere else along the roads in the area except it's three times the cost.If you're looking for souvenirs at a good price, there's a street market at Boulders Beach and an even better one at the entrance of the Cape of Good Hope Park. Bring cash though.

Nothing special. The shops were mostly low end, terrible "mall" shops. However there was one store not in the main building, sorta attached to a hotel that sold "cool", unique items made by local young artists.The top floor of the main building is where the high end stores were but they are small and it isn't like visiting the same shops in large international cities. We ate at Bukhara which I would say was OK but not great compared to NY or London Indian food.Parking was a bit of a pain but manageable. You can end up walking around and then realize you parked all the way on the other side which can take time getting to. Of course be smart and memorize where you parked. And for some reason, of the 5-6 times we parked, only once did the parking ticket actually work.There is also a spot to view sea lions there.

Chilled out atmosphere. Great place to hang out with friends, family, spouse. This place has a very relaxed ambiance & has some great eateries. You can get really cool Big Five Mementos from shops here

great for everything!. When you feel like relaxing a little, go to the waterfront, it is beautiful, find yourself a nice place to sit, or a restaurant, and watch the boats coming and going. If you feel like shopping there is plenty to choose from, from high end shops, to a lovely little market. There is plenty of food to choose from, from very high end dining, to casual pubs, the usual fast food, and an amazing food market. A large number of the "things to do" in cape town start at the waterfront, including the "hop on/off" red bus, the aquarium, boat trips, the diamond museum, the "big wheel", and a great deal of different stalls where you can arrange shark cage diving, or helicopter trips ect. Just be aware that everything costs money, and the parking is very expensive.

Easy Transition for North Americans/Westerners to South Africa. Wonderful diversity of things to do from boat rides, high priced diamond shopping, wonderful array of restaurants from Hagan Daz to Chinese to luxe seafood restaurants. Nearby there is craft market to buy your souvenirs and get your hair braided. Its a great place to spend a relaxing day. I especially enjoyed the record shop.

Nice area!. I liked the V&A, as far as the harbour, the food market, the craft market, etc. The mall was just another packed, high priced mall... I was happy to see seals in the harbor and was shocked to see BOX JELLYFISH floating around also! It was picturesque to visit the V&A and I did enjoy it.

Lovely place to visit! Lots of restaurants and shops!. We took a trip to the V & A Waterfront during our trip in Cape Town. Its a very nice area with lots of shopping malls, restaurants and bars! It's a nice place to go and enjoy some nice food. They have a lot of places with outdoor seating which is perfect when the sun is shining. I would suggest finding a good taxi company to use on your trip when in Cape Town as a lot of the ones that park in the Waterfront taxi rank are an absolute rip off. We used Excite and they run on a taxi metre and its very reasonable. One day we nearly took our chances with one of the parked taxis and he wanted to take double. Don't be fooled and get a decent company to use whilst staying in Cape Town!

A must for Cape Town visitors. Visit to Cape Town would be incomplete without a trip to V&A Waterfront. Located on the edge of water, the whole area is beautiful and caters to most tastes of visitors and locals. It has great recreation (boat rides, helicopter rides, kids play area, sailing), lots of restaurants, food court (very nice) and a plethora of shops, big brands and not so big brands as well. If one is looking to spend 4-5 hours during a weekend day on a business trip, this would be a perfect place!! I have visited many times and still it is very attractive to go spend a few hours and dollars as well :-)

Touristy area. Get your souvenirs at the various shops at the V&A Waterfront. The prices do vary a bit for the same type of merchandise so be sure to shop around. Also, there are a lot of places in this area to get a bite to eat. One of my favorite places was at the Market on the Wharf. They are not open 7 days a week so be sure to check out their hours. Lots of food vendors at this Market serving various types of food. Overall, this area has a lot to offer and is definitely great for tourist. The Two Oceans Aquarium and the tours for Robben Island are located at the V&A.
Fun day sunday. Good mix of street theatre eateries and shops to entertain the whole family lovely atmosphere where the general feeling was relaxed and happy

Fantastic experience. Great place to visit. Loads of really good eating and drinking options - and very safe (it was our first trip and we were nervous!).very friendly. Relaxed. Recommend virtually any of the restaurants. You can live like a king here for not much money. Climate very good, staff friendly, security good

Great Experience. Cape Town is a fabulous place to experience and during our stay in Cape Town we visited here several times. Along the wharf there are many delicious restaurants serving all different cuisines from Fresh Sea Food to Tapas, to there is also some fine dining spots for those that wish are more upscale dining experience.The shopping is great you will find all major brand and retailers well represented along with some not so well known treasures. While walking around you can find several boat cruises and shark diving packages, helicopter rides, and essentially anything else you might be interested in. Visit the Two Oceans Aquarium or take a ride on the giant Ferris Wheel and enjoy great views over the city.The shopping is bit more expensive then in the shops in town but the experience and convenience more than makes up for it.

"Touristy". You feel like you are in US... not so nice... many people try to sell you tours... like everywhere else in big cities... the craftmarket seems more like part of a mall... not so tipycal...
A little San Francisco. Beautiful and safe place , even at night . The restaurant are good and nor to expensive.During high season do advance booking.nice shopping center also

We enjoyed the V&A Waterfront. We stayed at the Table Bay Hotel on the Waterfront and we enjoyed being at that location. The V&A waterfront has a nice walking path along the water; it's attractive; there are many restaurants and lots of shopping. It is also where the ferry to Robben Island is. It's probably the prominent location in Cape Town.We had burgers and beers at Ferryman's Restaurant (a pub), and they had a great band there that afternoon. A beautiful, sunny day with good food, drink and music - what else can you ask for? Note: the waitstaff was fun and friendly - Ferryman's is worth a visit.
Good shopping. Lots of good shopping - upscale boutiques with unusual choices in the mall and a good selection of crafts in the Arts & Crafts hall.

Typical Waterfront Tourist area, nice if that is your interest. Shops and restaurants are the key reason to visit. Nothing unusual about the waterfront and certainly not that pretty from a geographical perspective. But if you are into shopping and restaurants this is the place to go. Parking is limited so include that in you visit logistics.
Waterfront day out. V and A is a wonderful place to take family freinds....to many things to mention,wonderful cafes,restaurents,retail stores,I had a lovly time.
Beautiful Place. Great place with really nice view. There is a mall, many restaurants, aquarium and many different places to see there.

good place to shop eat and drink. good mall, with an outdoor area. Plenty of restaurants and coffee shops. Playa particularly is good to sit and look over the ocean, especially as the sun sets ( you can also have a sheesha on the balcony)
Great Place to wonder around. This is where you get the boat to Robben Island and we spent a while walking about the shops etc. Definitely worth a visit and maybe lunch..

No-go for South Africans. Although has the most amazing backdrop with everything that is fancy and nice, I feel that the locals, whether they live in Cape Town, or travel from Pretoria, Johannesburg, or any other places, are being ripped off by overcharged foods, drinks and snacks.
Nice But Very Touristy. It's a nice setting and a must visit if you're in town, but realize that it's very touristy, crowded. My son loved the ferris wheel.

Nice place to hang around.. On my visit last year I stayed near the V & A Waterfront. Almost everyday during the few weeks of my stay I visited this place as it was very convenient and safe for people to hang around without worrying much about staying late out or transportation.It is very touristic as throughout the day you find many people mostly tourist hanging around having a good time. The locals are found in abundance too. The reason in my opinion this place clicks is because its got many restaurants to cater to different budgets, bars, shopping centre and shops. There are shows that take place throughout the day by the locals performing on the streets at times,very entertaining.The shopping mall has a big choice of products for all kinds along with grocery store, pharmacies, clinics, theatre hall, tourist help center, ATMs. The security in this area is very alert and in abundance thus keeping a control on any bad elements. At the quay side you can see seals and various yachts and sailing boats. Its also easy to book adventure trips from here. Very good for families and others.Price wise I found this area more expensive then other places in Cape Town but its worth spending more and enjoying the comfort and ease of shopping. There are taxi and bus service available from here if you want to go elsewhere. I would highly recommend people to visit this place or during the stay live nearby this area. Good place to hang around for a few hours.

Good place. I visited the place yesterday. Very good place. My kids enjoyed it. La thought it was cold for them (being from Congo) they liked seeing different shops, the diversity of people, ...
We enjoyed the Nu cinema movie theatre, the big wheel, the Aquarium.
Strongly recommend the stop by!

A must visit!. If you are in Cape Town, this is a must visit! Great views, shops, wonderful restaurants, fantastic atmosphere, everything African is here! Don't miss this visit to this monumental site in South Africa, highly recommended!

Great area to stay. We stayed in the V&A waterfront area on a recent trip to Cape Town and found it to be a great place to be. There are many restaurants at different price points to choose from, there is a food market with a butcher, cheese shops, and international stands to purchase all kinds of food. There are singing groups and street performers in the evenings. There is also a Hop on Hop off Bus stop nearby (adjacent to the aquarium). There are many shops around the area but really nothing that I felt compelled to visit. There are a lot of shops selling standard touristy stuff. There is also a mall with standard and high end shops in the area. We enjoyed staying in this location and I recommend it! It felt very safe (if you use common sense) and it was nice to be able to walk to dinner at night and not have to worry about transportation.
lovely place to walk around. great resturants and nice trips to robben island lovely food places nice shops and movie house and great views

Bucket list this!. Stunning views, shopping, places to eat, pubs and lots to do. From catching a movie to viewing Table Mountain from the sea, the waterfront has it all! Gourmet food market, crafts aquarium, museums! Beware though, its NOT for budget strapped and the parking is some of the most expensive in the country!

Perfect place to walk around. Wonderful place! My husband and I stayed at the Victoria & Alfred hotel and could easily walk around the V & A Waterfront. It was beautiful at night and very lively. There were often local musicians and performing groups around the V & A Waterfront. While the actual mall part is mainly retail stores found everywhere else in the world, there are some unique souvenir shops as well. We ate in several restaurants at the V & A Waterfront and all were delicious and exceptional. The pricing was average for US, some even cheaper than what we are used to back home. I would highly recommend the V & A Waterfront. It is a wonderful place to walk around and take in the sights.
Lovely place to wander. this place is great - nice places to eat, shops to browse and boats to watch...... well worth spending some time

Not impressed. We have expected much more from the Waterfront and were not impressed by it. There is a huge construction site on one side which is really dusty but you must go past it if you are walking from the city. The Waterfront is OK, nothing special, we preferred the city centre. The shopping centre is good, restaurants are better elsewhere, some souvenir shops are nice. The only nice thing is the view of Table Mountain.

Wish it were summer. Spent three evenings at the waterfront. The vibrant atmosphere even in winters makes me wonder how it must be in summers. Local musicians add to the flavour. A great place to hang out in the evening with many a watering hole and great places to eat. Mitchell's Ale House seemed very popular with the locals & tourists. There are eateries to cater to those with cash to spend (generally around the mall), but there are cheaper options too - typically fish & chips places.Lots of shopping places in the area. The craft market is a great place for buying local handicrafts - it's not necessarily cheap though.

Touristy Place, Touristy Prices. I can't imagine visiting Cape Town and not going to the waterfront. We ended up visiting three times during our stay, but the mall part of the waterfront was never our destination. Instead, we went twice to the Nelson Mandela Gateway center to catch the ferry (it was cancelled one day because of the weather) and once to shop at the nearby crafts center where we also caught the Red Bus Tour. We did venture inside the mall portion and did some shopping but the prices were high as you might expect. We shopped instead inside the crafts place next to the Red Bus tour stop where there are local merchants selling their goods for a lot less. There are also other things to do at the waterfront besides shopping. You can take a 1 hour harbor tour which we did when our trip to Robben Island was cancelled. It was pretty inexpensive. We also went on the Cape Wheel which is a very large ferris wheel similar to the London Eye. I would recommend either of these activities.

Over Priced...!. The V&A waterfront is a nice place to visit but unless you are eating fast food then you need to make sure you have a lot of cash with you. The restaurants are extremely expensive as they cater ONLY for tourists. You will find all the top end designer brands at ridiculous prices however there are a number of mid ranged affordable places to do some shopping. All in All rather drive 20km further north to Canal Walk, a much better Shopping Mall and has a lot more to offer.

Shopping, dining and watching the world go by. V & A has it all.. This is the pulsing heart of modern Cape Town. There are bars, micro-breweries, restaurants, shops galore and attractions. We spent two evenings here and an aftenoon shopping for gifts to bring home. Over a lovely local brew at Mitchells Ale House we mixed with the locals who were very welcoming and keen to talk rugby. The banter was good natured and fun. We also enjoyed the live band playing at Ferryman's Original Waterfront Tavern. So many great spots to enjoy. Dinner was equally as enjoyable and our impression was that this is where Cape Town's folk come to just enjoy themselves and relax. What a setting to do so. Make sure you allow yourself a few trips to the V & A Waterfront. You will enjoy every moment.

A little bit of a Disney feel in Cape Town. This is quite the sight. The Waterfront itself is exceptional and this is quite the tourist haven with its many shops, restaurants and performing groups littered about the area. It also houses the Nelson Mandela Gateway and ferry to Robbens Island. Parking is secure--I like the Portswood Square Parking across from the Aquarium and it's not all that expensive to park for several hours from R10-40 (USD 1-4).

Brilliant! Love it!. Love the vibes, the restaurants, the shops, the views, atmosphere, lots to do and see. The bathrooms were cleaner than most 1st world countries bathrooms. Everyone was very friendly, engaging and welcoming! We didn't want to leave!
Great. The Waterfront was close to our hotel. We felt safe enough to walk around at night. There is lots of security and they are also helpful if you need directions. Lots of choices for dinner.

Just a Mall. When we contemplated how to spend a rainy day in Cape Town, several people recommended the V & A Waterfront. Well, it did keep us out of the rain, but many of the stores were North American Mall chains. That and high end brand stores for label watchers. Food court and sit-down restaurants pricier than elsewhere in Cape Town, without the character. It was clean and pretty, but I really expected more from this gorgeous city.

Shopping and Culture. Take a walk around the malls filled with South African chain stores and crafts. Watch the boats sailing in and out of the harbour while trying to spot a seal popping its nose out of the water. Take in the talents of the buskers.

Ships, water, food and merchandise!. Like many cities the waterfront has been renewed and the old has been replaced by upscale hotels, restaurants and numerous tours. The atmosphere here is great and it is only a few steps from parking and a good number of above average hotels and restaurants. The waterfront is also the jumping off spot for tours to the prison on Robbin Island where Nelson Mandella was held for 20 years. The Victoria and Albert hotel and mall is especially nice and located in the heart of the waterfront. There is also a large shopping mall and native craft mall in the area. We found many great local crafts at very good prices in the craft mall.

It might be for tourists, but i really liked it. The waterfront is a great place to walk around a have a look at the ships in the port, it also offers a stunning view of the table mountain. It is great to go for shopping, especially for nice colorful african crafts. There is a huge choice of very good restaurants and many tour possibilities starting here. I like it a lot.

Everything you could want in a shopping mall. We spent 3 days in 2010 walking around the V&A and then spent another 2 days in May 2013 doing the same. The V&A has a wide variety of shops, many well priced from budget clothing to equisite jewellery and enough food outlets for all tastes. Security are at each entrance to ensure safety of shoppers and are all very unobtrusive. Plenty of parking underneath and nearby is helpful also. You will need a couple of days to explore the entire area including the red and blue sheds which have arts and crafts galore. Located right on the waterfront, taking a stroll in between shopping to the docks is great with stunning views of table mountain right at your doorstep. Great place to buy those last minute gifts for the family before heading home.

Represents Cape Town. Out of all the shopping malls, I feel this place represents Cape Town very well. It is definitely a must visit due to the rich heritage and diverse shopping experience. Do note that everything here is guaranteed to be expensive (besides the grocery store), especially the restaurants all over. There's quite a lot of activities available so definitely drop by when you feel like doing a bit of shopping and adventure!

Great part of Cape Town by day or night. The VA Waterfront is a good mix of shopping, food, drink and sights. You can walk around most of the marina area taking in the different views of Table Mountain and the Waterfront. There is a vast array of restaurants which get popular at night so booking may sometimes be necessary.A lovely place for chilling during or after a busy day sightseeing :)

Lovely section of Cape Town. We stayed across the street from the Waterfront. It was a bit noisy, but seems like they shut things down at midnight, so not too bad. We enjoyed the shops and the variety of restaurants so close to our hotel, which is really nice after a long day of touring. So nice to eat outside, even during the late fall, and enjoy the views, while having a nice meal.
Victoria and Alfred Waterfront. A must for those wanting to take in shopping, experience the entertainment of real singing and just soak up the atmosphere!

V & A Waterfront. This was where I spent the better part of the weekend. A safe and scenic place. I took two boat rides, ate at three restaurants, and shopped at the mall. It helped that the weather was fantastic.

International attraction. Huge shopping complex with breathtakingly views of Table mountain & harbour. Lots to do for whole family. Great restaurants & shops. Night time is beautiful with all the restaurants lights & lively entertainment. It's a must for visiting when you are in Cape Town!

Good and entertainment for all members of the family. Plenty to do but some activities at Sky High prices, so for the local traveller be prepared to shell out some serious money for a helicopter ride or trip to Robin Island. Lots of food options and plenty of shopping. Could use a bit more entertainment areas for the kids. Overall worth the trip there.
Lots of shops!!. Pricy shops!! Some pricy restaurants too, but you can find better value if you're careful. The Craft and Food Markets are well worth a visit. Atmosphere good in the evening.
Lots of shops!!. Pricy shops!! Some pricy restaurants too, but you can find better value if you're careful. The Craft and Food Markets are well worth a visit. Atmosphere good in the evening.

what a beautiful place. i had been here and it was terrific the aquarium here has sooo many fish and there are a variety of restaurants to choose from there is also a place where children can have fun the mall here is awsome for branded products

Great Spot for Dinner. Great views, plenty of international restaurants to choose from. The views are great here. Most restaurants offer outside seating and blankets for when cold. Also serves as a mall with all the euro and western clothing stores. There is a pick n pay here where you can grab water, drinks, groceries. Sometimes a few rough people looking for money but ignore if you don't want to give. If you do give have small money in a different pocket so you are not fumbling in front of.Some bands play too and always fun to watch. Just watch pick pockets

Getting a bit bling!. Feels like it has turned the corner into a typical tourist destination. Starting to loose it's character in return for high prices, brand names and lots... I mean lots of tourists!

Not just a Mall. Not just a mall, but a great experience. It really reminded me of Toronto’s waterfront with the street performers, live bands and all sorts of entertainment. Prices in the mall were on par for what I would pay in Canada. But they had things we usually wouldn’t see. Good food, good views in a total package. Spend a day wandering around you wont regret it.

You have to go there at least once. A great shopping centre with both upmarket and normal shops and a good variety of restaurants. You can catch some great entertainment and the views are beautiful in almost every direction.

Awesome!. The V & A Waterfront is in some ways a one stop gateway to most of Cape Town. You can book most activities here, shop and eat pretty much almost everything. During our time there, there was a series of live concerts by local bands held (mostly weekends) and we were lucky to catch one. This place offers loads of options for eating and possibly has restaurants of almost every cuisine, in case you miss home food or comfort food or even pubs. Plus it was walking distance from our hotel. We were told that the waterfront has been acquired by a Dubai based Company and new things will always be in the offing. A must hang out for everyone!!

A must visit. Spent the whole day at the V & A and never saw half of it. Great atmosphere, superb restaurants and shops, art galleries and so much more. All in a picturesque setting with Table Top Mountain in the background. Being from the UK we found the prices very reasonable. Hope to return one day.
Shoppers' delight. V and A is a shoppers and people watchers delight. Very clean. Upbeat atmosphere. Really good restaurants, many feature South African wines and entertainment.

Interesting. Beautiful for pictures. Also a good place for shopping although the shops at the mall are a bit more expensive than other malls. Would definitely visit again because I didn't get to experience the dividing bridge.

Great selection of all branded retail stores and restaurants. Must rate as one of the top waterfront developments in the world. Wonderful setting with views of Table Bay and Table Mountain. Launch base for trips to historic Robben island.

Nice stay but really shoddy internet. This place is located in a nice place on the waterfront with many restaurants and shops to choose from.However, the hotel internet is shoddy at best. I would rate it on par with internet service you'd get in the middle of nowhere - nonexistent. You'll likely get service on your device the moment you sit down, but what a tease! you try to open google and the service shuts down on you, so you'll have to make a call to the front desk to reset the router. I've had to do this 4 times already. Sorry, but internet should just work, i should not have to make calls to the front desk to make this happen. We're in the 21st century people! everyone is connected and if i want to check something up quickly, the internet service shouldn't be the backlog. Stay elsewhere if you at all care about being connected. There are PLENTY of hotels around this area to choose from. Also, front desk isn't very inviting, knowledgeable or willing to share information with hotel guests. If you ask them for any recommendations at all, they're happy with telling you "everything is good around here." really? give me an opinion. That shows you have no clue or don't care.

Water front is beutifull. Was on a business trip to Cape Town. The last evening before going home the next day, the boss decided to take us all for dinner at Quay Four at the waterfront. It was wonderful sitting next to the boats having cocktails and a fresh fish platter.
World Class. My wife & I really enjoyed browzing and eating at the V&A. Very clean and excellent decor. Great variety of shops and restaurants. View from top of big wheel great.

V&A Waterfront world-class restaurants & shops. V&A Waterfront is the most beautiful waterfront I've ever experienced. The views are amazing, the buzz of the harbor grand, the restaurants plentiful and the shopping great. With everything being in one place you can spend a day and evening here easily. Deciding where to eat will be your most difficult decision. I loved being here taking photos of the spectacular views, especially at sunset. If the weather gets hot and you want to cool down, V&A Waterfront is the place to be. The hotels here are magnificent as well. It's a perfect mix of experiences.

A great place with lovely restaurants, shops and activities. We stayed in Cape Town for 4 nights and visited this place 3 times. It is buzzing with street entertainers great eateries and souvenir shops. It is definitely the place to be.

Scenic and loads of shopping. The V&A Waterfront is designed for everyone from locals to the tourist. From the moment you enter the area there is a vibrancy about the place. With African buskers singing and dancing too the visitors and helicopter and Shark dive operators spruiking their wares. This adds to the whole atmosphere of the area.There are numerous tourist shops to buy that trinket for someone at home or even that special memento for yourself. Me, I bought an Ostrich egg painted with the map of Africa on one side and the big 5 on the other. There are eateries all over the wharf ranging from fine dining at Sevruga to the coffee shop at Vovo Telo and shops galore in two shopping malls to placate anyones shopping fancy. Also take time to look at the Waterfront Craft market and stroll through looking at local artists painting, carvings and jewellery.As far as scenic, no matter where you walk, you can see one of the most fascinating mountains in the world, Table Mountain. You can also arrange a trip to Robben Island at the Nelson Mandela Gateway, providing the weather permits. Cape Town is one of the prettiest cities in the world with plenty to do too take in the history and atmosphere, and is up there with the best in Rome, Paris, London and Sydney.
shopping till you drop. what ever you want you will find it here, its a bit pricey, but it is when all said and done, for tourists

A MUST DO!!!. Wow we hired a catamaran for two hours and had the time of our lives. So relaxing a must do for anybody wanting to chill out. Also just to walk around the shops and also they have a crafts market which is where i would suggest one got their gifts as this helps the local people who are trying to make a living and also is much cheaper than the shops within the Malls. Went back often and ate at The Spurs which had an unreal view of the mountain and the sea...miss you already...

Ideal place to ease into Cape Town. There has been so much said about this venue. It is a great place to begin you Cape Town experience. As usual my insider secrets:1. If you are shopping for high end timepieces, you will be surprised at the deals you can pick up here.2. This is a great place to have your "portrait" painted for a affordable price. There are usually artists near Cape Union Mart. Go have your photo taken and they will do a pencil drawing for you.3. I forget the name of the place but there is a fish and chips cafe at the marina across from where the Robben Island tourist boats leave. The food there is fantastic!

Colonial Elegance. We visited South Afica to tour the Garden route and had not booked any accomodation as we wanted to do it ad hoc. Arrived in Cape Town at 6am and took a Taxi to the City Centre, the only place we knew was the Waterfront. So after pulling up outside the Hotel I decided to try there first. The room was expensive but not over priced and we booked a room with harbour views.The room wasnt available due to the timing so we were offered breakfast on the Terrace; we sat down to fresh fruit and pastries and watched Sea Lions frolick in the harbour. The room was made available just after Breakfast and we took to our room, where upon the view wasn't just the beautiful harbour but also Table Top Mountain ......... Stunning!The room was aprox thirty foot long and in superb condition the bathroom was also hue with a massive bath. We took to the town for the Afternoon and pertied in the evening, feeling slighly jaded at 11pm due to travelling we returned to our room where we were met with petals on the floor and candles around the room.A truly Truly wonderful experience and highly recomended.

World class. The V & A waterfront is situated between Mouille Point and Cape Town central near the old SOmerset Hospital. It consists of a huge shopping mall with designer shops as well as the normal shops such as Pick n Pay, Woolworths, Truworths, Edgars etc. SO there is something for everyone. Outside consists of lots of restaurants, most of them pricey and not very good. There is a harbour which is beautiful and lots of rides around the harbour. It is certainly world class and you could spend at least half a day there (if youre wanting to shop). If not you could just go to one of the many restaurants or coffee shops and walk around. Just be careful - as upmarket as it is, there are pick pockets milling around

Touristy. Off course you'll have to see the Waterfront when visiting Cape Town - like all the other millions of tourists in town. It's a beautiful spot and a very tasteful way to rethink an old seafront. Enjoy the nice surroundings, the fresh air, and the sea view. But do yourself a favour: Don't eat at the restaurants, instead grab a bite and an excellent cup of coffee in the food market where you get good value for money. Or eat in one of Cape Town's many other good restaurants.

great mix of working port, tourist attraction, fine dining and retail therapy. Worth a long day out, but excursions, eg Robben Island need forward planning to get tickets. Full range of indie fast food outlets, craft shops as well as specialist high end retailers. Watching authentic shipping alongside tourism convinces that this is a sustainable model.

An Sprawling and Safe Shopping and Entertainment District. An enormous shopping center, cafes, and restaurants make it a nice place to visit. There is a fancy hotel and a museum. At night some places offer dancing. The area is cordoned off and looked after by (unarmed) security personnel, making it secure, also at night.

Such a beautiful location. Stunning location, whether you envy the boats in the harbour or like to watch the seals playing around the dock. There's great mix of tourism and industry and please let it stay like this. It is fascinating to see how quickly large ships are stripped down and repainted. There is a great variety of restaurants to suit most budgets. A must to stay near here if visiting Cape Town, as you can daily get to all the main tourist attractions from here.

More than Food at V&A. The postings below seem to focus on the restaurants, but the V&A is a lot more than that. Take a walk around and you will find the maritime museum, the clock Tower, and it is from here that you can take the boat to Robben Island. If the weather is not great go to the aquarium, and there is a great archeological museum just under the Nedbank head office. Also have a look at the business school which is located in a converted prison, which also has a restaurant at pretty decent prices. If you want to try another waterfront in Cpae Town, try the Royal Cape Yachting Club, be nice and they will let you in as a guest. The V&A has all sorts of restaurants at different prices, and a great supermarket where you can buy a sandwich at the going Cape Town price and enjoy the V&A waterfront vibe.
A beautiful location for beautiful people. a great place to sit and drink a chilled glass of wine for a "sundowner" Lots of choices for good food and people-watching.

Worth seeing from a touristy perspective. There's no doubt you need to come here when visiting Cape Town.It's more expensive than anywhere else in terms of the restaurants and bars and shops.Basically a working harbour with a collection of malls and all the usual KFC, McDonalds as well as upmarket restaurants.There is a nice farmers market bit where you can taste the lovely food, I liked this bit.A lot of souvenir shops and this is where you catch the ferry to Robben Island.It's always very busy amd bustling with buskers and singers.We only came once during our 12 day stay in Cape Town.Very touristy and they are cashing in on that with their prices. Also the taxi we got back to our hotel from the Waterfront 'forgot' to put the meter on so we gave him half the fare he was about to rip us off for.Overall I liked the fact I've seen it but wouldn't rave about it and i wouldn't stay here either. I believe the city centre has more to offer.

Tourists everywhere. It wasn't even as great as expected. I mean. Yes there is the waterfront with shops and food. But like expected it has high prices for food. With so many great restaurants around town I would suggest to eat something elsewhere and come for a walk afterwards. Don't get me wrong. It's nice to see the harbour. And if maybe there is a specific restaurant you want to go to. But tourists are everywhere an they gauge you in prices for knick knacks. And high prices for food. And the food lovers market. It's got vendors from flowers, butcher, sweets,coffee, ice cream and food of all sorts. I would only come back to try some of the restaurants over looking the water.
Excellent shopping and eating opportunities. The waterfront harbour area has been significantly enhanced by this shopping centre, and well located food courts / restaurants.

Amazing. i was there on new years eve and i should say its one of the best places to be ...the fire works the surroundings wow its out of this world.as a frequent traveler this is one of the best places i have enjoyed and one of the best countries i would be looking forward to going back .cant wait till the next time :)

A little bit of everything. The V&A Waterfront offers people a bit of everything, from shopping and dining to history and learning more about the surrounding ocean life. The mall is home to a wide range of shops. Here you'll find international brands, designer items and some local souvenirs as well.There are so many great places to have a bite to eat or enjoy a drink while taking in the view of Table Mountain and the harbour. My favourite thing to do is to get some Marcell's Frozen Yoghurt and stroll through the Waterfront. There's also a lot of history at the Waterfront. If you like history, visit the University of Cape Town's Business School. The Breakwater Lodge used to be a prison and you can still see etchings into one of the outside walls made by prisoners. Besides the history, you can also visit the Two Oceans Aquarium. It's a great option if you're looking for something to keep the kids entertained...although as an adult I love visiting it too.I was however very disappointed in the area near the Clocktower. What used to be vibrant and an incredibly busy space, especially as the weekend approached, now looks like 'no man's land'. The small mall area there is almost deserted,. There's a Moyo Restaurant (there seems to be one around every corner these days), but they've constructed these hideous stalls where you can buy snacks from and it just doesn't add anything to the area. I was very disappointed in that regards. But generally, the V&A is a great place to stop for a few hours while visiting Cape Town.

Stunning!. This is the safest and the liveliest area in Capetown. The waterfront is where the life of the city is, during the day and night. Places to eat, boating, breweries, shopping, wines, amphi theatre, giant wheel, aquarium and the list can go on!One can reach there post lunch and can indulge in the number of activities the place has to offer till the wee hours of the night. Not to mention the amazing views from the place.Waterfront has something to do for every age group. Make sure you go for the boat rides during the sunset and if ready to spend then the helicopter rides too!

V&A, the Cape Town honeypot. This is one of the key places to see and wander around when in Cape Town. Yes, it's really here for the tourist trade, though you'll find a surprising number of locals here too. There's a big shopping mall for the retail therapy, restaurants from McD to expnsive, from fish and sushi to ostrich and zebra (yes, zebra. Don't tell Findus!)The bar scene is good here too, with the "older" bars like the Ferrymans (live music on weekends) and Mitchells. And then the tourist shops, full of painted ostrich eggs and the like. Oh, and a few very expensive art galleries.In summary, something for everyone (including the kids - play areas and a cinema too). Don't miss when in Cape Town.
Wow. We stayed on the Waterfront. It's a great place to eat, drink, shop and people watch. We did all four to excess. Loved every minute.

A working dock. One of the many reasons why this excellent waterfront is so attractive to tourists is because it remains a working dock with a heartbeat!! Besides the shopping precinct with lots of shops to browse around, there are hotels, apartments, offices, craft workshops, wellness centres, bars, cafes, bistros, restaurants for all tastes, museums. live entertainment, harbour cruises and lots more. Great for all ages and lots of friendly visible security, Car parking is reasonably priced.

Nothing Lacking. My God.... this place has got the lot! Food, entertainment, bars, music and beautiful views of the Bay and Table Mountain. No wonder it is South Africa's premier tourist destination with more that three million visitors (seriously) last December alone. We stayed at the Table Bay Hotel for three nights (should have made it a week) so were right on the doorstep. Everything is here and conveniently within walking distance. Your own little world within a world buzzing with activity, colour, sounds and smells and never a dull moment. Everyone is happy. Everyone is helpful. And the Waterfront encapsulates all that is great about this great city. Street musicians pound on their drums, sing and improvise. You can spend as little or as much as you want on a meal. A multitude of cruises whisk you to all manner of sights. Helicopter rides, Ferris wheel, exclusive jewelry shops to dream in, amazing souvenirs, seals basking on the jetties... a real melting pot of all that is fine in life.The whole area is quite expansive but easily traversed on foot. Honestly, when you visit here it with some difficulty you eventually have to drag yourself away. Cannot possibly be done in a day so lash out and spend several. You will not be disappointed.

Enjoyable afternoon on Cape Town Waterfront.. Very enjoyable. Lively atmosphere -not too crowded, along with lovely weather. There are plenty of shops, attractions, and if you have money, plenty of items are available in the shops to purchase, including Nelson Mandela Type Shirts!There were stalls which sold Seafoods, African meats, Lobsters,and different African Wines. There were also African Bands performing, and one could stop, watch and listen to them for as long as one liked!There is also an African "Gallery" which sells all kinds of crafts, things that are made around the Cape Town Area, pictures, necklaces carvings etc. There were also the usual fortune telling rooms, and healers who offered their services at a price. My South African carer told us( Mum, Dad and me) that the vendors expect one to bargain, and if one accepts the first price they offer, they feel insulted! Unfortunately, bargaining is not a skill the English are accustomed to!We finished off the afternoon by going to the open air restrurant on the Waterfront in which we had Castle's Beer, with views overlooking Table Mountain. We had to be careful.because even in the summer, it can get very breezy in Cape Town, particularly in the evening, and my carer's glass of Castle blew over and soaked my trousers! Never mind, they soon dried!The restrurant also sells Snook, which is an extremely popular fish in Cape Town. One could also if one wanted eat Springbok, Kudu, Ostrich and Warthog. Snook apparently, was available in WW2 in Britain, but rapidly become unavailable when the war ended.

A Lively and Enjoyable Hub of Cape Town!. Sure, this is made for tourists. Not a big deal to me. So many food options of all prices and quality. Lots of shops, lots of variety. Very positive atmosphere with marimba bands (some really good ones played during my visits) playing randomly through the day. Very safe! Really clean! If a restaurant isn't your choice, then walk through the Market on The Wharf. The fresh choices looked amazing. I didn't eat there because I had an early dinner reservation coming up, but give it a try. And then walk next door to buy a good wine to enjoy. Downtown Cape Town does not (my opinion) have a core where you can walk, relax and enjoy a drink or a meal like the V & A. You are on vacation, people. Be a tourist. Its ok.

All you need with a VIEW. At the Victoria and Alfred Waterfront Summer Time is concert time! Live bands perform at no charge in an amphitheater in the old port, every weekend. So when you are done with your day of touring, need a place to relax, you now know where to get some live entertainment and a cold beer or a glass of fine South African Wine.
Nice but like any other. This a a modern shopping complex on the water. Nice restaurants, a mall, grocery store, and high end shops. Don't go here looking for bargains.

Touristy & Gimmicky. What you see is what you get with this place. It's a waterfront, so of course it is beautiful. I would go there to catch some rays and walk around and people watch, but I wouldn't actually buy anything there. If you plan to go to Robben Island museum, the ticket office and the boat to the island leaves from here, so you can see it before or after your museum visit.

A lot to see and do and I had great service when needed to ship abroad. You havn´t seen Cape Town if you havn´t visited V & A Waterfront! Here are both a big shopping center as well as smaller souvenir shops, restaurants for all ages with different cousines and in all price ranges. There are often live entertainments on the streets to enhance the mood. Here you find the ferries to Robben Island where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned and you will also get a good view over Table Mountain. Are you looking for adrenalin this is where you easy can book a speedboat adventure, a helicopter ride or a tandem paragliding flights. Don´t miss the fantastic Two Ocean Aquarium well worth a visit. Just outside the aquarium you find the main bus stop for City Sightseeing Hop on Hop Off buses - great sightseeing with guided tours in many languages via earphones included in the price. Take the bus to get to Table Mountain cableway, lyxury Mount Nelson Hotel where the afternoon tea is something extra not to miss, fantastic Kirstenbosch Gardens with all it´s flowers, Cape Town´s most luxury beach Camps Bay and you can also easy change to antother bus with a wine tour.If you want to buy a really nice souvenir you can have a lot of fun with like a djembe drum, I really recommend a visit to Waterfront Craft Market and the djembe shop on the ground level. The store is owned by Aisha Diop and her brother. I bought a djembe drum from them and got both a great price and outstanding service. They shipped the drum to Sweden and I was a little bit worried since I havn´t got the drum within a month. Aisha answered my e-mails with my concern, she visited the post office to track the drum and followed up by e-mail until I got the drum. Since it was shipped by boat it took about two months to arrive, but well worth the wait since it´s a proffessional drum with excellent quality - so no worries if you shop by Aisha if you need help with shipping abroad!

A nice spot to spend the afternoon. V&A Waterfront is, basically, a "tourist trap". But a very nice one! A huge mall together with souvenirs shops and very nice restaurants, all together in a beautiful scenery, contouring the harbour. The view of Table Moutain is astonishing. A perfect place to shop and eat!

A GREAT DAY OUT. The Victoria and Alfred Waterfront is a very worthwhile day out. Apart from the hundreds of shops, [paradise] there is an amazing ammount of excellent restuarants. Live entertainment, lots of attractions like the Aquarium where you can swim with the sharks if brave enough. On our recent visit we went 3 times and still didnt see it all. A big bonus is lots of sea trips go from there and most of all is very very safe.

Touristy, but actually very nice.... I normally wouldn´t expect that I would like a place this touristy, but to be honest I was very impressed. Aside from the fact that every 2 meters there is someone asking if you want to do their tour/cruise/etc, the area itself is very nicely built, with beautiful buildings, new markets with fresh, local foods, drinks and live music, some fantastic (not even over-priced!) restaurants (loved the sushi at Sevrugi), and even the shopping isn´t bad - our favorite was the African Exchange where you can buy lots of local goods for very affordable and know that the money is going to a good cause (near the clock tower). Very nice, and also open on Sundays, which is great because not much else IN the city is...

Felt very safe in this area. Security really keeps the riiff raff out of the Waterfront area. No loiterers or up-to-no gooders allowed!! While its easy to feel anxious in a foreign country, this was definitely my safe haven from my more dangerous outings away from the Waterfront. Everything I wanted to do was easily arranged by the helpful front desk staff. The morning breakfast was delicious, loved the fresh oysters! The rooms were not fancy for the price paid but it was very clean.
Massive shopping mall - US style.... with lots of eateries too. Nice to get in out of the heat for a few hours :) apart from that a shop is a shop the world over!

Entertaining Walkabout. Nobel square with SA laureates Albert Luthuli, Nelson Mandela, de Klerk and Desmond Tutu was the main attraction for me as a South African. The harbour has been revamped with modern buildings, designer stores, restaurants, a food market, craft market, the Ferris wheel and entertainment.It is worth spending half a day at the Waterfront when visiting Cape Town!

Eat, drink and be merry!!!!. What a wonderful spot to stroll and window shop and be entertained. A great addition to beautiful Cape Town. A very safe area filled with fabulous shop and restaurants. A great mix of new and old for locals and tourists to enjoy!!! There are even seals playing in the water for wildlife lovers to view!!! Modern shops line the way as well as local artisans showing their wares. Live entertainment keeps the place hopping! Don't miss!

A mixture of history and modern times. On one hand you have modern buildings filled with shops, the obligatory over sized Ferris wheel that every city seem to have these days, then you have this amazing historic harbor complete with dry docks, swing bridge and working boats, inhabited by seals. the older buildings have mainly been turned int more shops, but the overall effect is quite intriguing. well worth wandering around if you are in Cape town and certainly more entertaining than the aquarium located there.

Reclaimed waterfront that is the hub of entertainment and shopping in Cape Town. They did a great job redoing the ancient waterfront and developing it into a major attraction in the city. It draws thousands of people to shop, dine, walk around, listen to music. That may be one of its problems--too hectic and too many people. There are boat rides, ferris wheel, music in amphitheater and many more things to do. There are a number of shopping areas, a craft building and seemingly hundreds of places to eat and drink, from upscale, to fast food--there is even a McDonald's. For a novice, trying to find a specific store or restaurant can be daunting--there are kiosks that digitally show directions, but you can easily get lost inside some of those buildings.. Bus transportation to and from the waterfront is fairly easy and you do not have to deal with parking a car. We took a Golden Arrown bus from Seapoint which runs along the Beach Road and got us to the center in 20 minutes and cost only 8 Rand.

Something for Everyone. The V&A Waterfront has a little bit of everything.Mall: you can shop to your heart's content (from home goods to designer clothes)Movie theater: latest movies, although it gets really crowded on FridaysFood: there's a huge variety, from fine dining to KFCPhoto ops: ferris wheel (view from the top is great), statues of famous people, clear blue skies, waterBut when I say everything, I mean even things for people me--I'm not much of a shopper and I don't eat in fancy restaurants all the time. But on weekends my husband and I will pack a small picnic (bread, cheese, fruit, etc.) and go to the Waterfront just to sit in the shade with a book while enjoying the free music (there's usually a band playing at the amphitheater, or an outdoor performance by a marimba band or a drum/dance group). For a treat, we'll pop into the V&A food market for some chocolate or gelato.
Time for an Italian at Melonielio.. Great view over The Waterfront. Great for people watching.Good value and tasty food. Thank you Quiet for great service!

Nice place to shop & dine. Over the years the V & A waterfront has got bigger & better in my eyes offering an abundance of mixed shops for all tastes & pocket plus a huge variety of dining experiences.A day could easily be spent here and if you have friends or family that want to do the Robben Island Tour detailing the history of Aparthaid & Nelson Mandela they also could kill 3 hours.Nightime here is over run with tourists but to be honest if you looking for non touristy shops and restaurants then head for Cape Town City Centre where things are less busy.Even once during your trip V & A is a must stopping point

One big shopping centre. This is often billed as the number one tourist attraction in South Africa. Yes, there are lots and lots of tourist who visit this place... But it is just a big shopping centre. If you want to shop till you drop in a centre with an amazing view, this is the place for you. Also it has loads of restaurants - something for everyone, from fast food to gourmet. The seals are smelly, but good to have a look at. The live 'African' entertainment can be fun at times, but watch out for pick-pockets and the stray beggar that gets past the very good security. This is a true city-slicker tourist trap.

Cape Town sightseeing. V and A waterfront is a great place to spend an afternoon. Loads of shops to visit and interesting boat trips. Thoroughly recommend MoJo's for food. In the middle of the waterfront and you see lots of kids wondering round with their silver face paint .City centre itself is also nice to walk round and felt safe to us. There was never any feeling that we wee at risk.

An amazing place. You couldn't ask for anything more from this place. There are clothing, wine, gift shops, all types of restaurants, fast food joints, shopping centres, hotels, bakeries, pub/bars, cinema and many many more. It's a very clean and people are very friendly.

CAPE TOWN AT ITS BEST!. The Waterfront never fails to bring out the tourist in me - and in my home country! So much to do - shopping, eating out, boat trips, stunning views of Table Mountain and the ocean. Real cosmopolitan feeling - great to sit down at one of the many restaurants and just watching the people. Will return again.... and again .....
Impressive shopping and meals by the beach. My family and I enjoyed the shopping and meals at V&A, which is a the breach front. We shall definitely visit V&A again.

nice place for leisure. Beautiful place to dinner with some good and some bad restaurants. Huge shopping mall with good stores. A visit in the evening will give you great pictures to take by night of the area. Lots of companies where you can book a visit on Robben island.

Good for shopping and eating. Let's be honest. There's no fantastic view here per se. There are tons of shops and restaurants, as well as live entertainment on the little streets. Many popular touristy photo spots (clock tower, anyone?). This is the place to come hungry and be ready to spend a little money, otherwise you'll be bored. Great people-watching. Lots of places to sit and have a drink. Many good restaurants that serve tasty food. There are also often special events like the Red Bull Flugtag. We go to the waterfront every time we're in Cape Town because it's just a fun place to be. Reservations recommended for dinner in high season.

Love this place!. I am not a mall person or someone that is a die hard shopper but we found everything that we could possibly need all in one place! I have visited waterfront attractions in several countries around the world and have not really found anything comparable. There is a huge variety of different cuisines represented at the V&A Waterfront. We loved the Two Oceans Aquarium. I always enjoy walking through the craft markets and browsing to see what's new. There are great views of the mountain and bay from the main mall. We enjoyed watching the different shows and/or acts on and around the amphitheater. A few years back we played putt-putt in the caves. We didn't have the time this time around to see if they were still in existence. In season there is always something to do in the waterfront. There is a parking fee for those that are driving.

Great to explore, but mainly shops. Its really great to visit the V&A and is an interesting "wander about". However, once you have spent about an hour there its really just for the shopping - or eating

Great Place - but watch out for Con-Artists. I always enjoy visiting the waterfront - I think it is a beautiful place that every tourist in Cape Town should see.
