I have spent a lot of time visiting the waterfront in the last few months and before you read the rest of my review, please note that the waterfront is VERY SAFE with lots of security guards patrolling the place.However, being a huge tourist attraction, I think that it is very important to stress that con-artists and lately, I've noticed a con-artist-turned- pickpocket operating in the area. More specifically, ON TWO OCCASIONS, a very well-spoken brown-skinned woman with long curly/permed hair has approached us in the car park with a story about how she needs R100 for petrol or that her keys are locked in her car and she needs money... Tonight, the very same woman, carrying a child, tried to pickpocket my girlfriend by bumping into her from behind. Only once we noticed what she was up to, was she no where to be seen. My advice is to enjoy the waterfront but be careful (NOT PARANOID) about strange people that may come up to you. Be careful in the car park as well as near the entrance of the building. Otherwise, have fun and enjoy the wonderful restaurants, views and street performances that take place!
Commercial, tacky Mall. I don't know if we missed something but we thought the V & A waterfront was tacky, food orientated and touristy. Must betterlaces tone in Cape Town than this.

A Good Location for Relaxation. An ideal spot to relax and learn about Cape Town's interesting history. Many historical sites and many good reasonably priced restaurants. Many stores - most tourist orientated, but some better stores within the mall. Seal watching, boat tours of the harbour and trips to Robben Is., where Nelson Mandela was incarcerated some of the many things to do.

Nice shopping. Nice place, great shopping experience, you can get everything you need from here and they have a great variety of shops here. The food restaurants is also great and there are plenty to choose from. Along the waters edge is always some kind of entertainment so go have a look what's there. Great little stalls outside too.

Great shopping and food. Every brand and chain you want is in the V&A. It's a really nice air conditioned centre where you can shop till you drop. The restaurants are really good and reasonable bearing in mind the location. From the V&A you get the boat to Roben Island which is definitely worth a day trip. The sealift centre is also here so a great place for kids and to see the Kelp farm they cultivate. A great couple of hours spent. Penguins stink though.The South African Nobel peace prize winners statues are also here. A couple of minutes is enough to see them but netherless worth a look.

Great place to be. The waterfront is always a great place to be with very long operating hours. It has virtually everything from shopping to entertainment, and the 3D cinemas are wonderful. The parking, though it can get full during the peak holiday seasons, its still very spacious and well managed. It is closer to other great cape town locations and surbubs such as Table Mountain, Sea Point, Clifton & Camps Bay beaches, the harbour, great world renowned hotels etc.

Lovely day!. The Waterfront is the place to be if you like shopping, eating, entertainment and people watching! The fish is excellent! We were able to enjoy a perfectly cooked hake dinner while watching seals and boats in the harbor. Perfect day!

A great day out. If you like shopping and eating this is the place to go. Shops from range from the designer store to the every day with many having an African slant. Restaurants are from full service to fast food. Try a boat ride, listen to the live music or just sit and take it all in. Something for everyone

busy busy. have done shopping, been for meals and to some of the pubs. always too busy for me, no parking, in ct atthe moment and its the last place i would want to go. if you been once other better places to go and see

Food, fun, well being!. Its rare to find the combination of all three one stop but that's what the Waterfront has to offer! Entering the beautiful waterfront, you'll see the stunning aquarium to your right where you get to explore and learn. Right next to it affectionately known as the Blue Shed, stop off for an incredible massage or something to enhance your spiritual development. Entering the blue shed, you will experience a calm energy, spiritual tunes and uplifting incense combined with unique art and gifts to help sustain surrounding communities. Book a trip to tour Cape Town for the day using the Waterfront as a base or spend the day embracing the rich cultures from around Africa. Entertaining dancers, fire performers or African music, tantalizing tastes from all around the world.watch the sunset or take a sunset cruise as you're entertained by the funny crew. Not enough time? Take a tour of the harbour, just 30 minutes but worth every cent.Watch the seals play in the ocean or shop till you've had enough. Time flies here, so you may need to come back for more and more!

Great Hotel. We stayed here 3 nights in December, 2012. The food and selection at the breakfast buffet (included in the price) was fantastic, the staff very polite & helpful, the Wi-Fi was free and worked from the room and the hotel location was perfect. The rooms are spacious, clean and well laid out. It's on the waterfront, right next to shops, amusement with live bands and a large shopping mall. All of the main attractions in Capetown are minutes away by car. We would definitely stay here again.

Good cages, bars and live music. Yes the V&A is very touristy but push that aside and you can benefit from the upsides: great cafes, bars and live music. We particularly enjoyed the marimba bands and choirs.

Lots to see and do. My fiancé and I spent quite a bit of time here while in Cape Town. There are fantastic places to eat and drink and watch the world go by. Fantastic views at sunset. Lots of shops and entertainment.

If you like tourist zones. Just like the inner harbor in Baltimore, Pier 39 in San Francisco and many other planned tourist malls. This one is nice, lots of restaurants and shopping and more shopping. There is a local craft mall up near the entrance that is a little different. We were on business and ended up here for most dinners: all were ok, not great. However, the pricing was quite reasonable so it was not so annoying to have an average meal for an average price. The fun is in being around swarms of people and the place feels lively and there are bands playing and other street entertainers. Most restaurants had exotic meats so it was fun to eat Kudu or impala. Even the wine was reasonable. So it is worth the visit.

It is what it is. Seriously nothing special. Ok so there is more that needs to be said, but I really am battling to find anything interesting to say. It is an overpriced shopping centre for goodness sake!

Great Place to Visit While in Cape Town!. The V&A Waterfront was great! It was about a 10-15 min walk from my hotel (Protea North Wharf) I had the opportunity to visit several times. There are so many shops and restaurants there so you can spend hours there and not get bored! It's definitely a must do when you are in Cape Town.

A must visit. This place is worth a visit. Great place for souvenier shopping. During our stay there was live music. You have a good view of the Table Mountain here. After shopping, you can sit down, relax and have some drinks.

Great Shopping. The V&A Waterfront is a great place for shopping, dining at restaurants or just enjoying drinks at the pier. If you've got nothing to do in Cape Town you should pay this place a visit. It's great to end the day with. It's got souvenirs, crafts, clothes, outdoor gear, etc.... It's also pretty convenient to get a taxi right outside the mall.

Better with kids now. They have done some renovations this past winter, and wow, great job. There are now actually some funs for kids. (Free fun). 2 new playgrounds have been installed. (Just watch the kids; the playgrounds are a bit dangerous, for a few reasons. They seem to be falling apart already. Great fun in the water fountain (take extra dry clothing if your child likes playing in the water). Its fun and great way to cool down. We also went on the big wheel that was lots of fun, as our kids were still under 4 and therefore free.Great new food shops and the Market are opening December. Should be lovely to go and eat your way to the waters edge.Great family day, without spending a fortune. Now there are more healthy options. Don’t forget there is a Pick and Pay for picnic snacks. Great day out.

Best place in Cape Town. The V&A Waterfront is full of tourist but it is also a really nice. There are loads of restaurants here, many shops and stalls and it is also from here the boat to Robben Island sails from and one of the stops of the Hop on, hop off bus. The Red Shed Craft Market have the more expensive art and craft, while if you are into traditional curios you should visit the Blue Shed Craft Market. Actually the curios here are among the best in South Africa. I didn't know that at the time, but after 3 weeks in SA I can definately say so. The Blue Shed Craft Market also houses alternative treatments etc, so if you want a massage or a tarot card reading this is the place. The Waterfront is also heavy with security, so feeling very safe, though you should still be cautious not ending up at the far edges (like the aquarium) alone after darkness.

Best Shopping In Cape Town. Lots of shopping, dining and people watching. Africa is not just remote, desolate, arid wasteland, it also has world class cities and corresponding shopping venues. Something for everyone, but not for everyone.

real tourist place but. great selection of shops and restaurants, singers and bands, gest very busy but easy to park (which seemed secure) and on red hop on hop off route. Loads of tourists BUT also loads of locals, school parties etc, good place to spend a day or afternoon and then meal
Must Visit. Water front. A must in cape town. Departure for several adventures to the see. Many excelent restaurants. Everybody goes there. Don´t miss it.
A good venue. Always a good place to visit, especially in the evening when other places are limited.A nice 'alive' atmosphere and well managed.

Excellent vibe, but high prices.. The shops do close rather early, like 8pm. Perhaps I come from a country whose shops only closes at 10pm, so that came off as a little boring. The restaurants outside however, do open till late.Good to relax and chill out with some friends, watch the tab tho, some prices can be really over the top! Good for taking pictures too!

Lots to See, Great Places to Shop and Eat. Great place to visit. Several areas had outdoor entertainment. Great places to just have a glass of wine or a beer. Be sure to try to South African selections. There is a huge mall if you like to shop.

Shopping and Dining...my favourite place in Cape Town...... I love Cape Town and each time that I am in Cape Town, I always go to V&A Waterfront...I went shopping, posting my Postcard home, see the movie, visit Aquarium next door.., get a massage at the Handicraft Market next door... and Fine Dining @Quay Four Restaurant...After dinner, you can visit the bars with live music.....It is a place to visit once you are in Cape Town...

One of my favorite. One of my favorite spot in Cape Town. Great restraunts, 2 nice shopping malls,shops,Caffe's..etc
It is a perfect spot to enjoy the view of Table Mountain. Try Quay 4 Rest. for wonderful seafood. Try to sit at outside. There is live music at the weekends. Recommended!
Nice location and great breakfast. We were satisfied with our hotel. Room was spacious and modern. Location was great. I especially enjoyed breakfast buffet with great healthy choices.

Great shopping experience even for us Guys!. We were told not to miss the waterfront while we were in Cape Town. They were right, even for me some one who is shopped out! Don't miss the African Outpost, really great tribal goods. The first floor has all the cheap tourist take to your friends gifts but go upstairs to the upper levels and you will find some interesting pieces to take home!

Safe and fantastic. Plenty of waterfronts out there-this one ranks very high for any country. Water activities are varied. Plenty of fine restaurants with great views. Shops with all kinds of neat stuff. Attached is an ultra modern mall with hundreds of stores.

Shopping and dining in a mall environment. Good shopping and dining options and if you are looking for expensive souvenirs, there are many choices. We prefer to experience the authentic parts of town and while Cape Townians are very proud of this mall, it is just another mall and a quick visit was enough for us. If you are looking for awesome deals on souvenirs and South African crafts from the people who really make them, visit Green Market Square instead and bargain to your hearts content while benefitting the folks who really make the crafts.

THE ONLY PLACE TO STAY IN CAPE TOWN. After many visits to all areas IAnd hotels in Cape Town I would like to suggest to all tourists. Stay in the Waterfront!It is very safe to walk about day and night. Lovely restaurants and eateries within walking reach.

Great Place to spend Time. It was very safe walking around the waterfront and there were many places to eat and drink and the mall was within walking distance which has groceries and wine to take back to the hotel.The restaurants are expensive, but that should be expected.
Soooo expensive!. The Waterfront is one of the most beautiful places in Cape town, but it designed only for tourists, the average South Africans, cannot enjoy the mall without paying a fortune!
Great for shopping and some good restaurants. Lots of shops if that is your thing, and some lovely restaurants with great views. however more pricey due to location

NB NOT Victoria & Albert!. Always a great place to visit. Huge selection of shops, including designer fashion, fantastic array of restaurants and very often outside musical entertainment. Large cinema complex; boat rides around the harbour; or just sit and people watch. Boats to Robben Island leave from here; the Aquarium is close by; and it's the start and finish point for the tourist bus red and blue routes.
Shopperand Diners Paradise. This is where you have everything under one roof. Fashion, fashionable restaurants cinemas and plenty of parking.

Vibrant and safe. There are several shops, a huge mall, and restaurants for all tastes. The walk is also very pleasant but not too spectacular, there is a working shipyard there anyway. But it gives a very good taste of all that makes up Cape Town and its residents.
Great for Shopping. Great place to spend the day with fiance! Good restaurants and shops. Enjoy the Waterfront every time I visit.

Great spot for a drink, music and some shopping. During my week long stay in Cape Town we visited here several times. Along the wharf are several delicious restaurants with everything from Greek food, to fresh seafood, to Tapas, to upscale dining with a phenominal choice of cognacs. With that being said, teh prices were higher than other areas, but nothing unreasonable. It was about US $10-20 a meal. We did go shopping here and found some good buys but I also cautionon that, the prices on some items were much higher than you would get in other parts of town. Everytime we went they had perfomers on both ends of the street singing and dancing which was great. We had a friend buy a tanzanite ring at the jewlery store and a few other things. There is also a ferris wheel so you can ride and look over the city and they offer several boart cruises from here. You can also purchase shark diving packages, helicopter rides, and essentially anything else you might be interested in.

Waterfront - Cape Town. Cruise around Cape Town’s historic harbour aboard a cruise vessel. You will have fantastic views of Robben Island, Table Mountain and see the harbour in action.You will even the seals joining in the fun. There are fantastic shops to visit, A Red Shed Craft Market and the famous Aquarium. A visit to Cape Town is not complete without a visit to the Waterfront.
Nice place. Very nice place to visit, not as big as expected and very empty, no crowd, but very nice, especially comparing to port area. Worth to see in Cape Twon.

A taste of History and Modernism. A working harbour.. This venue , the most popular in South Africa, has everything you need for entertainment. Although prices are focussed non the tourist, it is affordable to most.

Way too touristy with so many other great things around. This area is just awful if you really want to see Cape Town. You are surrounded by so many beautiful things in Cape Town....if you go there do it for a beer before the football At Mitchell's or to jump a ferry to Robben Island or to see the seals. It's like Circular Quay in Sydney....over priced and a lot of great things to see not far away.

Fantastic. I love this place. SO many sections - so many things to do. Shopping is PHENOMINAL . Restaurants are stunning - love prima piatti, t5he tapas bar, willoughby and even the good old spur is great. I do my grocery shopping there at Woolworths. It is incredible. I cook unsual dishes and can find whatever I want there. Truly amazing. The clothes section will eventually drive me broke. Love it.

So many shops and so little luggage allowance!. What a place full of so much to do and places to eat. There are so many things to do here and we have tended to gravitate here several times after doing other activities to either eat or shop. The range and variety of shops is wide catering fo all tastes. It is a clean, secure and vibrant place.

Overlooking the Cape Bay with a global shopping menu. Well designed, easy to navigate, overlooking the old Cape harbour, a variety of five to one star restaurants, excellent hotels, cinemas for the masses or for the highbrow. Entertainment on the harbour front, sea trips, launch site for Robben island.

Highly Recommended. Some people may might say that this is not be the 'real' South Africa but it has a reality all its own. I should add there that South Africa has some of the largest and most amazing shopping malls I have every seen and that is saying something considering I come from the United States. Returning to the Victoria and Alfred Waterfront, like many other cities with aging port facilities, Cape Town redeveloped its port, or at least the older portions, into a shopping and entertainment district. The result is a first class entertainment and shopping area, complete with hotels and a world class shopping mall which is open late at night and safe for all concerned. I know it sounds like a something for tourists but believe me that is not the case. Locals both white and black shop and eat there. I suspect it has helped to kill the central business district of Cape Town but again this is not unique to South Africa. Tourists and locals alike like safe and entertaining area in which to shop and enjoy themselves. I should add you also get really good view of Table Top Mountain from the V&A. Enjoy it. We did.

Always a pleasure. No trip to Cape Town is complete without a visit to this shopping mecca. You can find amazing cosmopolitan designer stores and the more basic retail ones and everything in between. Even if you don't have much money to spend, you can take in the wonderful views of Table Mountain, and the harbor area. Nestled right on the water, a boat trip or helicopter flip is well worth it although a little pricey. You could spend a whole day here and not see everything! A good excuse to make another visit. Parking is available at a fair price and many tours depart from the waterfront year-round.

Eat, shop, relax. Great place in the heart of the waterfront. Great food variety is plentiful with something for everyone and all budgets. Walk off your meal with a stroll thru the mall then grab some ice cream for dessert on the way out. Local beer bar at the end of the mall for some late night music enjoyment. Overall a great place to visit. We spent a couple of days in Capetown before and after our cruise and stopped hung out here for a very enjoyable stay.

The revival of Cape Town. When tourists think of Cape Town, they think of Table Mountain and of the Victoria & Alfred Waterfront. To think that this area was run down not that long ago is amazing. Now, it is such a vibrant and interesting area, with all sorts of shops, restaurants and other attractions packed along the waterside. A real highlight of the “new” Cape Town and a must see.
A full day. Plan to spend your day there, shopping, dining, wine tasting, spa, and you can spend the night there in any of the bars. A very nice place to go

More than just a shopping mall. Victoria and Alfred Waterfront really needs a full day to have a good look around and consists of numerous buildings on the waterfront at Capetown. It's best to pace yourself by breaking up your shopping to stop for a meal, a beer at one of the numerous bars, a wine tasting at Carolines Fine Wine Cellar, a massage, or just laze in the sun for a half hour or so outside of people-watching. While the shops are not necessarily the least expensive in Capetown you will find such a variety of stores and products no shopping experience there will leave you disappointed. There is plenty of parking in the numerous carparks around the shopping centre and you are very close to many other experiences such as dining at numerous excellent restaurants. Well worth doing.

great for shopping and dining. We really enjoyed visiting this large Western style mall in Cape Town in the evenings. Many neighborhood in Cape Town are not considered safe for tourists to walk around at night, so we spent several evenings at this mall. There are plenty of shops with African crafts and hand-made items for souvenirs as well as the usual clothing shops that you could find anywhere. There are also a large selection of restaurants from very luxurious to relatively inexpensive, featuring everything from local Cape cuisine to Italian, Indian, seafood, and more. It was also easy to get a taxi from here to go back to our hotel, which was in a different part of town.

a lovely facility for Cape Town. Working harbour, homes overlooking it all. good shopping facility. Lovely to be able to go out on the boats and observe the area around the bay. Great place for visitors!

Culture, shopping, food and entertainment!. A great place to visit for shopping, everyday food to luxury goods! A great selection of restaurants with various cuisines! I think it's great rain or shine!I took the harbour boat trip too, lovely to see the fantastic landscape of Table Mountain from the sea. You have easy access to the Two Oceans Aquarium, trips to Robben Island and so many more boat trips! There's a number a good quality gift shops and the street performances gave a little taste of culture!

Great spot for enjoying day and night. The Waterfront is by far one of the best spot to spend your free time in Cape Town. Excellent restaurants, cultural attractions as well as a huge shopping centre will help you to enjoy the day. Always crowded at any hour of the day, the Waterfront will share with you an incredible view of table mountain!

Tourist's Paradise. The V&A Waterfront, or just "Waterfront" as locals refer to it, is shopping mecca, as it boasts many high end stores like Versace, Jimmy Choo, as well as the more affordable chain of stores (Woolworths, Edgars, etc) The harbor is just a few footsteps outside where you can have the most authentic fish and chips, eat some ice cream while walking around taking in the beautiful views, take a boat ride at any time of the morning/afternoon. This is also the place where the Robben Island cruises depart from.

shop till you drop. At the Waterfront:shop till you drop-walk till your knee lock and then go eat on a nice seat...That is how I experienced the Waterfront with its facilities. All kinds of posibilities.from handcraft to electronics and about 400 shops. Good food and I do not forget the icecream ! Delicious. And all over the place clean and safe.Each time I visit Cape TownI must spend a Whle day at the Waterfront with its open sky theatre with free performences for you to enjoy with. the Table Mountain in front of you in the background.eefrom.

Great place to start a trip in Cape Town. V&A is very central, stunning setting of Table Mountain and great place to start exploring Cape Town by bus or bicycle. Safe place to use ATM's. Wide variety of excellent restaurants
An essential destination for Cape Town visitors. If you missed buying that one item on your South Africa Tour, you will almost certainly find it here. Outstanding restaurants and shopping.
lovely. and wonderfully convenient to our hotel - we could exchange money, shop for forgotten necessities, add prepaid minutes to our cell phones, and eat - all within walking distance of our hotel.

Great place to visit for half a day. A lovely place with good restaurants, interesting monuments and a lovely marina (if you're lucky you may see seals there like we did). We enjoyed walking around and seeing traditional African dance groups busking. The shops are good too with plenty of traditional African gifts to buy. Worth a trip!

Wonderful. Being from Cape Town I love visiting the waterfront and am fortunate that I work close enough to pop in over a lunch time or after work when I feel like some retail therapy or a glass of wine. The waterfront is huge with a variety of attractions; from an amazing mall with fantastic shops to wonderful restaurants, boat trips, an aquarium, movies, etc. Go and enjoy, it is worth it!

V & A Waterfront visit. The V&A Waterfront is an absolute must during a visit to Cape Town. We did however find that the traffic into this area and finding parking can be quite a challenge during peak season. We had to park very far away from the closest attractions and had to walk far distances with small children (toddlers) - be prepared and where comfortable shoes !!!Although the cues to attractions like the Oceanarium was quite long the ticket sales when smoothly and the wait was reasonable. The Oceanarium is absolutely worth it, we spent most of our day there and basically went for late lunch at the Spur and went home (after finding the car of course).
Amazing. This place was amazing, probably spent every day of the holiday here. There was lots of amazing food places and the shops were also pretty good
One of the best waterfronts in the world. Everything there, views, restaurants, shopping, boat trips and safety! dont miss out a few days at least to enjoy the Waterfront in Cape Town!

waterfront-delight. The victoria+Alfred waterfront never dissapoints when it comes to entertainment ,whether its cruising on a yacht during daytime or dining at night with the sea breaking so close nearby.Live music is allways in the air,and cultures collide in colour-pride through tradisional dances in the open-air arena.Here is entertainment from the live shows at the TWO OCEANS-akwarium,to a 9-hole putt-putt course in a cave,to museums and elegant shopping-stores,all within walking -distance from the red-bus stop which takes you to the city-centre,and there is even a water-taxi that brings you to the steps of KIKS-center.Its all here,for your enjoyment!
always something to do. or to buy in a shop, finish with a cocktail and enjoying atmosphere and people
Worth a visit. We stayed in Cape Town for 3 days and visited the waterfront each day. Great for shopping, beautiful setting and some really good restaurants. Don't miss it!

a working waterfront experience. if you want to experience the retail and tourist side of Cape Town, there is no better place to stretch your C card than the V&A. You can shop and eat to your hearts content...all with a view!
nice.... great shopping! sad that the sale period was over during the time that we were there
Shops. My wife loved this location for the markets and the Resturants.However if you have to choose about spending a day here or the wineries! then Choose the Wineries.
Excellent hangout. You want to shop, go on a sunset cruise, enjoy a quiet dinner, enjoy drinks with live music... its all here!
great experience. great tourist attraction good resturants excellents shops for everyone
The waterfront. Quite touristy but worth a quick visit. Many tour companies trying to sell you their experience. Many restaurants and shops. We did not eat at the waterfront.

Not a tourist attraction but must be seen. The W&A is a big shopping center right in the harbor of Cape Town, many shops and restaurants.
Perfect for a rainy day or a lazy morning, I will not waist a sunset here!

this is called serenity. There is something very calming about the waterfront that i can't understand. It doesn't look different than any other harbour with a shopping center but there is something very relaxing about the place that you end up wanting to go there everyday.
Safe and many restaurants & shopping. Totally safe area of CT - well-patrolled. many restaurants and good shopping for those not from USA/Europe.
Must see, but has become very commercial.. Natural setting and view are great. Wide variety of stores. Can be very crowded.
Beautiful views. Beautiful views, wide variety of restaurants and pubs to pick from but generally quite pricey

Nice place to shop, dine and enjoy the evening. A very nice, clean and safe harbour. You can see the ships, big and small, and even the seals. This is the place to enjoy the afternoon, watching the sun sets on Table Mountain, buy souvenirs, having a good food, shops and enjoy the evening watching the street performers. Some of them performed good music and dance, giving you an atmosphere of African culture. A must visit place in Cape Town, beside the Mountain..
I really like the area. I really liked to walk around, go dinning, go shopping, admire the port,.....

Touristy but must see. Well developed Victorian waterfront with new shopping mall. Expensive compared to rest of town but has great atmosphere at night time. Must see at least once and enjoy the sun setting over Table Mountain.

Shops, Boating, Restaurants, Buskers, Touts. This waterfront area is clean and safe. It offers a nice walk through the active waterfront. There are a few good restaurants here that are pricey and recommended. There are fast food places and artificial eateries that are available too. There are many place to sit and drink while watching the sun cast its rays on Table Mountain. Many shops of souvenirs, collectors items, and junk abound this waterfront. There is carnival food in stalls and buskers sing or play away for your loose change. There are also beggars and touts looking to get anything they can from you. Public bathrooms are available as well as a taxi stand in the circle next to the eye/wheel.I recommend this area for an evening walk but not the whole night. Walk through, have dinner or a drink and resume Cape Town.

The requisite tourist stop. The V & A Waterfront is a tourist area and makes no secret of it. It's a fun place to shop and eat or just to stop by the working dry docks and check out how ship maintenance is really done. It is probably the best shopping spot in Western cape if you are looking for a high end shopping experience. It certainly beats the local places such as Canal Walk. It's a typical waterfront tourist hub, its actual design based on Darling Harbour in Sydney, Australia. It is what it is - a place to shop and eat and take pictures. Just do it and enjoy : ))
Excellent restaurants and shops. We had several delicious meals her however it has to be noted that the prices are a little higher than else where. There are also quality shops aimed at the tourist,
Tourist trap, but a few good restaurants. This place is really a tourist trap, but there's the harbour and a few good restaurants.

Very Active Waterfront. Many cities around the world have developed their waterfront into a tourist attraction. Some have succeeded, some not. This is one of the better ones and works very well. However, I was disappointed to find that teh food court was closed for the 'winter'. I have never heard of anything like this. The place was packed and they have the nerve to close the food court. I was looking forward to a falafal lunch at Anat (one of the best falafels this side of NYC). There was not much else to eat since most places were focused on dead animals and fish.

Just another massive mall. As malls go, it's rather nice because it's situated in a working port, but really, there's so much more to see in Cape Town than a massive block of concrete and glass, however attractive.
Commercial Rubbish. A commercial wasteland of plastic chain restaurants and bars pretending to be cool and indy
Good Restaurants. Great restaurant options (Harbor House!) with outdoor seating, but didn't think it was anything special. Just a big mall.
Entertaining area. I enjoyed the waterfront but it is like many other waterfront areas, nothing unique. It does have many wonderful restaurants. I think every place I ate at there was excellent.
A obligatory stop, but nothing more. This is just a part of the USA in SA, nothing special to see here.
Very pretty.... Quite a lot of shops and restaurants and a pretty harbour.

beautiful waterfront in a beautiful city. at first sight you could be anywhere (in Boston, in London, in San Francisco) but then you have the seals in the harbour and the Table Mountain at the back, and you realise you are in a unique place. Restaurants fantastic - spoiled for choice.
Nice but touristy. I'd rather be at the Cape point. There is a nice market if you feel like shopping.
Great choice of entertainment/restaurents. Loads to see, do, eat, listen too and buy. We ate at a few restaurants, and had gorgeous meals every time. Recommend it hugely
Great atmosphere. While many of the shops are on the expensive side,there are the usual South African shops too,and a couple of steps and you hear the seagulls and smell the sea
Loved it. What a great place, i could sit here sipping wine and eating all day long. So many places to eat and drink here and such a lively place. Great views of table mountain.
nice shopping. nice shopping inside the mall and along the waterfront. variety of different restaurants ranging from mid price and casual dining to fine dining.

perfect place to chill. We love visiting here because there are such wonderful places to eat and you can celeb spot in the shopping mall, we saw Gary Barlow!!! The views are amazing and it seems like you see table mountain at every turn. We spent a few days here buying presents, going to the cinema, catching a boat to robben island and visting as many restaurants as we could from greek to italian to wonderful seafood. A real must if you visit Cape Town and is always at the top of our list.
Tourist mecca. This is a huge retail complex with shops and restaurants. Surprisingly, the restaurants are very good - try Harbour House and Karibu.
Wonderful. Great dining and shopping, for all kinds of people from takeaways to fine dining. From basic weekly shopping to more upmarket and designer stores. On the harbour and close to the aquarium.

Tourist Hotspot. Typical tourist hotspot - lots of shops and restaurants. It was very busy with lots going on. You can see seals in the harbour too. I was not that impressed - when it is compared to what else I did in the Cape Town area.

A must visit area. A must visit. Beautiful area with lots of shops in the center and then shops with African crafters. Capetown reminded us much of San Francisco and this was the wharf area only better.

Good Hotel. We decided last time we were in CapeTown we would stay here and have not regreted the decision. We arrived with a car and were directed to a parking spot at the front door! Our room overloooked the water and had a ver y good king bed. Breakfast was not limited to the menu and was good. The staff on the front desk are excellent. We had invaluable help from Luci on the tour desk. Our stay was memorable because of the good care we were give by all the staff.
Huge. This is a great place to just wander around even if you are not shopping. There are restaurants and outdoor entertainment. We enjoyed eating outside in the wonderful Cape Town weather.

Not one for Malls but......... Not really into malls but coming from a smaller town in Natal I found it really interesting to get the full picture and get expert advise. An example would be the Nespresso shop, they only sell the coffee machines and coffee capsules but we had a very helpful assistant, Craig, show us the machines and made us a cup of coffee and explained the range of coffees to us. I had looked at the machine before in a smaller mall that had it at the back of a chain store and got no advise on how it worked.The views around the mall are spectacular. I don't think we got to see a tenth of the shops but certainly spent ten times what I would normally in a mall.

Go Visit!. Waterfront is a fantastic place to visit lovely restaurants while enjoying a truly spectacular view. It's just so, so beautiful. You must do it. Ideally, find a seat that allows you to face Table Mountain. :-)
awesome!!!. quaint and pretty and quite romanticmany dining options- (halaal) fast food to luxury formal diningmultiple activities:hellicopter rides, numerous types of boat rides, picturesque scenery

Shopping, dining and entertaining. This place has everything, it is entertaining, especially on weekends. You can shop everyday of the week till 7-8 in the evening, in all the fancy shops, there is something for everyone. And you can eat at any of the fancy and very tasty restaurants, they have something for whatever you feel like eating.

Great experience. Spending time in the area on a beautiful day was fantastice. Dining at the Ocean Basket was excellent. We also enjoyed seeing the statues of the Nobel prize winners. The shopping area was very nice.
You could spend days on end there. Because of it's popularity with the tourists it is very busy and you can easily get lost but there is lots to do with good restaurants and interesting shops.

Spent almost every evening here. You can't beat the exceptional restaurants here! Everything is well maintained and you feel safe. The street entertainment is incredible and the quality is very high. I will be staying in a hotel on the Waterfront on my next visit.

Lovely bayside promenade. A timeless way of eating the fab local fare while sitting on the colourful waterfront. Very scenic and loads of water sport activities on offer locally to digest those exotic ostrich steaks or full bodied outh African wines..

Lively Place. It is a safe, lively place with lot of restaurants at the waterfront. We visited Italian/Sushi/Indian restaurants and did a little shopping for toiletries at the grocery store in the small shopping mall. There are some smaller restaurants in the mall for budget travelers. Having a free shuttle service from our hotel to the Waterfront was nice. For the Robben Island trip, walk to the right along the water's edge, cross the bridge and you are at the building housing the box office and the ferry dock. The last ferry from there departs at 6:00 PM and the island is deserted after that. Online prior ticket purchase for a designated time slot is the best option for the Robben Island trip.

great buzz. Must do in Capetown. This is a must do in Capetown.. There is a great buzz with musicians, mime, jugglers and all kinds of buskers. It is always crowded so it is very important to watch your personal belongings carefully. There are great restaurants all full to capacity at night but pleasant to sit and have a coffee during the day and watch the tourists strolling by. There is a very big shopping mall. The Red shed is a great place for South African made craft souvenirs. There are boat trips running to Robben Island or around the harbour.
Superb!!!!. Superb place to hang out! nice views, and the wheel was also good. historic and very well managed and maintained till todate!

nice walk. there are many musicians that play in different parts & alternate in specific locations. Had one group of old guys playing Tennessee waltz & 7 young men drumming, singing & doing native dance. A lot of restaurants for all tastes & many w/ great view of harbor & ships & sailboats.

V&A a Must Do. Spend half a day or more walking thought the V&A waterfront, with the magnificent back drop of Table mountain. Great shopping with the best views in the world. Food, fun, a must do in Cape Town.

Shop 'till you drop. The Cape Town waterfront is great, so much to see and do, including a huge indoor shopping mall, statues of famous South Africans, including Desmond Tutu, and of course, Nelson Mandela; don't forget to take a boat ride over to Robben Island where Mandela spent 27 years as a political prisoner. Fascinating.

One word.. FANTASTIC. We loved it and went back again and again. The atmosphere was buzzing. Great shops,including the craft markets and great bars and eateries.Security is very good here so you can just relax and enjoy.
A nice spot..... Enjoyed our time here on a trip in 2004. Would recommend as a nice place to spend an afternoon.

A must!. From cinemas, supermarkets, banks, post office, shops galore ... restaurants galore ... how wonderful to find this all under one superb roof! And more ..... yes, you'll need lots of time to enjoy this place - it caters for everyone's needs and requirements in a tastefully thought out design. A real must!

A must visit. Its out of Africa......The eating place.... let alone shopping...I liked it there because i bumped into my two friends that l last saw a long time ago one from England and the other one from Kenya. Amazing we were all on holiday.

A bit like SF Fishermans' Wharf. Crowded scene - lots of restaurants and shops and a mall. Music and acts performing throughout. A bit too much for my taste but a thriving tourist venue in a lovely setting.
Excellent. Amazing place good shops and awsome food. Robben Island is a must.

Give yourself plenty of time to explore. Give yourself plenty of time - and money - to spend here. There are lots of interesting shops & restaurants, so take your time. Don't just use it as the departure point to Robben Island. The real downside if you have hired a car is finding somewhere to park.

Beautiful. The waterfront is one of the best places to be in Cape town. The Crafts exhibition was great. There are a lot of places around for buying souvenirs for your loved ones! We also made reservations for our Shark Diving trip from around one of the places there.
Tourist paradise. Here's a tourist shopping paradise, it's one of the largest shopping centres, with restaurants and a few side attractions in the Waterfront. Not to be missed.

tourist attraction so be a tourist. really enjoyed the marketplace with crafts in big wharehouse.
The Fish and chips is very very good at the restaurant on the wharf. You can walk in leisure. Next time will rent a bicycle and take the path down the beaches.

outstanding people-watching!. Don't take on the V&A waterfront if you're in a hurry, because you'll want to spend several hours wandering around and taking in the energy. Grab a coffee, lunch, or gelato, and watch the world wander by. It's a delightful place loiter and browse, and the street entertainment rivals the Boston Common, Sydney's Circular Quay, and Key West's pier at sunset.
Very nice. Perfect to have lunch on a sunny sunday. Lots of gret restaurants, nice shops and other attractions! Have to go!
Great!. The mall here is a little dated, honestly, but there's such a good variety of restaurants and little shops around it, that the dated mall is kind of the last thing that matters.

Fine sightseeing. Loved the sculpture, enjoyed the shopping, like how Cape Town capitalizes on its waterfront. It's a tourist-friendly city with lots to do outside, from boat rides to a visit to Robben Island, the former maximum-security prison that housed Nelson Mandela under apartheid.
Worth a Visit. Just a bit commercialised but a pleasure to walk around early evening and plenty of places to eat. I remember the harbour back in the 80's when there was just one fish restaurant!!

Shopping. The ammount of great resteraunts.
A lot of the shops were of no interest to a traveller. Items are not cheap, same sort of prices as in the UK.
Great entertainment.
Brilliant. It was so great being there, we went almost everyday! Great restaurants and entertainment!
Too commercial. Good place to meet and have a quick lunch, otherwise, over priced and over rated
Interesting.... Really enjoyable to visit. But why Alfred? It's Albert surely!
Always good for sightseeing. The V & A is always good for sightseeing and showing my European colleagues a taste of Cape Town!
lots to do. did not think shopping anything special but there is a wide variety of restaurants, some have life entertainment. Can easily spend a day or two wandering around

Fun at the waterfront. The waterfront is a fun place to spend a few hours - mostly for shopping, eating and relaxing. One can also ride the big wheel which gives you a nice view of Table Mountain and the surrounding area.
Great spot for dinner and people watching. Lots of shops, places to eat, grab a drink and watch all of the people and boats moving around.
The place to be in Cape Town. We spent lots of time here. Our hotel was at the Waterfront, this is the best location

Touristy but gott go... It's the place to go. For a single female it was the only place I went for meals in the evening. Its safe with taxi's trained in tourism. Take care when & where you choose a taxi.....!
There are many bar's, restaurants and activities. Reminded me of Clarke Quay in SIN or The Rocks in Syd.

Fantastic waterfront. This waterfront must not be missed. Just sit have a coffee and let the world go by, Plenty of good eating places, any time of day this part of Cape Town is a must and so safe to walk around in

Tourist Destination. The main attraction here is an upscale mall and restaurants. One should see this, and it is a particularly nice spot to eat on the water..but also realize that this is Cape Town for the rich/tourists..

nice area to stroll. an interesting place to stroll both in the day and evening.
lively with lots of eateries and a large shopping mall.
a very interesting covered craft market with a wide range of traditional and unique items at reasonable prices.
All you need for shopping. The Waterfront offers all one could need for shopping and for all budgets.
Nice area. Nice shops and restaurants, even if very touristy.

lots to do. free parking. i visited here several times dring my trip to SA.
it is very big, with lots of shops. there is a large variety of stores.
lots of restaurants and bars.
lovely views of the boats also

Always great for drinks with friends. The Waterfront remains one of my most favourite places to visit. The vibe is great, the place is clean and there is such a huge selection of places to eat, you can't go wrong. I would go more often if I could. And if you are not from Cape Town and just visiting, it is definitely worth going to see!

Vibrant. The Waterfront is so alive. We dined in various styles from fish and chips to gourmet meals and they were all great. One evening watched an advert being filmed whilst sitting outside a restaurant having dinner!

Great area for lunch. We went to ocean basket for lunch. Its a chain there, but very yummy. We ate at two other more expensive places and we liked this one better. Get the platter for one and enjoy the view!
Shopping. A great location with good range of retail outlets and big range of attractions and eateries. Not to be missed.

Worth a look. The Waterfront is pretty on a sunny day with views of Table Mountain, definitely worth a bit of a wander around but it is very touristy with lots of chain restaurants. The souvenirs on sale at the Waterfront are very expensive and the shopping centre itself is really average.

touristic waterfront. the place is very nice, with ships, wharf, mountains around, but it has became just a another big shopping center
Hoot Bay, 30 minutes to the south, is a much better place for "fishermen" feelings
A girl's first love "Shopping" :-).... I went crazy over the shops at the waterfront, if i had all the money in the world i would have bought all those clothing shops there hehehehe..
An Interesting Mix. The V and A waterfront is an interesting mix of typical items aimed at tourists and unique items from South Africa

So much to do. I love the V&A waterfront, its a great spot to find something to do, whether it be a spot of shopping, or a boat cruise around the harbour, or just a stroll around the harbour listening to the many great musicians playing in the walkways. My favourite is to pick one of the great restaurants over the waterfront and grab a bite to eat and a cocktail. You will be able to see seals swimming around and if you are lucky enough you may even spot dolphins in the harbour, its great. I would recommend Quay Four and the Harbour House roof top Sushi Restaurant, both great spots to grab a meal and great cocktails.
Lively place. Have lunch at Willoughbys -best Sushi I have ever tasted.

Everything in one!. I love the wharf! from the entrance where you see the best aquarium ever! to the artisans shed, to the foo, shopping and gorgeous mall the atmosphere is just relaxing, and you can end your night with a movie!would go back presto!
Not my favorite. Touristy and not an area I would elect to stay in. Preferred the city central.
Harbour living. Great harbour atmosphere and restaurants against the back drop of Table Mountain, with one of the best aquariums in the world

A good introduction to south african artisans' work. Perfect place to spend an afternoon , hearing the musicians and enjoying south african music and dances. There are a good variety of places to eat, and of course lots of shops. look for those which sell native sculptures and native artisans work . We founf beautiful fabrics , shirts and stationery.

A perfect place to spend hours shopping. Spent a few days around Cape Town seeing the sites and made several visits here to either shop or visit the food places. It has some great palces to spend some time shopping or visiting the attractions within the site. Well worth the time spent here.
Eaterys in Waterfront. Restaurants offer poor service and food quality and too expensive for value one receives

Best Shopping and eating...with stunning views!. Many shops, tourist and boutiques, Wonderful restaurants and Cinemas. Many outdoor restaurants with exquisite views of Table Mountain or the sea, So much to do and see, it is a joy walking around this area.

A must see in Cape Town. Take a ride on the ferris wheel at night to get a great view of the city and lights. Visit the craft market during the day for all kinds of handmade African art, jewelry, and crafts. Take a boat ride and see thensights from the water. There are many restaurants at the V&A - make reserevations ahead of time for the popular ones - especially during holiday times.
nice place to walk around. lots of shops and restaurants. It was very busy, but we enjoyed the energy

A nice addition to the Cape Town harbor area. The V & A waterfront area is crammed full of tourists and many things to do. If you take a tour of Robben Island you will depart and arrive from the pier. Nice place to get a bite, have a drink or people watch. Many tour operators offering a number of day trips. many shopping opportunities as well. Prices reflect the area. Treat yourself to a fantastic meal at Willoughby and Co. in the mall.

Shoppers paradise. Many shops, restuarants and cafe's which should satify most people. Lovely setting by the harbour which has plenty of pleasure boats offering a variety of trips. Be careful of the prices though..

The most beautiful harbour city in the world?. Cape Town is breathtakingly beautiful especially when viewed from the water. The waterfront is safe and secure for the tourist and although clearly not representative of the city as a whole, provides a wonderful base for exploring the region. Very easy to take tours of the harbour, Table Mountain, the wine regions and then enjoy plenty of eating options along with great nightlife.
its ok if you want somewhere to eat. possibly i had better expectations- dont get me wrong its nice but theres not a huge variety of anything there other than shops and restaurants.

A different side of Cape Town. I first visited the V&A 15 years ago - not much has changed! Still a great place to spend a few hours at the bars, cafes or shopping centres, or to get the ferry to Robben Island. A safe area in town, near to Green Point Stadium. Lots of musicians and performers too.
Shopaholic paradise. Wonderful place if you are a shopaholic and your friend is not. Loads to do cruises, in the cinema and live concerts if not busy shopping. Great for gifts!

Beautiful Place. Although very touristy, the V and A Waterfront is definitely a place to visit while in Cape Town. Over 5 days we visited at least 4 times. There are good restaurants, nice shops, an awesome mall and individual groups singing and dancing to entertain. You can also catch many boat tours and the ferry to Robben Island.
Everything you ever need and more... You can find everything there - interesting craft markets but the prices in the craft markets are slightly more than in the malls for the same product. !

Very commercial but stil fun to do. We did not expect that the Waterfront would be so modern. it's basically a very modern shopping mall with a lot of European brands, so kinda generic. However, the actual harbor has a lot of restaurants where you can have a nice meal outside at night. it is very touristy so not cheap!

Cool experience.. Everything here for the shopping queens. All types of shops for all types of people. Lots of very good restaurants, coffee houses and Ice cream palours. You could spent all day here just in the shops from brand names to the local shop. Very cool and the experience is well worth a visit. What ever you want from the V & A. Just for good measure there is some sort of entertainment just outside of the main entrance.

Cannot visit Capetown without seeing it.. Just so much to see and do, superb shops and eating places. Listening to all the different languages spoken by visitors from all over the world makes it a sort of magical place.

Great to Wander. We had a fantastic time just wandering around the waterfront and looking at all the shops and sights. We stopped for lunch at an outdoo patio and enjoyed a cold beer and some delicious pizza.

Everything Sparkles. Cape Town is a number one tourist destination. It starts right here on the waterfront, where gayly painted buildings, a retracting pedestrian bridge, double-decker carousel, smaller version of the London "Eye", brightly face-painted marimba and steel drum players, and fabulous food and beer at the pub in the old Ferryman's building, left us wanting more. Of course, it's also the wharf where you embark for Robben island, the World Heritage Site dedicated to Nelson Mandela and his fellow prisoners who spent decades imprisoned for their efforts to end apartheid. From the boat, the views of Table Mountain and the sea side of the city set against a miraculously blue sky are breathtaking. Our camera was clicking constantly. This is an all day event or more if you want to really shop in all the places which sell South African goods from the outrageously chic to good value locally made crafts, clothing and jewelry. Tickets for Robben island need to be purchased a couple of days in advance. The waterfront is also where you get the local double decker bus which takes you all around Capetown (the city with a mountain in the middle) for more days of incredible Cape Town sightseeing.

From Morning until Night its alive with a Vibe. The V & A Waterfront is of course built for tourists but has got to be one of the best entertainment venues anywhere in the world. It has loads of eating and drinking venues from budget to high class, sensational views of the ocean and mountain, you feel very secure because of great security in the area, prices are a little high but I suppose that is to pay for the great security, entertainment and great facilities there.
Meh. The Waterfront is nothing spectacular. It's a harbour with a shopping centre and way too many screeching seagulls.
Nice. The V+A waterfront is very nice. All the shops you need if thats what you are there for but shopping is not my thing. There are some lovely restaurants and bars

Such an ejoyable place to chill at. Great mall experience, so many dining options, beautiful area and lots of entertainment... walking there is so much fun ...
It's a must do when visiting Cape Town

Lively with lots of choice. We stayed within 15 minute walk of the waterfront and made a bee line for it when we arrived at our guest house.It had a great shopping mall with good selection and very reasonable prices.There was a great choice of restaurants, cafes and bars to choose from, catering to all tastes.The lunchtime specials in some of the more exclusive restaurants were very good, and sitting in their outside areas gave a great view of table mountain.While we were there the Volvo Ocean Race was in town, which brought a level of excitement to the area, with lots of singing, dancing and other attractions.

The place to see and to be!. All the best cafes, restaurants, shops, ets. are here. The views of the Table Mountain and the ocean are amazing. You can shop till you drop, eat, show yourself and see others, take a boat trip, watch the seals in the water, see the kano race, visit the Aquarium and so on and so on.

Shopping for all. If you don't particularly like crowds, I will not recommend this for December and January. It can get extremely busy with people from all over the world and the queues can get really long...but of course if you don't mind this...you will have a great time anytime. For the rest of us...try another month to experience all that the waterfront has to offer (really worth it).

Busy, buzzing place. I was actually staying in an hotel on the waterfront, so felt very much part of it all. A great atmosphere, especially at night with lots going on. It seems to be very safe with lots of security staff patrolling the area. I only wish I'd had more time to spend there so that I could have made use of some of the sea cruises and visited Robben Island. Next time!
Great Vibe. The place to be in cape Town. the restaurants are well priced here too
A real buzz of a place. Music food shops laughter just sheer fun . To walk around the waterfront puts you in touch with life . Try the slowest boat in the world Steam Boat Vicky !
Worth a visit. Excellent place to have a nice evening.. everywhere else in CPT closes at 5, except V&A. Shopping was so-so. Same thing everywhere... but good place to visit at night.
Lovely upbeat place. Lovely place to have a drink/ eat steak/ have a walk. lovely both during day and night. Lacks good shopping.
Lots to do!. Boat is tied up at the end of Jetty 2 so it was easy to walk into the waterfront, great shopping and fun bars!
Great for tourists, but lacks much character. Plenty of shops and restaurants. Lacks much character, could be pretty much anywhere in the world, but perfectly safe place to spend time
One of the best. Have visited many cities that have "Waterfronts" - New York, Baltimore, Barcelona, LA, Seattle....... but none really are as nice as the V & A Waterfront.
Shopping. If you want to shop while in Cape Town, then give yourself a whole day here, you will need it and probably more

Lots to see, lots to buy (if you like that sort of thing!). Lots of restaurants, shops, expensive and cheap, local art stuff, some spritual services, palm reading, tarot cards, back massage, so something for everyone. We had some lovely meals in Oyo, good service as well, seals playing in the harbour below us, a few people begging, but not as excessive as some places. Good place for people watching, while enjoying a good wine.
At the Waterfront. The Waterfront is full of shops and restaurants and on the street performances. We had a great time just walking around and getting lunch.

Tourist area. The shops and restaurants are nice and this is where you get the ferry to Robben Island which is worth a visit. But it is just shops and restaurants - good place to buy your souviegners but I don't go to Africa to shop I can do that at home.

plenty on offer. During our stay in Cape town we split our stay between Greenmarket Square and the V and A waterfront. We enjoyed the ease and luxury of a 2 bedroom apartment in the waterfront apartments, which we found to be excellent. Security was good, parking for our rental car and close to a wonderful working Harbour. The Waterfront has all the attractions and ammenitites. We could shop, dine and be entertained in truly beautiful surroundings. Heaps to do and seein the area, my wife especially loved the African trading co and the marvellous colonial style buildings

V&A with something for everyone!. We enjoyed the atmosphere, the sheer number of restaurants to choose from and the various activities available. From boat cruises to arts and crafts there really is something for everyone. We did not like the prices, they truly are a bit mad. R90 a hamburger?? Seriously? Parking is sometimes a bit of a mission since everything gets full very quickly but there are plenty so driving around looking normally resolves that.

OYSTERS AND CHAMPAGNE FOR BREAKFAST. We stayed for 3 nights , I decided to stay here thanks to other reviews -no regrets whatsoever. The best location in Cape town for a short stay and if you just want to relex , right in the middle of the action , and very safe. The hotel is good 4 stars ,with room in a regency style , our room was on a first floor with a small balcony and great views over the harbora and table mountain .The rate was a bit to high -£200 per night , I used to pay less for 5 stars hotels . This hotel one of the three sister hotels -there are The Dock house and Queen Victoria but defenitely the best location and best breakfast -apart from a huge buffet spread to include oysters and champange , there are hot breakfast of your choice .. Very friendly and helful staff. Best place to eat -restorante Balducci's ( located just 3 min walk in shopping mall) . The open top bus tours are great way to see everything in Cape town ( we took a red route which stops to Table mountain and marina. ( £12 pp)Taxi from airport aprox .£20- 24 . Will defenitely recommend this hotel to my friends to stay.

Nice to see but nothing more. Coming from Sydney we are used to a nice harbour and this was just another nice harbour.If you are in Cape Town head down for a walk and take some snaps of the Coca Cola crate man, the Nelson Mandela statue and then head back into the town for some good food. Prices are expensive down there so keep your money.

Vibrant and cosmopolitan. You wouldn't be blamed if you thought you were somewhere in Europe, with th trendy cafes, variety of high end shopping and vibrant atmosphere. The backdrop of table mountain makes it unique!
Cosmopolitan. Lots of places to eat and shop.Fairly expensive as you would expect.The shopping centre was much bigger than we expected.

Perfect scenery and in total harmony with the environment. This is one of my favorite spots in Cape Town. One could spend days here-dining, drinks, relaxing, shopping-all this right on the Atlantic Seafront.

Typical Seaport Development with a huge Mall. This is the typical seaport development that you find in New York, San Fran, Boston, etc. The Victoria mall is lovely and looks like a glass boat warehouse. Lots of restaurants and the typical mall stores except there are some stores with African goods. Some interesting musicians can be heard playing in the seaport area. This is a particularly safe area and well patrolled. You can also get boats to Robben Island and rentals here..
Lively place.. Many tourist spots such as Cruises , Jet boats , Robben Island , Aquarium, even Cape carnival happened near to this place... Its a lively place and most happening place in cape town.
Seals in the sea. I still cannot forget this scenery at the bridge when we passed and saw a dozen of seals playing around in the sea and showing off :) you will love them when you see them..
A great place to wander. We spent 2 whole days wandering in the Waterfront. There is great shopping in well presented malls and good eating experiences. The prices were reasonable for the area

Great place to start and return from.... We spent several days in Capetown, and often found ourselves starting or ending our day along the V&A Waterfront. We loved the fact there were so many great places to eat, quaint shops and an assortment of live entertainment available no matter time of day. The hub for most tourist activities, we picked up the On & Off bus here, caught the ferry to Robben Island and after watching another stunning sunset, we would have a nightcap (or two) to end our day....than call for a cab to bring us home. We found the area warm, inviting and not over touristy at all. Met lots of locals and had great meals here as well.
Great Food and Drink. Great bars and restaurants. Harbour House does a great fish platter. Spectacular views looking back at Table Mountain
Great place to shop. V&A waterfront has many varied shops - great places to eat within varied price ranges. It is the lauch point for the tour to Robbins Island and don't miss the views.

Very vibrant. We stayed in the village so only a short walk away from a very vibrant area both during the day and the evening. Lots of eating and shopping for those who wanted it. Then of course the usual things you would expect at a the waters edge.
V&A. Beautiful, but somewhat pricy. Good restaurants and shops, great views and generally relaxing atmosphere. A bit touristy, but that is part of the appeal, even for a local.
Very nice. Excellent place to socialize, day or night. Excellent bars and food

Shop 'till you drop. Excellent facilities. Entertainment amphitheatre brilliant with acts on every day. Loads of shops, bars and restaurants.
Shops are a bit expensive though. Lovely view from Waterfront.

Something for everyone. Whatever your needs are on any day you visit the waterfront, they will surely be met. A place to eat, to share a glass of wine, to buy that all important present, to watch the sailing boats enter harbour. What more can I say
Plenty to see. Lots of shops resturants and street entertainment. also grat view of table mountain and the waterfront.
Worth a visit. Enjoyed a leisurely drink here in the sunshine. Really handy to be able to exchange currency when there were problems with IT in the banks.
Super place. Everything you could possibly need can be found @ the V&A
Fun touristy place for shopping and food. A great place if it's raining for shopping and food. Some really good restaurants are inside. My favorite being Willoughby's.

This attraction justs gets better and better.. The level of this attraction justs gets better. The quality and variety of things to see and do and the restaurants are fantastic. Makes me so proudly South African. Great to see so many international visitors just loving the experience. Clean and organised with great security.
Touristy. Place for the tourists. Some good places to eat and drink but you will pay more than in Cape Town centre. This is the place to go for Robben Island, heli trips and water adventures
We loved the African Trading Post...best store in V&A waterfront.. Looked at many markets while in Cape Town and the African Trading post at V&A waterfront was the best.

Great Shopping, Great Dining and Great Views. I visited with my sister and some American friends who have moved to South Africa. I enjoyed having some local fish," Hake," at a nearby restaurant which had a great view of the pristine ocean. Then I shopped at the outdoor local market which was clean and organized. I got great bargains and gifts. I also went into an art gallery which was kinda expensive but worth the look. Then I ended my time there at a local store. the attendant graciously sold me stamps and offered to put my post card in the mail for me.

Belgian Beer. Try the belgian beer by the waterfront of the inner marina. Can't remember the name of the bistro but it's the one with the upside down African Queen above the bar area. The food was mouth watering too and the ambiance by the waters edge was superb for just chilling and watching the world go buy on land and water. Sit under an umbrella or catch some rays while you soak up the beer.

Waterfront. I was on a 2 week conference trip to Cape Town, and I have not been here for many years as I now live out of the country. However I really enjoyed the waterfront and spent a lot of time there and so did everyone that was with me. it has become rather pricy, especially for South Africans I would imagine, but they do very much cater for tourist, there are many wonderful places to sit by the waters edge for cocktails or sundowners. The food on the waterfront is not always that great, but the atmosphere certainly makes up for it. It is one of those places that you simply have to visit, I certainly enjoyed it.
Shopping Center. We went to the V&A but its really a shopping center and something you can do anywhere --- there are many other things unique to South Africa that would be better use of your time.

A taste of Cape Town in one centre.. Nothing in the world beats the Waterfront. Apart from the myriad of shops and fine restaurants, it is the hub of a working harbour, with all types of vessels entering and leaving all the time.The ferry to Robben Island, from the Waterfront, Sight seeing excursions by boat, the Waterfront, Helicopter jaunts, from here as well.From fine dining to beer halls and fast food restaurants, its all here.A wide variety of shops, cinemas, this centre lacks for nothing.We are almost daily at the Waterfront as the ideal central meeting place. Live shows on the side walks, or in the outside auditorium. A kids delight.Eveb a giant ferris wheel, you name it, its at the Waterfront.

Nice with lots to do ... can be expensive .... A good location with something for everyone ... hotels, restaurants, bars, fast food outlets. A variety of shops including designer brands (expensive by European standards), local crafts as well a variety local street performances. Regarded as one of the top sites when visiting Cape Town. Easy to get to by bus from the CBD as well as lots of parking. Well worth a visit

Always something on.. The V&A Waterfront is one of the best waterfronts with lots to do and see. Some very nice but busy restaurants, lots of shops or just a place to go for a walk and a drink. Always worths a visit.

Interesting - Feel Good Factor. Enjoyable visits.... come lunch time buzzing and vibrant with street entertainers and good cafes. Much variety. Some good value craft work.. some expensive. Ample shopping for those interested. also aquarium and Cape Town Eye which gives great views, Good place to relax, enjoy a drink and watch the world go by.

A must see but. Dont spend too long here as much better hotels restaurants bars and shops elsewhere. Easy to get there and parking very good. Access for the Robben Island tour which is the best thing around. Very pretty surrounds for a shopping centre though.

Great restaurants and some shopping. A good place to visit and to find restaurants and bars off all types. Also the place to take a sunset champagne cruise. Also, good just to have a walk about and do some window shopping and look at boats and yachts.

Very nice but expensive!. No stay in Cape Town would be complete without a visit to its famous waterfront. It has a wealth of shops and restaurants as weal as the Nelson Mandela Gateway which takes you to Robben Island - another must during any visit. Our impression was however that the majority of the other individuals there are also tourists and the prices everywhere reflect this, especially at the shops. The same is true at the craft market where you will pay at least double for the same type of souvenir that you may get from a Cape Town Market. On the other hand there are soma amazing artists exhibiting in there which are well worth a perusal.

Loved the athmosphere there. V & A Waterfront is always full of people, especially on the weekends. They have some really good restaurants, the Quay 4 can be recommended, and Sevruga for best sushi in the world! Believe me, we are not sushi fans, but there sushis were amazing! Especially the baked ones. No wonder it's always ful. Balducci's for italian food is also great.We have tried the Cape Town Wheel, no big deal, I believe, and went to the Aquarium, now that was great!
Interesting if very touristy. Great sights of an active port surrounded by very touristy attractions and restaurants. Some nice eating in the early evenings watching the boats come and go

Confine those tourists!. The waterfront is a great place to have fun, eat and spend money if you dont have the time or inclination to explore Capetown beyond the designated tourist area. Trading post, hotels, shops, diving gear, ferris wheel and a giant monument made out of Coke boxes are the key. Suvenir items are top quality but also top price. The ferry to Robben Island and the museum are located here. Short bus ride from the train station or a shuttle from your hotel. Worth visiting but I prefer St Georges Mall and Observatory and getting out to the Townships.

Lively!. Our hotel was on the waterfront, which is a good lively place to wander around. There are usually street entertainers around, lots of eating places, boat trips, aquarium, craft market etc.One of the highlights of Cape Town.
You never get tired. Plenty to see, do and eat/drink - helicopter rides, boat rides, harbour cruises, aquarium, hunt for semi precious stones - something for all the family
Pretty but very touristy. Enjoyed a walk there and a pint in the German bar.

Anything a tourist or shopper could want. This place has it all in the way of the areas best shopping and culinary experiences. I would say there is 10 - 15 of the cities finest restaurants plus hundreds of stores in the adjoining mall and shops. Virtually any clothing, grocery, or pharmacy item a person could want could be purchased here. Easy parking too. This area could be enjoyed in good weather or rainy weather.

Just OK. While it is nice that this area has been cleaned up and is safe it seemed like a collection of souvenier shops and restaurants and the cultural side of life is missing. I did like the African Trading Port, which had more that just the knick-knacks I was anticipating. The wine shop was also nice to pick up a couple of bottles and bring back to the hotel. I didn't like all of the people badgering the tourists to take cruises... it felt like walking the gauntlet.
Good place to shop/eat. Plenty of interest here also up market shops and supermarkets

No justice to the royal names. Compared to Canal Walk, Century City, V & A cannot supercede the ambiance and experience. The harbour attraction is perhaps the only star at the V & A establishment. If it were'nt for this, I would not visit V & A.
Lively fun place !. We love everything about the V and A ...from the boat trips to the music and food ,Wonderful atmosphere and currently there is a big wheel which we reccomend!.

Fun bars, restaurants, hotels and great stores all within walking distance. Many bars ask you to remove your hat before entering.The scenic bus tour is a great way to see Cape Town. Go early in the day so you can stop in Camps Bay for a few hours.
One of the best waterfronts in the world.. The Cape Waterfront is full of people from all over the world having fun. It has a unique vibe.
Great place to party and watch sports. This was the hangout of choice during the world cup and was agreat fun. Plenty of bars, restaurants, shopping etc.

a way to pass some time. Too kitsch for our tastes. Very touristy but pretty since it is on the water and since it is so popular, makes for some good people watching. Worth a "look see" for an hour or so, or go for dinner, but choose carefully—ask your concierge for recommendations.

Pretty much a big mall, but a fun atmosphere. The V&A Waterfront is a fun place to visit. There is a lot of security in the area, so we felt very safe. There is a mall and several pretty decent restaurants in the area. It is also the location that you go to in order to catch the ferry to Robben Island. The V&A is not a destination in and of itself, but it is a good place to go and be with other people and catch a bite to eat.

Tourist central!. You obviously have to come here as a tourist/visitor to Cape Town, not least because some of the attractions like the open top bus and the ferry to Robben Island leave from here. But it's not really a particularly special place. It has a rather sterile feel, and you could be almost anywhere in the Western world, except perhaps when you glimpse Table Mountain and are reminded where you are. Fundamentally, it's a rather artificial place.There are lots of restaurants, but we never had a particularly special meal here. you certainly pay special prices, though - everything here will cost more, sometimes significantly more. The exception is parking, which is very reasonable. It depends what you are looking for, really. If you want to stay in a safe tourist bubble then maybe this is the place for you. I would suggest staying outside it (the hotels here are very expensive) and popping in and out when you need to or feel like it. See a bit of the real Cape Town as well. But it's ok to wander around, it just didn't feel all that South African.
Shopper's delight. A great mix of trendy, boutique and everyday stores with many options for yummy food!

The best way to spend an evening in Cape Town. We spent almost every evening at the waterfront. There is a huge choice of great restaurants and bars and there is a great vibe down there. Lots of the restaurants offer an al fresco dining option and you can eat dinner and watch the sun go down over table mountain. what more could you want!

Touristy but what do you expect?. This is a tourist destination and shopping mall. It is in my opinion good at what it does. All the shops you could need during a trip are there and there are some good restaurants too - Den Anker, Harbour House. There is a cinema also and the parking was free between 6pm- 10pm. Very safe.

I just love this place!. The first time I visited the V&A was as a young boy with my family. At that stage, only the first phase was operational. Over the years I saw it growing but it is always a treat for me to visit the place. Quay 4 is one of my favourite places to have some sundowners - or just to sit and watch some of the street performers....I think the V&A has something for just about everyone! A visit to the Cape is not complete without spending some time here.

Great Recreation & Dinning. The shopping Mall is excellent, bits of everything. The restaurants have good varieties and reasonable prices. Good service. Lots of excursions on offer. Street Performers at all time. It is just a very fun, relax and enjoyable place to be.
Good food.shopping and very relaxing. Take a sunset boat trip. Good idea to do the Robben Island tour the same day as it leaves from here.
