It should be visited both at day and night. There are many cruises departing from here, including the ferry to Robben Island. The place is very safe at all times, even in the middle of the night.
Stunning!. Absolutely beautiful. a very friendly place with great restaurants and plenty to keep you entertained.
Shopping and eating at it's best. Everything you need, appeals to all. Shopping and resturants all in one place. Chill out enviroment
AMAZING!!. experience the walking over there, where there lots of restaurants, souvenir shops, performers all over the place
Excellent shopping centre. A very enjoyable place to do some shopping and have a meal and also soakup the atmosphere that is unique to South Africa
typical tourist trap. nice and clean place, but typical tourist trap with no locals and older white tourists, if that's your thing. must go here to catch boat to Robben Island
Bit over commercialised. Slightly disappointing, we were expecting more of a wow factor and found it very touristy, much preferred the quieter parts of Cape Tow , however, worth a visit.

Tourist shopping but still excellent. It's a tourist destination - make no mistake. But the shopping is good and dining at the waterfront is just fun. They also have lots of street music that is great to enjoy!
Wow. Our overseas guests just loved the Waterfront. It has improved so much over the years. Loved the music and the vibe.

For all your shopping and dining desires. Unfortunately the V&A Waterfront is much like other malls around the world. The main mall offers excellet shopping and the area has many restaurants from casual to upscale including Balthazer with the world's largest selection of wine by the glass and Spur's the Bonanza of South Arfica. Worth a later afternoon visit.

Great place to hang out and take in the scene. Nice place to hang out in nice weather. Seems to popular with the locals as well as with tourists, lots of bars, restaurants, street performances etc. Also a good mall right in the centre with all the standard stores and a nice supermarket. Not a very scenic setting though - for that go to the waterfront at Camp's Bay.
Lots for the tourist ... Great resturants and shops, plus lots of outdoor entertaining. A great place to while away a beautiful afternoon / evening in Cape Town

Great time at the waterfront. I had the privilege to visit the waterfront twice on my past trip to Cape Town, and it is well worth it. There are great shops to purchase souvenirs and also restaurants with delicious food. I would certainly recommend it to anyone who enjoys shopping.
V&A Waterfront. Plenty to see and do, with loads of places to eat. A mixture of old and new.
Still Cape Town's vibiest shopping destination. Great stores, location to die for and a few exquisite restaurants! What more could you ask for?

Tourist + local mecca. The V&A is often criticised as being touristy however this waterfront is loved by locals and you certainly get a great blend of cultures both local and international visitors thus making it a delight to wander around.
Nice environment. Give your self a good time to go to the waterfront, many good shops, restaurants and café's including San Marcos that have the motto "life is short - eat desert first!" :)

trendy and fun. loved the harbour view,street musicians,boats comin in,and the seals!Busy execs can get a shoe shine,and one store has a proper
british shave.
Not so much liked the prices,and watch your wallets/purses.
Fantastic. Every course perfect for every meal. The location itself would be worth the 5 stars but the food deserved six.
Shopping in beautiful surroundings. There is no better position for a shopping mall like this. You find everything you need and there are still lots of outstandling restaurants
Lots to see and do. Plenty going on everywhere; restaurants, live music, boats, shops.
Touristy. Nice harbour waterfront, lots of restaurant and a shopping mall, a place to go to if the weather is bad,
V&A Waterfront. Lot's to see and do - numerous restaurants and shops plus always something going on.
Iceeeeee baby .... The ice-cream and ice skating + shops rides Atmosphere movies
Cfrat Shed and live music. Loads of fun - don't forget the very good Aquarium next door.

Luxuary which is quite non-African. This is a very luxury place. You see a lots of restaurants but most of all, the most luxuary shops. All the big players are overhere...And if you want to find a good restaurant, it's a good place. In the Waterfront, it's quite safe. But take into account that you have to go back to yor hotel and this is not always that safe.
Food and shops and views. What a great combination, food, shopping and views to die for.
Tourist trap. Avoid. It's for tourists. I know you are one, but there are so many other places to eat and shop.
An allround enjoyable day/night delight. Great local 'street entertainment' , plenty of shopping and a huge range of affordable quality restaurants.

fun, touristry, a lot to take in all at once. I looked forward to visiting the V & A Waterfront cos I had heard so much about it. It was a nice tourist attraction. I went there on 4 different occasions to do different things, eat sushi, go to robben island, shop at the malls, morning boat ride, the aquarium, etc. It has a lot of things, hotel, places to eat, things to buy, things to see. It was cool. You can get there with a Minibus Taxi, A regular taxicab, you can drive or you can take the red/blue sightseeing bus and its one of the stops along the routes as well.

Number 2 sight in CPT!. V&A Waterfront is a good example for how to reuse a former industrial area. There are many high prices international fashion shops but you can also find "MrPrice" "CLICKS" and other siscount shops. V&A also hoststwo pub breweries, PAULANER and MITCHELLS, the latter with beer from Knysna. There is a big variety of restaurants as welll. Street musicians entertain vistors all over the place. V&A is a must for all visitors to CPT!
Lots to see and do.. Loved it very much. Lots of activity, restaurants, shopping, etc. It takes a couple of visits to get the feel of the place. Nothing to dislike about it.
Very buzzing atmosphere. It's got shopping, very good restaurants and lots to see and do. Spend a day there, and see what's on offer. Worthwhile.
good shopping. Be sure to go to the craft marketplace....i got some good deals there!

Very touristy but OK in some ways. Packed with people, lots of tacky shops, and the shops in the malls could be anywhere. But - the old harbour is lovely, The Thai restaurant is out of this world, and some of the shops selling african art and design are very good.

Too much tourist tat and generic stores. Interesting setting but it was full of global brand shops which you can get anywhere and the "local" shops are full of tourist tat. Go to look, but dont bother staying too long. Some of the restaurants are probably worth a visit in the evening.

Just another tourist precinct. While it sounds like the V&A redevelopment has revitalised pars of Cape Town, the resulting area is no different to many similar areas we have across Australia with its selection of restaurants, souvenir shops, fashion boutiques and other generic shop fronts that you'll find around the world.

A class act!. With strolling musicians - marimba, African a cappella choirs, jazz band and pan flutes to excellent boutiques, restaurants and activities, dono't miss the V & A Waterfront! DO MISS the trip to Robben Island.

day of enjoyment. This V&A is absolutely glorious, the amount of shops inside the 2 shopping malls were great.The cleanliness of every where around the area was excellent,every day they had entertainment in the square and most of the were really good.there was a big screen tv that played in the amphitheatre showing documentaries,was very peaceful to sit around,plenty of outdoor restaurants and brilliant cafe inside "Exclusive Books" in the V&A mall you can choose book/magazine to browse through while have something to eat/drink.There is a smaller version of THE LONDON EYE.
Robben Island. we missed out on Robben Island trip as we had not booked eaerly enough, make sure you do

THE BEST WATERFRONT EVER. We never tire of visiting the V&A during our trips to Cape Town. The shopping, entertainment, restaurants, views, safe parking, visible security and overall atmosphere all contribute to a great 'day out'. The reason why this WATERFRONT is so special is probably because it is contained within a working harbour and docks complex. If you visit Cape Town do not miss out on this place.

Nice Tourist area. The waterfront area is nice and you can find any store of almost any kind here. It had all the very high end stores in the mall. I wasn't overly impressed with the restaurants, but we had some good food. It seemed set up for rich tourists. It was safe, but a bit boring. I prefer the downtown area where it seems more authentic and lively.

This is an awesome place to get lost in. shopping, eating, and waterfront departures go from here. It is a tourist mecca and worth the visit. Try the tapas bar that over-looks the warf for an afternoon rest in-between shopping and touring about.

So much to choose from. There is every type of shop here from Crabtree and Evelyn, Istore and Shaminski Jewelers, to small local hand made crafts, so plenty to see. The location is wonderful with the backdrop of Table mountain on one side and the Atlantic ocean on the other, which sets it apart from other waterfront shopping centres. There is lots of entertainment going on in the centre with african musical artists and dancers, great atmosphere.

Good shopping but the food is expensive, shop around. We liked the shopping as all the famous brands are available. Mall is open to late in the evenings and you are not exposed to the Cape wind. Be carefull at some of the restaurants as they can be expensive and service poor. Shop around, take your time and observe before you sit down.
Great place for people watching. Visited the V&A three times in the two weeks we were there. Had some great meals and shopped till we dropped. Great street entertainers by the amphitheatre.
A must. Great palce to visit, but better during the week than the weekend, prices vary, but you will find what you want.
Fun place. good restuarents good wine shop good shopping always something different going on
Shop, eat & drink. This place is buzzing, there are loads of shop, restaurants and bars. Its not cheap and is full of tourists!

Waterfront is a great shopping & entertainment centre. I actually often do regular grocery & clothes shopping here since I live close by.
it's pleasant on weekday evenings, and has ample parking space. I'm just not a fan of when it's super-crowded.
Otherwise it's great, convenient, beautiful, you can do boat rides there, get yummy food and watch movies in addition to shopping there.
Shops to die for. Great shops and bars too many to visit in a day make sure you have your credit cards!
Just another shopping area. This location did not impress me. Other than shopping and dining and maybe visiting the aquarium, there's not much you can see there.
Great place!. That is where the excitment happens! Marimba bands, nice restaurants and great attractions. If you go to Cape Town you wouldn´t want to miss the Waterfront!
Touristy. Yes, the Waterfront is beautiful. But it's a very expensive area, so don't buy curious here--rather buy them outside the central station where they're much cheaper.
Spend hours here. Great everything. shops, restaurants, outdoor entertainment, and a very safe area. Can get ferry to Robben Island from here.

Beautiful but pricey.. A lovely part of Cape Town with grand hotels, plenty of bars/restaurants and expensive shopping. Don't expect any bargains here though. Nice to see some seals swimming around the bay though.

Must visit. Good area to visit, many shops, cafe resturants, supermarket other shops. So you shop till your wallet is empty ot you nee drest or help to carry bags !!! All shopping needs to suit visitors , make sure sure you check out prices before you buy can vary according to where shop is-- you might be able to buy better after a time looking and checking out. Good luck have a good time and mind your bank balance you can get carried awayyyyyyyy !!!!!If you take a car good parking ... safe ---- fee to park but not expensive to park.Other attractions on site... you can take trips into harbour...

An experience - for all. An eclectic wharf - full of shops restaurants curios people street performances and yes the quintessential tourist nick nacks!!! Take a lazy stroll along the water, sit down take a bite or drink some wine you are in Cape Town after all!!! Take in the fire eater the dancers the contortionists and the musicians. Agreed almost all port cities have a wharf - but its Capetown its just different somehow!!!Caution - it is heavily touristy!!!

Pleasant, Practical, Peaceful. As I approached the footbridge to cross the water to the Mandela Gateway, it rose to allow a sailboat to pass. I photographed this and many other picturesque scenes, drank in the charming maritime atmosphere, strolled the numerous interesting shops, visited the artisans and perused their crafts, enjoyed the singers along the streets, noticed the varied places to snack and dine, watched a seal soak up the sun on a dock. ... What a pleasant way to spend an afternoon after a week of touring the cape. If shopping is an obligatory part of your travel, I think you can find every possible souvenir you're looking for right here!

Lovely way to spend the day or evening.. We love this place. Bustling with street performers muscusians dancers and acrobats. Lots of wonderful shopping in both the large adjacent shopping cetre or the African crafts market and vendors. The area is like a large navy pier or waterfront with so much to offer un the way of restaurants bars and pubs. There are lots od tour companies offering boat cruises and scenic sails. We were there during te rugby world cup and there was face painting and they were showing the game in the bug screen in the square. Just a lovely clean safe place to stroll around or head for lunch or dinner. A must see while visiting cape town

Tourist place. We visited Watefront in every visit of Cape Town and we must say that is really great place. Many "tourist" atractions, BUT this place has very specific spirit, singers&dancing bands are very offen! Over Volvo Ocean boat race you can see many interestings boats with international crew! Its very good place for visitors which are first time at Africa continent and they can very slow addapted to Africa we think Last time my wife and son visited Panoramatic Wheel and they really enjoyed :-)

Wonderful Stay. Three couples stayed at the VA Aug. 2011. The hotel is very nice and clean. The rooms are large with a wonderful view of Table Mountain. The location can't be beat. Although it was a bit cold in August our stay couldn't have been better.

Great waterfront landing for Cape Town. Stayed at the V&A for 3 nights for business recently. Mid winter is not Cape Town's best season, but the waterfront location is unbeatable regardless of the weather. The hotel is very nice, and the breakfast is very good (especially the continental spread...) The hotel itself feels a little dated now. Perhaps time for a make over. The shower door was half broken, the decor feels a bit late 1990s. The staff were great, and the location for dining at night perfect. Unfortunately my room had a view just of the entrance - make sure you book a waterfront view.

classy, efficient, great views & great rooms!. We stayed 3 nights at the V&A ; immaculate, clean & modern with just the right touch of class. Fantastic views of the harbour & table mountain from spacious rooms with the biggest bed! Staff were efficient and friendly - and the breakfast was absolutely amazing!! Great position and looks beautfiul inside & out : highly recommended!

Shopping and Dining. Great place to spend either a rainy or sunny day. We went here when it was tipping it down since there is a large indoor shopping centre attached to the V&A. Had all the shops you could need and is very safe. Also spent a few evenings in the restaurants and bars and whilst it is commercial... it has a great buzz about the place and the food is very good. Yes its commercial but so too is Covent Garden, Sydney harbour and The Bund but i wouldnt miss them for the world.

Capetown Five Star Venue. Wonderful tourist site with restaurants shops music. Band shell featured Delft Big Band (great youth band and amazing vocalist) under direction of jazz trumpeter Ian Smith. Other groups shared stage stage throughout day for free entertainment.

Amazing pictures can easily oversell the V&A Waterfront. Caveat: We liked the V&A waterfront, it does have a lot to offer, see, taste and photograph but its area is quite small and much there is expensive and overpriced. The setting below Table Mountain makes this place iconic and world-class. However, its smaller than you'd expect, crowded with little (expensive) shops and restaurants (very expensive - not very good food). But there is still some good to be had there. Pros: The photos of table mountain you can take here are amazing. The local craft market halls are nice to see and a good place to spend some money as many of the artists and sellers deal in local goods, arts and crafts. The Two Oceans Aquarium is a very nice (pricey) stop. The Ocean Basket restaurant is the same price as their other branches and affords excellent views as well, making it the best choice there, value for money. Cons: Many expensive shops but ok as you don't have to buy anything. The restuarants are surprisingly poor but charge very high fees. Anywhere else in the world, they would go out of business quickly but they seem to survive on the V&A Waterfront. I had a expensive yet poor meal in 2004 and repeated that mistake during our recent trip. We ate at the Ocean Basket for our second meal, much cheaper and actually quite a good meal of calamari and sole. Thus, we highly recommend giving your business to them over the more posh sit-down restos overlooking the marina and mountain. They are clearly selling you the mountain view, not a great meal! Another problem with the V&A Waterfront is that you expect to be amazed when you visit here. Unfortunately, its just nice not amazing so you can easily feel a bit disappointed. Keep your expectations in check and you can enjoy your visit to the V&A.

Far too commercialised. On my first trip to Cape Town, I was very excited about going to the Waterfront, however it was nothing like what I imagined. The area is very pretty, with some lovely views out to see and back to Table Mountain, however that is where the enjoyment really stops. The area is extremely built up now. Thousands and thousands of apartments and lots of large brand name hotels. The area is dominated by a large shopping centre, with many shops which you could see anywhere around the world. Not many of them are unique to Cape Town or South Africa. Prices are crazy when compared to normal South African prices. The restaurants again are dominated by large chain names at prices which want to make you cry. I don’t really consider this area to give you much of an insight into South Africa or Cape Town, you could be in any shopping area in the UK or the US. Personally I believe that if you want to experience ‘true’ South Africa, then you are must better off eating at some local restaurants, away from the Waterfront (which will be a ¼ of the price) and definitely finding a hotel away from the area as well.It’s one of those places which you have to go and see if you are in the area, just to be able to say you have been there. However I always leave with the overwhelming feeling, that I am so glad that I am not staying here!

Nice enough place to walk around but generally felt overdeveloped and sterile.. Lots of restaurants, malls, boat trips going out, some wandering minstrels, a bit of history kept alive and will keep kids quiet cor an afternoon but over developed to the point where its losing it's character and overall misses the buzz that it should have.

Doesn't live up to the hype. I am sad to say that Cape Town in general does not live up to its reputation as a world class city in the same leage as Sydney and San Francisco. To be honest, it has a great view - an awesome view. But you can't put any old ragtag town at the bottom of a great view and call it a world class city. The V&A waterfront is at the heart of the 'great view' and it's a pleasant enough way to spend an afternoon. But really, it's just a tourist ghetto. Bars, restaurants and tat-shops a-plenty with all the tourists herded in. It's very 'plastic.' But look up, and there's Table Mountain looking ancient and majestic, so that's it's get-out-of-jail free card. Take in the view, take your pictures, and you've done here.

Nothing special. This is a place which you can find in many cities. It has your typical shopping, cinema and food places. If you have free time and want to shop then visit here but if you dont have a lot of time it isnt really worth the visit.

Pretty, touristy and lots of shopping. Being a tourist, I think it's worth visiting although I'd never go there if I were local. Too crazy! Lots of shopping- both mall shops and touristy shops. A fun way to spend the afternoon and the restuarants looked good.

magic spot but can be a bit busy. very upmarket section and a very popular section and a market section. Most restaurants overpriced and not great value, great for drink and cocktails overlooking harbour

Beautiful waterfront with lots of restaurants and shops. The V&A Waterfront is a beautiful waterfront, with lots of restaurants, shops, two indoor crafts market, the Two Oceans Aquarium, and a huge shopping mall. It's worth a visit just to see the place, but how long you want to stay depends on what kind of things you like to do. If you don't enjoy shopping at all, then just go there to take a stroll and have a coffee/drink, or have a meal there. If you enjoy shopping, you could easily spend your whole day there.

Magic. The V&A Waterfront is excellent way to spend a day. Markets, shops, boat trips, theatre, wine and dine and amazing views of harbour and table mountain. Restaurants can be hit and miss, but most are good quality but on the pricy side. Go for a sundown cruise and cocktails , shopping prices inflated, try Canal Walk instead
good hotel, kind of touristy. I think this its a great place with an even better location, but it has become a Tourist only location, and you feel walking on disneyland

World class venue in stunning setting. As an inhabitant of Cape Town, I have watched the V&A Waterfront grow from humble beginnings into one of South Africa's top tourist attractions. It offers something for every taste, age and age group. With over 50 restaurants or bars, many of them with outdoor seating, you can observe ships coming and going, observe tourists from all over the world, whilst enjoying a meal from a cuisine or country of your choice. If shopping is your thing, you can literally shop 'til you drop. The well stocked Aquarium features sea creatures from every continent. Ample parking and excellent security make this an enjoyable venue. Please allow a full day, this place is very large.
Very nice. This is a nice place to go in Cape Town. For shopping or for meals, this is a beautiful place, with nice stores and many different options. It's easy to get with a cab.

Nice area. The Waterfront is a beautiful place to relax, have a drink and grab a few gifts for friends at home. The prices are a bit high, but that is to be expected when you have a lovely area with restaurants, shopping and entertainment. Camp's Bay and the Waterfront were our two favorite places for a sundowner. Belthazar has wonderful steaks and an amazing wine list and there is also a German Beer Garden. Very nice!

Touristy, but worth a stroll. If you need a retail buzz head to the V & A. There are numerous shopping opportunities interspersed with coffee shops, up market and family restaurants. I liked the coffe shop at Exclusive Books, which is also a must see if you like books.The working harbour is also at your doorstep and if you visit when I did in January, take in a concert at the Aquafest. Here the voices of the African Black Mombaza were challenged by the local seals!Sure, it's a bit of a tourist trap, but you'll enjoy it.PS it's also the departing point for the trips to Robben Island

Interesting, Socially Responsible Gifts. In case you're looking for unique, well-made, and socially responsible Africa-related gifts to bring back home, check out the "Janine Jones Creations" stall in the Waterfront market. Her outfit sells a variety of products adorned with decorative ostrich egg shells, which employs a network of single mothers from the Cape Flats township.My girlfriend and I bought a series of well designed, high quality (we hope) bowls for Xmas gifts for loved ones, and even picked one for ourselves. This stall - as well as a few others near by selling similar socially responsible gifts - were the highlight of our visit to the Waterfront

Very touristy. V&A Waterfront is the most touristy place in all of Cape Town. It's a very nice place--lovely modern shopping mall, upscale restaurants, cool coffee shops, and a functioning harbor to boot!The restaurants are definitely not my style--lots of white-tablecloth type places, pricey, definitely geared toward tourists. I would much rather eat where the locals eat.But, the shopping is great! There are no fancy designer boutiques that no one can afford to shop at. Rather, the stores are geared toward the average tourist budget. I love the Exclusive Books there! Lots of African theme stores, although prices are higher than elsewhere.I'm giving a 3 rating instead of 4 because of the lack of maps and directions. The entire V&A Waterfront is a large complex, with lots of buildings. If you are looking for a specific store or restaurant, it is very difficult to find it while driving through. You'll have to park, then walk--potentially a kilometer to the other side of the V&A--to look for a directory of shops/restaurants.

Shopping, eating, drinking, people watching. Locals may think the Waterfront is a bit of a tourist trap, but I love it. It has a very European atmosphere to it and you can shop - anything from supermarket to Armani and diamonds! Recommend the Carol Boyes shop for quirky household objects and 50% of the price vs UK and Cape Union Mart for anything outdoorsy. You can sit with a coffee and watch the world go by, eat fine dining, have a glass of wine, take a boat trip. Great place to spend a day

Tourist trap. On the whole I hated this place. The restaurants were over priced and the food like nasty British pub food. Its OK for a stroll or to go to the cinema but to spend night after night here is to deny a great cape town experience.

Cape Town's main tourist attraction. One doesn't really visit the V&A Waterfront as much as experience it. Most visitors will at least pass through here on even the most cursory visits to the city and while visiting more subtantial sites such as Robben Island.Pros: Endless entertainment and dining options, from solitary musicians and colorful dance groups to essentially any major type of cuisine you could imagine. There are also nearby hotels from mid-range (V&A) to upscale (Cape Grace) and, once again, endless shopping options as well. Being a major tourist attraction, it is also very safe, easily accessible, and mostly affordable.Cons: Well, being a major tourist attraction it is also, how shall we say, very "touristy." Imagine Pier 39 in San Francisco without the sea lions yelping in the background and you pretty much have this place. At first (and second and maybe third) glance it seems rather superficial, but again this is somewhat to be expected. You have to travel a bit more "inland" to find a more authentic experience.

Great Place to Stay. Bustling, with top class shopping, top class eating and a great atmosphere, buskers, entertainers etc..If you want an authenitic African experience, go backpacking in bush, the Waterfront is civilised and pleasant. A great place for a city break.

Sunset Cruise. The V&A Waterfront is built for touists and has the obligatory curiosity shops, restaurants and other commercial establishments. It's very busy and for many, this is the target destination spot where everyone seems to go.After doing some research, I advanced booked a sunset cruise with the Maharani Yacht company aboard their clipper ship and this proved to be the highlite of our Waterfron visit. Cindy and I were the only two passengers booked for the Monday night (December 30th) cruise and the captain inisted on taking us despite our concerns about him not having enough to justify the outing. The two young crew members were attentive and eager, especially Kenneth. We were the beneficiaries of a beautiful sunset and a thrilling sail through the slightly choppy waters before returning to the Waterfont.This is a great value and I'd strongly recommend Maharani Yacht.

Great stay at the V&A. We stayed at the V&A during our visit to Cape Town, and we were not disappointed. The staff was very friendly and very professionel, the food was good, the location great and the room was clean, modern and comfortable. We were very well taken care of and will definately choose to stay there again when going back to Cape Town. When you book try and get one of the rooms facing the mountains - they have amazing views.

Beautiful Views, Terrific Service. The Victoria and Alfred was truly a treat. It is clear that this hotel understands guest service and makes it a high priority. Staff members were friendly and helpful at every turn. Everyone, from the front desk staff to the housekeepers were quick to greet guests in a friendly manner.The room we were in was both enormous and very well appointed. The mountain view was spectacular. The hotel would do well to market not only the view of the mountain but the view of the harbor as well. Each morning, we awoke to views of seals sunning themselves on the dock below. Watching the seals play and the boats coming in and out of the harbor just added to a terrific experience.The only negative with regard to the hotel itself is that it is located in a major tourist area. Restaurants and bars abound close by, including the very noisy Green Dolphin located on the ground floor of the hotel’s building. We had already heard of noise complaints for rooms on the opposite side of the hotel but had not heard of these problems in the mountain view rooms. Our room shared a wall with the Green Dolphin and the music, drumbeats, etc. floated right into the room. To the hotel’s credit, when we called to complain about 11:30 one evening, the hotel’s guest services department said they would call to put a stop to it immediately. Within two minutes, music at the bar had been shut down (apparently the hotel has an agreement with the bar to end music around 11PM).The noise issue was not a major bother for us, but I would hesitate to recommend the hotel to those who go to bed early. Again, it is not a major concern, but one that should be considered for guests willing and able to afford a property of this caliber.

well worth visiting. Very touristy - but well worth visiting to shop and then sit with a drink and watch the sun go down behind table mountain. Long St, Kloof St, Greenmarket Sq and around Parliament are more the real Cape Town (and have better restaurants) but the V&A is definately worth going to - especially if you're a first time visitor to SA

We Loved the Waterfront. My family and i just got back from Cape Town and we absolutely loved the Waterfront. I disagree with all the negative comments about it. We had a great time eating out there, all the restaurants had such great views and phenomenal service, the staff in all restaurants were very humerous and entertaining. Especially since we have 3 teenagers, there are a huge amount of family restaurants at the waterfront that the kids loved. There's also lots of entertainment going on. Buskers playing/singing African Music while you stroll along or eat lunch is also very pleasent..THe prices were extremely reasonable compared to Australia as well. We were there in winter, and on the couple of days where the weather was incredibly ordinary, going to the waterfront was the best possible option. It's warm and the shopping centers are very nicecly designed, especially Victoria Wharf. No one said that you had to spend your entire holiday there, as Cape Town has so, so much to offer, But the Waterfront is definately a nice place to come at least once while you are in Cape Town, who knows, you may keep coming back like we did.

The Americanisation of Africa continues. It may be unfair saying Americanisation, as this place reminds me of many shopping districts around the world, but I guess they appeared in America first. I'm reminded of harbour fronts in New York, San Francisco and Boston to name three. Its a safe place to visit and its fine for shoppers and those looking for a reasonable meal, but I was bored after an hour and wanted to see a bit more of the real South Africa.You can buy the same artefacts much cheaper elsewhere and there are many restaurants that serve more interesting food at cheaper prices (Heritage Square for example).Worth a visit, maybe even a (very) short stay, but there is so much more to see in and around Cape Town.

Unforgettable even after 8 years. We stayed there as a family eight years ago and loved it! Never forgotten the hotel or the area. We will return! And we thank our South African travel agent in CapeTown - Rufaro - for selecting the place and guiding us to it. In comparison, Jo-berg is a slum!BG KoshyBangaloreIndia

Yep - miles too touristy, in fact!. I agree with the previous post - it's a plastic tourist trap, sanitised, clean, safe, spendy. If that's what you're into you'll love it, but if you're looking for something at all authentic, it will simply waste your time. Personally I hated it, but if you want a big open-air mall sort of experience, the setting is pretty and the shops upmarket.
